SummaryOfEvents:
THE RUSSIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'DANADI 1' CAUGHT FIRE IN CAPTAIN'S CABIN WHILST BERTHED AT YEYSK, RUSSIA AT 0630 HOURS LT ON 01/01/13. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

FIRE FIGHTING ATTEMPTS BY CREW UNSUCCESSFUL. BLAZE SUBSEQUENTLY EXTINGUISHED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM LOCAL FIRE SERVICES. 1 CREW MEMBER DEAD. 2 OTHER PERSONS SUSTAINED SMOKE INHALATION INJURIES AND TAKEN TO LOCAL HOSPITAL. INVESTIGATION EFFECTED. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN. REPORTED CAUSE OF FIRE WAS ELECTRICAL SHORT CIRCUIT IN HEATING EQUIPMENT.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: 115 MILES WEST OF KRUTOGOROVA, KAMCHATKA, RUSSIA
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
SUSTAINED MAIN ENGINE FAILURE IN THE SEA OF OKHOTSK 115 MILES WEST OF KRUTOGOROVA, KAMCHATKA, RUSSIA IN LAT. 55 03N., LONG. 152 20E., AT 0130 HOURS LT ON 01/10/13. SUBSEQUENTLY SOLD FOR BREAKING UP.
FV 'ANASTASIYA' ATTENDED THE SCENE AS SAFETY VESSEL. TAKEN IN TOW OF FV 'K. EMERALDA' ON 01/10/13. TOW SUBSEQUENTLY TRANSFERRED TO FV 'BUZANSKIY' AND CONVOY ARRIVED AT PETROPAVLOVSK-KAMCHATSKY, RUSSIA ON 08/10/13 FOR INSPECTION.

Location: ATLANTIC OCEAN 75 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CAPE AGULHAS, SOUTH AFRICA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE SOUTH AFRICAN-FLAGGED STERN TRAWLER 'HARVEST GARDENIA' FOUNDERED IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 75 MILES SOUTHWEST OF CAPE AGULHAS, SOUTH AFRICA IN LAT. 35 18S., LONG. 018 48E., ON 01/01/13.

ALL CREW RESCUED BY NEARBY VESSELS. NO INJURIES REPORTED.

At 1818 (LT) on 30 December 2012, a fire broke out in the women sauna room of the passenger vessel Carnival Spirit, whilst en route from Mystery Island, Vanuatu to Sydney Australia. 

Automatic fire/heat detection devices activated and alerted the crew.  Although the fire was contained inside the sauna room, the fixed water dry sprinkler system did not activate and the fire was extinguished manually. 

The safety investigation has concluded that the fire was caused by the placement of the women’s sauna wooden cedar floor grate on top of the frame work surrounding the sauna’s heating element/hot stones. 

An examination of the dry sprinkler pipe and check valve revealed that the latter was blocked in the closed position and did not open due to corrosion/oxidation of the valve seat. 

The safety investigation has also found that there were no specific maintenance records for the fixed dry sprinkler system in the sauna.

THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP "OCEAN LEGACY" SUSTAINED 25 DEGREE LIST TO PORT, STRUCK QUAY AND SANK WHILST DISCHARGING CARGO AT ORMOC, PHILIPPINES AT 0730 HOURS LT ON 29/12/12. WRECK REFLOATED AND SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO NAVOTAS, MANILA, PHILIPPINES FOR BREAKING UP.

ALL CREW SAFELY EVACUATED. NO INJURIES REPORTED. APPROXIMATELY 3 BARRELS OF OIL SPILLED INTO THE SEA. ANTI POLLUTION BOOM DEPLOYED AND CLEAN UP OPERATION EFFECTED BY COASTGUARD. 1,400 LITRES OF OILY WATER MIX REMOVED BY SALVORS. CARGO LIGHTERED AND CRANES REMOVED PRIOR TO THE REFLOATING OF WRECK. TOWED TO NAVOTAS, MANILA, PHILIPPINES IN 2014 FOR BREAKING UP.

Location: NORTH END OF KWAIAWATA ISLAND, PAPUA NEW GUINEA
SummaryOfEvents: that brings bananas and pineapples to New Zealand, has run aground on a small island off Papua New Guinea on Dec 24. Wellington Harbour Master, Mike Pryce, stated that the vessel departed from Lyttelton on Dec 18, bound for Philippines, where it was scheduled to pick up more produce. However, the vessel ran aground on the remote Kwewata Island, near Papua New Guinea, on Dec 24, said Captain Pryce. He also added that the vessel is leaking oil into the water. The oil has reportedly reached the shores of the island. Salvage experts at the incident location have been trying to repair the damage.
REPORTED TO HAVE FOUNDERED ON 24/12/13

In the early morning of 22 December 2012, the bulk carrier Theofylaktos anchored at Rio Grande outer anchorage.  A few hours earlier, fumigation of her cargo of wheat was completed by a shore- based contractor whilst in port. 

In-transit fumigation was planned to ensure cargo disinfestation by the time the vessel reaches her discharge port. 

During the afternoon, an explosion happened in cargo hold no. 4, followed by the escape of white smoke over the cargo deck area.  Further explosions occurred in other cargo holds. 

This culminated in a relatively violent explosion in cargo hold no. 2 at 1622.  Eventually, the situation was brought under control and temporary repairs enabled the vessel to continue on her voyage for repairs. 

The safety investigation concluded that the immediate cause of the explosions was an explosive mixture of phosphine and air.

GENERAL CARGO SHIP "HAN SPLENDOR" TOOK WATER IN HOLD, DEVELOPED 30 DEGREE LIST TO PORT AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN THE PHILIPPINE SEA 180 MILES EAST OF BATAN ISLAND, PHILIPPINES IN LAT. 20 33N., LONG. 124 47E., AT 1000 HOURS LT ON 22/12/12.

COASTGUARD SHIPS AND AIRCRAFT PROCEEDED TO THE SCENE. ALL 17 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFEBOAT AND RESCUED BY MV 'JIN FU'. NO INJURIES REPORTED. CREW SUBSEQUENTLY TRANSFERRED TO REPUBLIC OF KOREAN COASTGUARD VESSEL AND TAKEN TO SEOGWIPO, REPUBLIC OF KOREA FOR REPATRIATION.

Location: AEGEAN SEA 2 MILES SOUTH OF BOZCAADA ISLAND, TURKEY
SummaryOfEvents:
THE TURKISH-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'CEDIT 4' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM WHILST ANCHORED IN THE AEGEAN SEA 2 MILES SOUTH OF BOZCAADA ISLAND, TURKEY IN LAT. 39 47N., LONG. 026 01E., AT 2120 HOURS LT ON 19/12/12. SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP.

FIRE SPREAD TO ACCOMMODATION AND BRIDGE CAUSING EXTENSIVE DAMAGE. RESCUE BOATS 'KEGM-6' AND 'TCSG-84' AND TUGS 'KURTARMA 3' AND 'SONDUREN 7' ATTENDED THE SCENE. 5 CREW RESCUED APART FROM THE CAPTAIN WHO INITIALLY REMAINED ABOARD, BUT WAS LATER ALSO RESCUED. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUBSEQUENTLY DRIFTED AND STRANDED IN STRONG WINDS. REFLOATED AND BLAZE EXTINGUISHED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM 'KURTARMA 3' BY 0630 HOURS LT ON 20/12/12.

On 19th Dec 2012, at Vishakhapatnam anchorage, during routine Lifeboat lowering drill, while hoisting the Starboard Lifeboat, manual hoisting handle was engaged after the blocks touched the davit. Further hoisting was being carried out manually. The 'hoist' button on remote control unit got accidentally pressed. This resulted in manual hoisting handle turning and hitting the handle operator on left leg causing serious injury.

At approximately 11 :10 hrs on 19 September 2012, the 605 m steel-hulled passengers and the skipper on board as it crossed Loch Lomond. There were no injuries and no pollution. Vixen foundered because the weight of the passengers, bilge water and the dynamic effect of propulsion was sufficient to submerge the weed hatch, which was sited above the rudder and propeller.
The fixings that had originally secured the weed hatch cover had corroded and there was little to prevent water flooding in. Vixen sank quickly, around 50 m from the shore.
Five or six passengers donned life jackets and jumped out of the boat. One passenger, who was a weak swimmer, was not provided with a lifejacket, she and the skipper remained on board as the boat sank beneath them.  They were dragged underwater, but managed to swim back to the surface. Some of the passengers swam ashore, the remainder, and the skipper, were quickly rescued by a member of the public who was in another boat nearby.
WHILE BERTHING SUDDEN CHANGE OF WEATHER MOVE THE VESSEL FROM HER POSITHION WITH RESULT TO BRAKE THE  ROPE AND KILLS SEAMAN OF BOARD

On December 19th, 2012, at 05:30, the fishing vessel IAIO PACURRI left the port of Calpe (alicante) with five people on board. The aim of the master was to go to a fishing area, ten miles away from the port. Ten minutes after leaving the port and sailing at 11.5 knots, the vessel got near the mountain Ifach, and started to go around it, at about 50 meters from the cliff face. A few moments later the vessel contacted the cliff with the bow. Only the two crew members that were in the bridge in that moment were injuried. The vessel didn't suffer any leakage.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: The tug boat was towing the floating dock from Kaliningrad ( Russian ) to Tallinn ( Estonia ). When passing Lithuanian territorial waters 10 n. miles west from Sventoje, 1 n.m. till Latvian border in pos. 56-01-95 N. 020-45-75 E. it was notice that the floating dock get 20 degrees list and during 12 minutes sank under the water.
SEAMAN΄S LOSS OF LIFE WHILE ON DUTY

Location: Balmoral oilfield, 120 miles north-east of Aberdeen
SummaryOfEvents:
The Bahamian rescue vessel, VOS SAILOR was damaged and took on water due to strong winds of more than 70 knots and 6.5 metre waves while on standby vessel duties in the Balmoral oilfield, 120 miles north-east of Aberdeen on Friday 14 December 2012 at 04:30 (GMT).  The vessel became rendered disabled, but was not in any danger of sinking.
11 crewmembers were rescued and 1 was reported dead. 
The nearby rig North Sea Producer was evacuated, leaving only essential staff, as a precaution against the drifting vessel striking the structure.
The Maritime Coast Guard Agency was taking all measures to bring the vessel under control and ashore.
REPORT A FIRE INCIDENT TO BE OCURRED AT AROUND 1900HRS ON DECEMBER 15,2012 BRAZIL

Location: MEDITERRANEAN SEA 2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF POLIRIZOS, CRETE, GREECE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'SANTA' STRANDED IN THE MEDITERRANEAN SEA 2 MILES SOUTHWEST OF POLIRIZOS, CRETE, GREECE IN LAT. 35 10N., LONG. 024 17E., AM ON 13/12/12. SUBSEQUENT REPORTED NOT FINANCIALLY VIABLE FOR REPAIR.

ALL 6 CREW RESCUED BY COASTGUARD. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER IN HOLDS. TUG 'PERIKLIS K' ASSISTED WITH REMOVAL OF BUNKER FUEL AND LUBRICATING OIL.

At 03:08 hrs on 12 December 2012, the dry cargo ship ran aground on cabo Negro on the north Spanish coast while on passage from La Coruna to Aviles. At the time of the grounding she was proceeding at full speed, and the officer to the watch (OOW) was asleep

Location: YELLOW SEA 125 MILES WEST OF INCHEON, S. KOREA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CAMBODIAN GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'DONG SHENG' SANK AFTER DEVELOPING A 30 DEGREE LIST IN THE YELLOW SEA 125 MILES WEST OF INCHEON, S. KOREA IN LAT. 37 11N., LONG. 124 24E., AT 1738 HOURS LT ON 11/12/12.

ALL 11 CREW RESCUED BY UNKNOWN VESSEL. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED.

When the owner/skipper of the SIEMPRE AMA BEGOACOA, and the rest of crew, were approaching the boat early that morning to commence the working day, they noticed that the boat was partially submerged. After several hours of attempts pumping out the water, they could get a salvage tug and tow the boat until a dry dock, where she get safely secured. Investigation demonstrated that the flooding was due to the breakage of an unauthorised plastic hose fitted as the salt water refrigeration circuit of the main engine. Further investigation showed also several deficiencies in the surveys and inspections made by officials to the boat during previous years and pointed out some room for improvements in the legislation.

Location: SEA OF JAPAN 70 MILES EAST OF CHONGJIN, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF KOREA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'TAE GAK BONG' SUSTAINED MAIN ENGINE FAILURE AND DRIFTED IN THE SEA OF JAPAN 70 MILES EAST OF CHONGJIN, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF KOREA IN LAT. 41 29N., LONG. 131 02E., ON 09/12/12. NO FURTHER TRACE OF VESSEL FOUND SO PRESUMED TO HAVE SUNK.

ALL 24 CREW SUBSEQUENTLY ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFT ON 15/12/12. BODIES OF 2 CREW MEMBERS RECOVERED FROM JAPANESE WATERS ON 27/04/13 AND 28/04/13. REMAINING 22 CREW MISSING.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

the vessel reported that the 1/E got seriously injured in his fingers( when moving lubricating oil barrels) during his daily works when berthing at Portland, Australia on 07/Dec/ 2012.

Location: WEST SHORE TERMINAL, ROBERTS BANK, CANADA
SummaryOfEvents: dated Dec 7, states: A small quantity of coal spilled into the Pacific Ocean early Friday morning when bulk carrier Cape Apricot (90091 gt, built 2004) crashed into a trestle while docking at Westshore Terminals in Delta. It is unknown why the vessel struck the trestle, which supports a conveyor belt that carries coal from the deep-sea shipping berths to stockpiles, said Westshore spokesman Ray Dykes. "It went straight into the trestle instead of turning into the berth." No one was hurt in the crash and the vessel sustained minimal damage. It was being loaded at Westshore's Berth 2 by Friday afternoon. It will take longer for Berth 1 to become operational again. The crash knocked out power and water, in addition to leaving a 300-foot gap in the conveyer belt. Dykes said the conveyer had an emergency brake so minimal amounts of coal spilled into the water. "Coal is not like oil, it's not toxic," he said of the environmental impact . Salvage and recon

SOLASStatus: BALTIC ACE: Unknown/unspecified, CORVUS J: Unknown/unspecified
Location: 50-60nm off the coast of The Netherlands
SummaryOfEvents:
The Bahamas flagged vehicle carrier ‘Baltic Ace’ was involved in a collision with the Cyprus registered container vessel ‘Corvus J’. The Baltic Ace, which was enroute from Belgium to Finland, with 24 people aboard, sank shortly thereafter. A major search and rescue response was immediately mounted by the Dutch coastguard who feverishly continued to their efforts throughout the night and following day. Thirteen (13) crew members from Baltic Ace were pulled to safety, some of whom were sent to local hospital where they were treated for hypothermia and provided pastoral care.

However there have been four (4) confirmed fatalities and seven (7) seafarers remain missing.

M.V. LADY ROSEBUD
Port of Tanger , Morocco
VOY. 1149N
December 05, 2011

Phosphine gas was released during cargo discharge operations of a maize cargo on board a general cargo ship. Following the loading of her cargo, fumigation sleeves were placed on the top of the cargo in the vessel’s four holds. The hatches were then closed and sealed for the  voyage to the discharge port. The atmosphere at the tops of the holds was tested before cargo discharge started. However, the fumigation sleeves were still in place and although a crew member later removed several sleeves; a number of sleeves were also discharged into the shore hoppers. An attempt was made to remove the fumigation sleeves from the hopper but at least one burst open. The shore side response to the spill included the bagging up of the sleeves that the crew member had removed. The bags, which had been placed on the deck, then began to smoke as phosphine gas was produced by the still active fumigant. The crew were evacuated to the quay and, as a precaution, some were taken to hospital. None were injured. It took several days for the fumigant to de-activate. Not all of the fumigant sleeves were accounted for; some may have continued into the food chain.

Location: BLACK SEA, OFF THE COAST OF SILE-ISTANBUL
SummaryOfEvents: FAST RESUE BOAT, KIYI EMNIYETI 7, LEFT HER STATION FOR THE RESCUE OPERATION FOR VOLGO BALT 199, WHICH SANK IN THE CLOSE VICINITY. THE BOAT WAS BUMPING THE WAVES, AS THE SEA WAS VERY ROUGH, 8-9 BEAUFORT AND WAVES BECOMING HIGHER AND STRONGER AT THE ENTRANCE OF THE PORT. AS THE BOAT HEAVILY FELL DOWN FROM THE HEIGHT OF ANOTHER WAVE AFTER SHE WAS LESS THAN 150 METRES OFF THE BREAKWATER, THE ENGINES STOPPED AND COULD NOT BE STARTED AGAIN DESPITE THE ATTEMPTS OF THE CREW. AS A RESULT, THE BOAT WAS DRIFTED TO THE BREAKWATER, GROUNDING ON THE ROCKS AND BEING TOTALY DESTROYED WITH THE INFLUENCE OF THE STRONG WAVES. 3 OF THE FOUR CREW MEMBERS AND ANOTHER VOLUNTARY FISHERMAN WHO RUSHED TO SAVE THE CREW MEMBERS OF THE BOAT LOST THEIR LIVES AS A CONSEQUENCE.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The Saint Kitts and Nevis general cargo ship VOLGO-BALT 199, carrying about 33 tons of coal and 12 crew members, sank in a storm on Tuesday 4 December 2012 off Istanbul's Black Sea coast, about 40 km (25 miles) east of the northern end of the Bosphorus Strait.  A rescue boat searching for the missing crew hit a nearby rock and sank.  According to the Turkish Authorities, VOLGO-BALT 199 did not send any distress signal and disappeared off the radar on Tuesday at 10:18 A.M.  Four people were rescued from the ship (one died on his way to the hospital) and one person was found dead and 7 are still missing.  Two rescuers died and one other is missing.  Conditions are getting worse because of bad weather.  Rescue operations continue with the help of helicopters and boats from the Turkish coastguard.  Three people died and eight other were missing in the two accidents.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: West Side of Entrance Channel, Freeport
SummaryOfEvents: While sailing out from port of Freport eith pilot on board, vessel drifted to starboard extreme of the chanenel and touched bottom causing damage to No 4 (S) F.O. Tk and No3 (S) W.W.B Tk.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Atlantic Ocean, 30 miles southwest of Nouadhibou, Mauritania
SummaryOfEvents:
On 2 December 2012, the Mauritanian-flagged stern trawler foundered in the Atlantic Ocean, 30 miles southwest of Nouadhibou, Mauritania at 0210 hrs (local time).

All 22 crew  members jumped ino the sea, but were unable to reach the liferafts due to the speed at which the vessel was foundering.  Eighteen crew members were rescued by fishing vessel RIMBAL, RIMBAL 2 and AMABAL 2, three bodies were recovered and one crew member was reported missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Clipper Ranger was in an extended warm lay-up condition after a period of dry-docking, with 10 crew members on board.  She was berthed at No. 3 Dock, West Float, Bidston, Birkenhead.  The vessel was on an electrical shore supply. 

Following a routine maintenance task, one of the fitters observed a crack on one of the engine-room ventilation duct, which was fitted right over the starboard side main engine’s reduction gearbox.  He observed that the crack could be repaired in situ by welding. 

At around 1400, he placed a fire blanket over the gearbox and started to weld the crack on a ladder with the arc welding set. 

Whilst welding, he noticed a fire in the engine-room bilges below him.  Soon after, the fire alarm went off.  The crew members fought the fire using portable fire extinguishers.  The fire was extinguished in about 20 minutes. 

The safety investigation concluded that the immediate cause of the fire was a welding spark, which dropped into the bilges underneath the starboard side main engine.

Location: KALMAR STRAIT 2 MILES NORTHEAST OF KALMAR, SWEDEN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP OF ANTIGUA AND BARBUDA 'TRANS AGILA' STRANDED IN THE KALMAR STRAIT 2 MILES NORTHEAST OF KALMAR, SWEDEN IN LAT. 56 42N., LONG. 016 24E., AT 0305 HOURS LT ON 29/11/12 WHILST UNDER PILOTAGE. BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND TOWED TO FREDERIKSHAVN FOR BREAKING UP.

SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM. 6 CREW RESCUED BY PILOT BOAT. 3 CREW AND PILOT REMAINED ABOARD TO ASSIST WITH SALVAGE OPERATIONS. REFLOATED BY OWN MEANS 4 HOURS LATER AND INTENTIONALLY GROUNDED ON SANDBANK TO LESSEN RISK OF SINKING. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. REFLOATED ON 30/11/12 AND TOWED TO KALMAR FOR TEMPORARY REPAIRS AND PUMPING OUT. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO LANDSKRONA, SWEDEN FOR INSPECTION.

Location: St. Lawrence River off Sainte-Anne-de-Sorel, Quebec
SummaryOfEvents: On 28 November 2012, the bulk carrier Tundra departed Montréal, Quebec, under the conduct of a pilot, downbound in the St. Lawrence River for Halifax, Nova Scotia. At approximately 2148 Eastern Standard Time, the vessel exited the navigation channel and ran aground off Sainte Anne de Sorel, Quebec. The vessel was refloated on 05 December. No pollution or injuries were reported; however, the vessel sustained minor damage.

Location: PACIFIC OCEAN 24 MILES NORTHEAST OF HACHINOHE, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE JAPANESE FISHING VESSEL 'YAE MARU NO. 51' TOOK WATER, DEVELOPED LIST AND CAPSIZED IN THE PACIFIC OCEAN 24 MILES NORTHEAST OF HACHINOHE, JAPAN IN LAT. 40 41N., LONG. 141 56E., AT 0250 HOURS LT ON 27/11/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

ALL 9 CREW ABANDONDED SHIP TO LIFERAFT AND SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY NEARBY FV. NO INJURIES REPORTED. REPORTED CAPSIZED HULL STILL DRIFTING ON 02/12/12 BUT SUBSEQUENTLY SANK.

At 14:59 hrs, on 25 November 2012, two crew members   were washed away overboard from the general cargo ship Timberland. The accident occurred during heavy weather in the North Sea. Both men lost their lives; the body of one of them was recovered from the sea by helicopter following a search and rescue operation co-ordinated by the Netherlands Coastguard. The body of the other remains missing.
The body of one of them was recovered from the sea by helicopter following a search and rescue operation co-ordinated by the Netherlands Coastguard. The body of the other remains missing.

Fire on one shaftblock (starboard side) in the AQUAMASTER space, on board the "SAINT-TUDY" a small passenger ship, 35 passengers on board, ten minutes before entering the harbour of GROIX ISLAND near Lorient (Brittany). Alarm given by fire detection. Fire quickly under controlled by the ship means and after arrival alongside final intervention of local fire brigad. 9 crewmembers are on board : 6 official crewmembers and 3 others (additional crewmembers / inahabitants of Groix island).

Le fileyeur Le Solitaire appareille le vendredi   16 Novembre 2012 du port d'Arcachon en début d'après-midi avec un équipage de 5 personnes à destination de ses lieux de pêche situés dans l'ouest d'Houtin, à trois milles de la côte.
Il travaille dans cette zone jusqu'au samedi 24 novembre sans problème particuliers, cependant, dans la nuit, la météo se dégrade très fortement: houle 6 mètres et vent de sud-ouest  de 25 nœuds. Dans la nuit de samedi à dimanche, vers minuit, alors qu'il est au mouillage au nord de ses filets, il reçoit une déferlante qui brise deux de ses carreaux de passerelle en fronton et un sur l'arrière. 
Le patron estime à ce moment de la houle aux alentours de 6 mètres avec des passages à 8 m et le vent en rafales supérieures à 30 nœuds.
Le patron, de quart au moment  du choc, est blessé sérieusement à la tête par la projection du bandeau soutenant les appareils  radioélectriques, le moteur principal stoppe et le mouillage se rompt, le navire tombant travers à la houle.
Après plusieurs tentatives, le moteur est remis en route et Le Solitaires peut faire cap à l'Ouest pour s'éloigner de la côte, un autre fileyeur Voluntas  DEI, prévenu par le Mayday du CROSS Etel, le prend alors en remorque.
L'Etat de santé du patron se dégradant fortement, il est hélitreuillé à 4:15 pour le CHU de Bordeaux.
Le canot tout temps de La Cotinière prend la remorque et ramène Le Solitaire à la Rochelle.
Le patron quittera l'hôpital deux jours plus tard avec nombreux points de suture au niveau du crâne.

On 24-11-2012 at 1310Hours at Heshang Island port of Dalian (39°0.72’N, 121°44.97’E), the ship staffs was preparing to hoist some hoisting rig from No. 1 cargo hold with the No. 2 crane. With the No.2 crane operating in no-load condition, one of the pulleys in the topping lift failed. The jib of No.2 crane fell on the No.1 hatch cover and killed one stevedore.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SOLASStatus: Island Panther: Non-SOLAS, ISLAND PANTHER: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At 1811 on 21 November 2012, the wind farm passenger transfer
vessel Island Panther made heavy contact with the transition piece
of turbine I-6 in the Sheringham Shoal Wind Farm at a speed of
about 12 knots. The impact caused the five persons on board to be
forced out of their seats and sustain various injuries. The structure
immediately aft of the vessel’s bow fender crumpled as a result of the
impact but no water ingress occurred.
During the day, Island Panther had been operating within the wind
farm transferring personnel from the floating hotel, Regina Baltica,
to various turbines situated in the wind farm. With bad weather
approaching, the master collected the personnel from their various
locations and had returned them all to Regina Baltica by 1536.
At 1750, Island Panther’s night master and deckhand joined the vessel from Regina Baltica
and a handover between the day and night masters commenced. At 1800, with the day
master still at the helm, Island Panther collected a passenger from Regina Baltica before
the night master took command.
The night master had to make passage through the wind farm to follow the approved route
back to Wells-next-the-Sea. It was dark, the wind was gusting 25-30 knots with driving
rain from the west-north-west, and there was 1.5m of swell from the south-east. The south
cardinal buoy light on the south side of the wind farm was visible, as were the rows of
turbine aviation safety lights. The master steered Island Panther towards the south cardinal
buoy light, glancing at the chart plotter in front of him, at a reduced speed of 11-12 knots
because of the sea conditions.
At 1811, Island Panther made heavy head-on contact with the unlit transition piece of a
turbine. The impact forced everyone out of their seats. The passenger sustained a head
injury but remained conscious and was tended to by one of the crew. The vessel was
assessed for damage before slowly heading out of the wind farm. Two other passenger
transfer vessels stood by and the vessel was met off Wells fairway buoy by two lifeboats.
Having decided it was safer to keep the casualties on board, once there was sufficient tidal
height, Island Panther entered the harbour and was met by shore emergency services.

Just after 1712 on 21 November 2012, the wind farm passenger
transfer catamaran Windcat 9 made contact with a floating target in
Donna Nook Air Weapons Range while on passage to Grimsby. The
port hull was holed, causing extensive flooding, but there were no
injuries.
At 1620, Windcat 9 left Lynn and Inner Dowsing Wind Farm, situated
2.7 nautical miles off Skegness. On board were two crew (master
and a deckhand), a supernumerary (trainee master) and 12 wind
farm technicians. The vessel was on autopilot and the master
was following a reciprocal course on his chart plotter to that of his
outbound passage. At about 1650, the master was demonstrating to the trainee master how
to adjust the plotter’s range. In doing so he inadvertently moved the route, which took the
vessel to within 0.75 cable of an unlit floating target.
The master, believing he was still on his reciprocal route, then applied port helm to get
ahead of Fastnet Tern, another vessel returning to Grimsby. A short time later, he made
another course correction, this time to starboard after he belatedly realised he was
significantly to the west of the planned track. About 30 seconds later, while proceeding
at 23.5 knots, Windcat 9’s port hull made contact with the target. Following the master’s
distress alert radio transmission, a number of vessels came to his aid. Soon afterwards, the
passengers and crew were transferred to Fastnet Tern.

On 20-11-2012 at 0810Hours at Western Anchorage No.1 of Hong Kong (22°18.131’N, 114°4.329’E), when the ship staffs of the Hong Kong Registered M.V. “Kum Song 8” were mixing diesel oil with fuel oil in the engine room, a gas explosion took place. The Chief Engineer and one engineer staff were found seriously burnt. The engineer staff died later in the hospital.

The fishing boat NUEVO ELMO was fishing with lines too close to shore when a submerged rock hit against her bottom and the boat got stranded. Then, the boat suffered a massive flooding and sank. The crew called SAR services and abandoned the boat by their means as they were quite close to shore. No casualties were produced.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: In Ro Pax KRITI II, 5 nautical miles before entering to Patras port, a fire broke out on a reefer truck in No 3 Deck (main vehicle deck) . Drencher system was activated and vessel entered Patras port where passengers disembarked safely. Fire fighters from the local fire fighting service were engaged and fire was extinguished by noon the next day. Due to the fire vessel sustained damages to the insulation and equipment inside cargo space No 3, plating deformation and many trucks were damaged (some of them totally).

While entering port with a pilot on board, a yacht "Carmel 10", while overtaking the "Seven Star", lost engine power about 30 meters ahead of the vessel. In spite of the ship's efforts, the starboard side came into contact with the port side of the yacht. There were no injuries, no loss of life and minor damage only to the yacht.

On 17h of November 2012 at about 09:56H/LT while M/T DUQM leaving GS CALTEX Jetty No.2 at Yuso Korea, with Pilot on-board and 4-Tugs assisting the vessel. M/T DUQM was making her turn to starboard after leaving Port, Speed of 1.2 to 1.5K. The weather was fine, sea smooth and visibility was more than 5 miles. While M/T DUQM was turning to starboard, M/V FORTUNE MIRACLE, Bulk Carrier entering into Kwangyang Port suddenly altered her course to portside toward the vessel  M/T DUQM” 270deg ~280 deg against Normal Course of 320deg~325deg to fairway No.4. Master of M/T DUQM alerted his Pilot to check the opponent vessel to which they communicated through Korean language and later found out that there were abnormalities on steering of the vessel M/V FORTUNE MIRACLE.

M/T DUQM Pilot gave order to TUGS on stbd to push back the vessel to full power and at 09:59 used M/E to full astern power in order to stop the momemtum of vessel to starboard.

At 10:02H/LT the starboard bow of M/T DUQM came in contact with the Port bow of M/V FORTUNE MIRACLE at the position of LAT 34-51.5N, LONG 127-47.1E.

At 05:59 hrs on 15 November 2012, the bulk carrier Amber made contact with moored craft and grounded on the south shore of the River Thames shortly after departing from Tilbury power station. The ship's bridge team lost situational awareness in dense fog as the ship manoeuvre from the berth on the north shore, before grounding on the opposite side of the river

ON 14TH NOEMBER 2012, AT VISHAKHAPATNAM ANCHORAGE, INDIA, WHILE MV PRABHU SATRAM WAS SAFELY ANCHORED, LIBERIAN FLAG BULK CARRIER, MV MARIELENA WAS DEPARTING ANCHORAGE TO PROCEED TO PILOT STATION, DURING THE MANOEUVRE MV MARIELENA INTENDED TO PASS AHEAD OF PRABHU SATRAM, APPARENTLY MISJUDGED THE EFFECT OF CURRENT AND TIDE RESULTING IN PORT QUARTER OF MARIELENA COMING IN CONTACT WITH PORT BOW OF PRABHU SATRAM. VESSELS SUFFERED MINOR DAMAGES, NO HULL RUPTURE, POLLUTION OR INJURY OCCURED.

On 14 November 2012, Liberian flagged vessel MARIELENA collided with Indian flagged vessel PRABHU SATRAM in Vizag Anchorage, Bay of Bengal.  MARIELENA and PRABHU SATRAM sustained "minor" damages.  Repairs were completed with Class satisfation.
ShipType1: Other Bulk Dry (cement, woodchips, urea and other specialized) Carrier

Location: Western apporach of l'Ile de la Possession. Crozet Archipelago
SummaryOfEvents:
As part of her third mission of the year for the TAAF, MARION DUFRESNE, who sailed
on 7 November 2012 from La Réunion with 97 passengers and 48 crew members on board,
arrived during the 13 November night in sight of Île de La Possession, in Crozet Archipelago.
She cast anchor at 0.45 mile in the North of Pointe Basse at 5.50 am. The unloading
of the equipment for the scientists’ shelter had been achieved around 8.00 am.
The vessel sailed bound to another shelter in front of which she would cast anchor for
a similar operation. Baie du Lapérouse, located in the south-west of the Island, is a dozen miles
away. The course shaped was rounding the western end of the Island. A helmsman was
steering.
At 8.44 am, in the west of Pointe des Moines, the master handed over the manoeuvre
to the OOW. A few minutes later, when the vessel was closing the waypoint between the 208°
and 125° courses plotted on the chart (WP28), the OOW began to alter course. Considering it to
be too early, the master took over the manoeuvre back and ordered to set the helm midships
then a few moments later, hard-a-starboard. An impact was then felt the vessel took on a
starboard list. The speed of the vessel suddenly decreased from 11 to 6 knots. The master
reduced speed to slow ahead.
He requested to close the watertight doors and to activate immediately the damage
control procedures.
Soon before 9.00 am, several compartments were reported (remote water level sensors
and alarm control panel) flooded by seawater, the vessel was normally floating and making her
way slowly ahead.
The master decided to proceed to his final destination, the Baie du Marin, located at
the eastern end of the Island opposite to Port Alfred, where is the main research station of
Crozet archipelago, well protected from the westerly swell. He cast anchor there around 11.00 am.

Coming from Reunion Island,  the french research ship Marion Dufresne was approaching the Possession Island (belonging to the Crozet Islands archipelago) with the purpose of supplying some equipment in two secondary scientific bases by the mean of an helicopter, then landing scientist and unload equipments in the main base, in the east part of the island.
After the first anchoring in the north oh the island (Pointe Basse), early in the morning of the 14th of november, she was proceeding towards an other one in the SW (Lapérouse point).
At the time the ship was reaching the most western part of this small tripp, the officer on duty altered the course. At the very time the captain, realizing that the manoeuver was done too early, the ship touched hardly a reef on the starboard side. 
Some capacities in the port forepart of the ship have been flooded. 
Nobody has been injured.
The ship remain floating and doesn't show any problem regarding its stability.
The passengers have been taken on shore by the ship's helicopter.
After some days the french authority authorize the ship to proceed towards a repairing yard.
Repairs have been done in the dry dock of Durban.
Being the fisherboat getting the net of, a fisherman became trapped with the fishing equipment and launch into the water, resulting finally drowned.

THE US-FLAGGED TUG STRANDED OFF UKOLNOI ISLAND, AK, USA IN LAT. 55 11N., LONG. 161 37W., AT 2058 HOURS LT ON 13/11/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER. ALL 5 CREW RESCUED BY USCG HELICOPTERS AND TAKEN TO COLD BAY, AK. NO INJURIES REPORTED. APPROXIMATELY 6,000 GALLONS OF OIL SPILLED INTO SEA. ANTI POLLUTION MEASURES DEPLOYED. REMAINING OIL REMOVED BY SALVORS. TUG WAS TOWING BARGE 'UNIMAK TRADER' WHICH ALSO STRANDED AFTER TOW LINE PARTED. REFLOATED ON 29/11/12 AND TOWED TO SAND POINT, AK ARRIVING 30/11/12 FOR INSPECTION.

MV “FRONTIER QUEEN” loaded with 168725MT cargo of Concentrate of Sinter reached port Rizhao, China on 12 November and dropped anchor.

On 12 November evening after the vessel anchored, deck and engine officers maintained anchor watches. 

On 13 November at 0300hrs, motorman on duty, opened main engine scavenging space manholes on order from 1ST Engineer. At 0600hrs the ventilation of scavenging space was commenced by the duty motorman.

At 0730hrs, 13 November tool box meeting was held which was supervised by Chief Engineer and attended by available watch ratings, all engineers including engine cadet and wiper. First Engineer intended to make scavenging port inspection at anchorage due to time constraints and many other jobs in hand to be carried out while the vessel in port alongside discharging berth.   

Understanding that the scavenging port inspection would not take much time, Chief Engineer permitted for the job although port permit was not requested for immobilization of main engine as vessel was at anchor. 

Chief engineer, Second and Third engineers, with assistance of deck crew, started other machinery work on deck.  

By 1030hrs, the First Engineer completed preparations to enter scavenging space. He carried with him the turning gear remote control and a torch light. On reaching M.E. unit #1 he adjusted with remote control the piston position, began inspecting and taking photos of piston rings, crown and cylinder liner. After completing inspection of #1 unit in about 10mins time, he came out from 1st unit. 

At this time Engine Cadet came to First Engineer and expressed his desire to observe and learn the scavenging space inspection procedures. First Engineer accepted Cadet’s request and along with him started to inspect #2 unit.  He then adjusted the position of the piston, using remote control, to bring it below scavenging port at BDC. When the piston reached at BDC 1st Engineer handed over the remote control of turning gear to Cadet and instructed him to release the screw mounted on the improvised switch, which was required so that movement of the piston could be stopped that was going upwards. 

Cadet was not familiar with the remote control switch as he was handling this remote control of turning gear first time. Being uncertain and unsure the Cadet started slowly releasing the screw fitted on remote switch of turning gear. 
By this time 1ST Engineer anticipating that the Cadet would release the screw and stop the moving piston, he placed both his hands inside the scavenging port of #2unit of main engine, holding a camera in his hands. He concentrated and focused to take photos of cylinder liner while the piston continued moving upwards. The Cadet till this time could not completely release the switch which would stop the movement of the piston. 

The upward moving piston was not noticed by 1ST Engineer and eventually his both hands were caught between moving piston and cylinder liner at the upper edge of scavenging port and disintegrated from both wrists. This incident took place around 1048hrs.

Cadet managed to stop the movement of the piston but by this time 1ST Engineer’s both hands were severely injured and he was not able to move from place. Cadet informed about the incident to other engine crew who called for immediate help.                    

Some times later other Engineers rushed to the location along with ratings. Chief Engineer, moved the piston down using remote control switch, a little below upper edge of scavenge port and set free both hands of the casualty. 

The ship’s crew carried injured 1st Engineer from engine room to ship’s hospital on stretcher where first aid was provided to him. 

The local agent was requested for urgent medical assistance. A tug was arranged which came alongside the ship at 1515hrs and transported the casualty from the ship to shore hospital.

The fishing vessel RUMBO AL MAR suffered a list to the port side when the crew were stowing the fishing gear. The crew threw a life raft into the water but did not time to embark before the fishing vessel capsized. Another vessel that witnessed the events went to rescue the shipwrecked and moved them to the port of Conil (Cadiz). Upon arrival in port, one of the members of the crew required medical assistance due to symptoms of hypothermia.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: While transiting the South Atlantic Ocean, the vessel’s intermediate shaft bearing alarm was activated when the temperature suddenly rose from 65.1° to 120°. The Chief Engineer observed that all of the holding bolts for the intermediate shaft were all loose. The propeller shaft was inspected and there was a crack about 60cm long.

On 5 November 2012, 6 crew members were poisoned by leaking gas on board MAHARSHI KRISHNATREYA during repair works in the compressor room in the Arabian Sea.  Five of the crew members died, while the sixth member, in a serious condition was airlifted to Porbandar by helicopter for medical treatment.  The Indian Navy and Coast Guard were alerted for relief and rescue operations and the MAHARSHI KRISHNATREYA was diverted to Porbandar Port, Gujarat where two vessels with a medical team and a Sea King MK-42C helicopter were deployed to evacuate the crew.  The Merchant Marine Department has been ordered to conduct an inquiry into the incident.

THE GREEK PASSENGER SHIP 'PSARA' CAUGHT FIRE WHILST MOORED AT CHIOS, GREECE AT 0510 HOURS LT ON 04/11/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND BROKEN UP AT PERAMA, GREECE IN OCTOBER 2013.

BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES 50 MINUTES LATER. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE TO INTERIOR. VESSEL HAD BEEN LAID UP UNMANNED SINCE AT LEAST 2009.

Location: Baltic sea/3,6 nm. SW of Klaipeda port breakwater
SummaryOfEvents: Due to continously increasing list ( 10 degr and increasing ) ship had to dump the cargo not in place of the appointed dumping area.

On 31 October 2012, strong winds during Cyclone Nilam resulted in the chemical and oil tanker PRATIBHA CAUVERY running aground off Chennai’s coast.  The master ordered the 25 crew members to abandon the ship as it was sinking, but six drowned.  The Coast Guard, who assisted in the search and rescue, airlifted the master from the stranded ship and took him to hospital.  The search continued for the missing crew members
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: BAY OF BENGAL 170 MILES EAST OF BATTICALOA, SRI LANKA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VIETNAMESE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'SAIGON QUEEN' SANK FOLLOWING A SHIFT OF CARGO IN THE BAY OF BENGAL 170 MILES EAST OF BATTICALOA, SRI LANKA IN LAT. 07 59N., LONG. 084 07E., AT 2330 HOURS LT ON 30/10/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

CREW RADIOED SHIP OWNERS AT 1028 HOURS LT ON 30/10/12 ADVISING THEY WERE ATTEMPTING TO RESECURE CARGO THAT HAD SHIFTED IN ADVERSE WEATHER. GENERAL DISTRESS CALL ISSUED AT 1222 HOURS LT THE SAME DAY AND SUBSEQUENTLY CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS. RESCUE VESSELS EFFECTED SAR OPERATION. 19 CREW RESCUED BY MV 'PACIFIC SKIPPER' BUT WHILST BEING LIFTED ABOARD THE CAPTAIN FELL INTO THE SEA AND WAS NOT RECOVERED. 3 OTHER CREW MISSING.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: FRONT STREET, STATEN ISLAND, NY, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE US-FLAGGED TANKER 'JOHN B CADDELL' STRANDED AFTER BREAKING MOORINGS AND DRIFTING OFF FRONT STREET, STATEN ISLAND, NY, USA IN LAT. 40 38N., LONG. 074 04W., PM ON 29/10/12 IN HURRICANE 'SANDY'. REFLOATED ON 11/12/12 AND TOWED TO ROSSVILLE, NY FOR BREAKING UP.

NO INJURIES REPORTED. VESSEL HAD BEEN LAID UP UNMANNED PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT. ANTI POLLUTION BOOMS DEPLOYED AND CLEAN UP OPERATION EFFECTED BY COASTGUARD. SALVAGE CONTRACT AWARDED TO DONJON MARINE. TEMPORARY REPAIRS EFFECTED. REFLOATED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM FLOATING CRANE 'CHESAPEAKE 1000' ON 11/12/12 AND TOWED TO DONJON RECYCLING AT ROSSVILLE, STATEN ISLAND, NY FOR BREAKING UP.

While approaching anchorage #10 at port Primorsk, the vessel experienced a propulsion system failure due to the loss of connection between the intermediate shaft and the propeller shafts followed by the connection bolt’s rupture.

Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
The French Passenger ship Napoléon Bonaparte was laid up without her crew in Marseille; only a watchman and the Chief engineer were on board (the two technical Assistants for daily maintenance tasks had already left the vessel).

When the wind began to increase dramatically, the duty Officer of the company, a Boatswain and the two technical Assistants were called from their home in Marseille. A tug was requested to maintain the ship alongside and a pilot came on board, but stayed less than two hours. 

2 hours later a generator and the bow thruster were started. Nevertheless, all the hawsers broke 3 hours later and the ship began to move away from her berth (Poste 116). The shore supply connection tore off  and the generator stopped. The vessel was now adrift in the basin without her main engine and moving toward another berth (Poste 40). She collided with it, but thanks to the assistance of 2 tugs, she was then secured and maintained alongside.

The main engine compartments began to be flooded. The pumping was started but was not enough effective. 1 hour later, due to the impossibility to reach the flooded compartments, a shore pumping operation was not yet possible. In the following hours the vessel grounded by the aft and various plan of salvage were assessed.

Location: Sea of Okhotsk, 18 miles east of Kiran, Russian Federation
SummaryOfEvents:
On 28 October 2012, the general cargo ship AMURSKAYA from the Russian Federation capsized and foundered in the sea of Okhotsk, 18 miles east of Kiran, Russian Federation.

Search and rescue operations including tanker NOVIK, fishing vessel KAPITAN GAMS and TERNEY-1, A BE-200 aircraft and other ships and helicopters were deployed.  The ship was located at a depth of 25 metres on 9 November 2012.  One crew member's body was recovered and 10 members were reported missing.  The search and rescue and diving operation discontinued on 26 November 2012 due to hazardous hydro-meteorological conditions.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: 500 METRES FROM THE MOUTH OF THE TUMEN RIVER, RUSSIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'TU RU BONG 1' STRANDED 500 METRES FROM THE MOUTH OF THE TUMEN RIVER, RUSSIA IN LAT. 42 17N., LONG. 130 41E., ON 28/10/12. HALF SUNKEN WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.

RESCUE VESSEL ATTENDED THE SCENE. ALL CREW RESCUED. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED.

Location: NORTH PACIFIC OCEAN 1,850 MILES NORTHWEST OF FRENCH FRIGATE SHOALS, HI, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE TAIWANESE, CHINA-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'CHIN ZUEI YIN' CAUGHT FIRE IN THE NORTH PACIFIC OCEAN 1,850 MILES NORTHWEST OF FRENCH FRIGATE SHOALS, HI, USA IN LAT. 36 08N., LONG. 166 13E., ON 27/10/12. VESSEL SUBSEQUENTLY ABANDONED AND LEFT TO DRIFT.

CREW UNABLE TO CONTROL THE BLAZE AND ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS. USCG HC-130 AIRCRAFT FROM BARBERS POINT, HI EFFECTED SAR OPERATION AND LOCATED THE VESSEL AT 2230 HOURS HST THE SAME DAY. MV 'SUN GLOBE' AND 2 SISTER FV'S ALSO ASSISTED WITH THE SEARCH. ALL 28 CREW SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY ONE OF THE SISTER FV'S. NO INJURIES REPORTED. DERELICT VESSEL REPORTED STILL AFLOAT ON 26/11/12.

On 25 October 2012, the tanker Nanny ran aground on a shoal while outbound from Baker Lake, Nunavut, damaging the forward section of the hull. On 27 October, the vessel came off the shoal during strong northwesterly winds and later proceeded to St. John’s, Newfoundland and Labrador, for repairs. There were no injuries or pollution reported.

On 23 October 2012, NORD GOODWILL was moored in buoys at the Tema Offshore Oil Terminal. 
On the same day, a crew change was about to take place. The transportation to and from Tema 
was done by launch. To embark the launch, a pilot ladder was rigged from the deck of NORD 
GOODWILL to about one metre above the surface of the sea.
When trying to embark the launch, the ship’s chief engineer fell into the water from the lowest step 
of the pilot ladder. 10-15 minutes later he was recovered by the launch.
After having been recovered, he was rushed to a hospital ashore where he was declared dead on 
arrival.
After the accident actions have been taken by Dampskibsselskabet Norden A/S.
Prior to the accident, the Danish Maritime Authority has submitted a guidance to enhance safety 
during transfer operations to the IMO.
1
The Danish Maritime Accident Investigation Board does not have any safety recommendations in 
relation to the accident.

Location: Hyundai Car Pier No. 2, Ulsan Korea
SummaryOfEvents: While two tug boats were assisting Liberian flagged Personal Car Carrier vessel, HYUNDAI No. 106, at Hyundai Car Pier No. 1 in Ulsan Korea during very windy conditions, the vessel was getting pushed towards shore from the port side of the vessel. One tug was pushing from the vessel's port bow (fwd) and the other tug was pushing from the vessel's port quarter (aft). The aft tug appeared to be pushing with more power than the forward tug and the drection of the wind seemed to further push the vessel's aft towards the port. As a result of this unevenly distributed push, the vessel's main engine storage tank from the vessel's starboard side contacted the port. This caused damage to the storage oil tank and crew members had to immediately transfer the lube oil from the main engine storage tank to the No. 1 cyl. oil tank. During the course of this transfer, however, the vessel discharged about 16,600 liters of system lube oil into the sea. There were no injuries.
SEAWAY LANDING BOOM KILLS SEAMAN ON BOARD

On 21 October 2012, at about 0400, the chief mate relieved the second mate from the navigational watch on board the multi-purpose vessel Wilson Newport.  At the time, the vessel was in transit from Derince, Turkey to Antwerp, Belgium, navigating in the central Aegean Sea.  After taking over the watch, the navigational officer of the watch (OOW) sat down on the starboard wheelhouse chair and subsequently fell asleep. 

There was no look-out during the watch and with the OOW fast asleep, the vessel maintained course and speed practically with an unmanned bridge.  Wilson Newport passed two consecutive way points for course alteration at the Straits of Kea Island.  At about 06151 1 Unless otherwise stated, all times referred to in this report are ships time (UTC+2). , the vessel ran aground off the South-East coast of Agios Georgios Islet, which is located about 15 nautical miles South of Cape Sounio. 

The area where Wilson Newport ran aground was a rocky shoreline.  Consequently, the vessel sustained damages in way of double bottom tanks nos. 1 port and starboard, the bow thruster room, the forepeak tank and two other ballast tanks.  There were no reported injuries or pollution as a result of the occurrence. 

The salvage operations commenced on the morning of 23 October 2012 and the appointed salvors were able to refloat the vessel during the afternoon of the following day.

Location: PACIFIC OCEAN 115 MILES SOUTHEAST OF OKINAWA, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE REFRIGERATEDCARGO SHIP 'MING YANG' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE PACIFIC OCEAN 115 MILES SOUTHEAST OF OKINAWA, JAPAN IN LAT. 24 30N., LONG. 128 20E., AT 1600 HOURS LT ON 20/10/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND SUBSEQUENTLY SOLD FOR BREAKING UP.

BLAZE SUBSEQUENTLY SPREAD TO ACCOMMODATION AREA. JAPANESE COASTGUARD SHIPS AND AIRCRAFT AND MV 'SASANQUA' PROCEEDED TO THE SCENE. 28 CREW AND 36 FISHERY WORKERS RESCUED AND INITIALLY TAKEN ABOARD COASTGUARD VESSEL, THEN TRANSFERRED TO RESCUE TUG 'DONG HAI JIU 111'. 3 CREW SUSTAINED MINOR INJURIES. 'DONG HAI JIU 111' SUBSEQUENTLY EXTINGUISHED THE BLAZE AND EFFECTED TOW TO ZHOUSHAN, CHINA ARRIVING 25/10/12 FOR INSPECTION.

Location: CARTER SHOAL IN THE SINGAPORE STRAIT 5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF THE HORSBURG LIGHTHOUSE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE BRAZILLIAN-FLAGGED PRODUCTS TANKER 'ITAPERUNA' STRANDED BRIEFLY ON THE CARTER SHOAL IN THE SINGAPORE STRAIT 5 MILES SOUTHWEST OF THE HORSBURG LIGHTHOUSE IN LAT. 01 16N., LONG. 104 22E., AT 1355 HOURS LT ON 20/10/12. TOWED TO XINHUI, CHINA FOR BREAKING IN FEB 2013.

REFLOATED IMMEDIATELY BY OWN MEANS AND ANCHORED TO AWAIT ASSISTANCE. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO AFT HULL AND TOOK WATER. RESCUE VESSEL 'RB-209' AND TUG 'SMIT LYNX' ATTENDED THE SCENE. CREW DECLINED TO BE RESCUED. VESSEL SUBSTANTIALLY LOW IN THE WATER BY THE STERN. TEMPORARY REPAIRS EFFECTED AND TOWED TO XINHUI, CHINA BY TUG 'PACIFIC HICKORY' IN FEBRUARY 2013 FOR DEMOLITION.

Location: NORTHWEST COAST OF URUP ISLAND, KURIL ISLANDS, RUSSIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE RUSSIAN-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'MRTK-0718' STRANDED ON THE NORTHWEST COAST OF URUP ISLAND, KURIL ISLANDS, RUSSIA IN LAT. 46 06N., LONG. 150 09E., PM ON 20/10/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

VESSEL HAD BEEN UNDER TOW OF MV 'KASPIYSKIY' BOUND VLADIVOSTOK FOR REPAIRS WHEN THE TOWING CABLE PARTED IN ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS AT 2250 HOURS LT ON 19/10/12. CABLE REATTACHED BUT SUBSEQUENTLY PARTED AGAIN 2 HOURS LATER. NO FUEL OR CREW ON BOARD AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.

Location: YELLOW SEA 19 MILES WEST OF CHAGWI ISLAND, JEJU, REPUBLIC OF KOREA
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
THE MALAYSIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'SHINLINE 8' SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL, TOOK WATER AND SANK IN THE YELLOW SEA 19 MILES WEST OF CHAGWI ISLAND, JEJU, REPUBLIC OF KOREA AT 1550 HOURS LT ON 18/10/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

INITIAL DISTRESS CALL RECEIVED AT 0714 HOURS LT EARLIER THE SAME DAY AFTER CARGO IN THE HOLD HAD SHIFTED AND PUNCHED A 0.5 METRE HOLE IN THE PORT SIDE HULL PLATING. TOOK WATER IN HOLD AND ENGINE ROOM. ADDITIONAL PUMPS SUPPLIED BY NEARBY MV AND COASTGUARD VESSELS TO ASSIST WITH PUMPING OUT. CREW STILL UNABLE TO CONTROL INGRESS OF WATER AND VESSEL SUBSEQUENTLY SANK. 14 CREW RESCUED BY COASTGUARD BUT 5 DIED WHEN A RESCUE BOAT OVERTURNED.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship
