La M/N COPIHUE, de bandera chilena, efectuaba transferencia puerto- buque de carga en contenedores , utilizando las grúas de la nave,  atracada en el sitio exterior del muelle José de los Santos Mardones de Punta Arenas.
Mientras levantaba un contenedor de 40 pies, se produjo el desprendimiento de la base del brazo de la grúa de proa, provocando la caída de la carga en al interior de la bodega, quedando esta sostenida sólo por uno de sus pistones hidráulicos.
Producto de lo anterior, resultó con lesiones graves uno de los trabajadores portuarios,  el Sr. x.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: due to erratic manoeuvre during berthing the M/V Cielo Di Livorno was collided with pier in the Port of Koper (Slovenia)

On 11 October 2012, at approximately 1340 Eastern Daylight Time, the passenger vessel Jiimaan grounded while approaching the ferry terminal in Kingsville, Ontario. The 34 passengers and crew remained on board until the vessel was refloated at approximately 1308 the next day, after which time the Jiimaan was escorted to the port of Leamington, Ontario. There was no pollution, damage, or injuries.
the vessel ran aground near of Santa Luzia Island on October 10, 2012.

On October 10, 2012 at 10:00, Liberian flagged oil tanker, LIQUID SILVER, while transitting the East China Sea incurred Main Engine failure and the vessel was unable to restart and resume it's voyage. Less than a week earlier, the main engine had been cleaned of the backwash in its filter due to the low pressure indicated on the gauge. After that cleaning the vessel proceeded on with its passage and encountered rough weather conditions. The pressure gauges again indicated low pressure, and the crew members, again, cleaned the backwash in the filter. Eventually the vessel's main engine failed and required towing assistance for the necessary repairs.

THE GUYANESE-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'FAIRLAND' STRANDED IN THE DEMERARA RIVER OFF SUPPLY, GUYANA IN LAT. 06 37N., LONG. 058 13W., AT 2030 HOURS LT ON 09/10/12. SUBSEQUENTLY INSPECTED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

NO POLLUTION REPORTED. DURING REFLOATING ATTEMPTS A CRANE COLLAPSED AFTER A HYDRAULIC HOSE BURST CAUSING FATAL INJURIES TO A CREW MEMBER. REFLOATED THE FOLLOWING DAY AND PROCEEDED TO ANCHORAGE IN THE GEORGETOWN, GUYANA AREA FOR INSPECTION AND INVESTIGATION.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 09 October of 2012, one of the engine ratings forming part of the electrical team on board the Maltese registered passenger vessel Logos Hope, was assigned to trace down an electrical fault on the forward boiler unit, which had been put out of service on 05 October 2012.  Assuming that the system was isolated and safe, the engine rating started disconnecting the terminals. 

However, the system was not completely isolated and he suffered an electric shock, resulting in second and third degree burns in three of his fingers. 

The safety investigation concluded that the engine rating was unaware that other parts of the system were still live.  Moreover, before disconnecting the terminals, he only tested a number of them, and therefore assumed that the rest were also isolated.

A cargo ship was approaching her intended river berth with the master controlling the vessel's Aquamaster propulsion units. A river pilot and the chief officer were also on the bridge. As the vessel neared the river bank on her starboard side (as planned), the pilot advised the master to reduce speed. Speed was reduced and the vessel was quickly set by the flood tidal stream closer to the river bank. In response, the master manoeuvred the vessel's heading to port but, indoing so, the starboard Aquamaster unit touched the river bottom and was damaged. The vessel berthed successfully using only the port Aquamaster unit. The vessel had to be dry-docked to enable the starboard Aquamaster unit to be repaired.

Location: At a quay of Tokuyama Kudamatsu port, Yamaguchi Pref., Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
While the bulk carrier SAGE SAGITTARIUS was alongside the quay of Tokuyama Kudamatsu port, a superintendent was found caught in a feeder conveyor roller onboard.
He was rescued by a rescue team but was confirmed dead.
He died of suffocation in the crush.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: hile the vessel was alongside the TOKUYAMA KUDAMATSU port , a superintendent was found caught in feeder conveyor roller onboard. a superintendent was found dead..

SOLASStatus: DOUBLE PROGRESS: SOLAS, E.R. TURKU: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 4th of October 2012 the weather was fine, sea smooth and visibility was 8 to 10 miles. At 15:06 Hrs (LT) MV DOUBLE PROGRESS Anchors aweigh to proceed to Port Kelang Pilot station. The ship maneuvered, turns to starboard and steered at 340 degree, then Master ordered engine full speed. At 15:38 Hrs (LT) the ship MV DOUBLE PROGRESS made contact with the Bulb Bow of MV E.R TURKU which was anchored in the position of 02-47.93N / 101.15.7E. 
M/V “DOUBLE PROGRESS” sustain damage to port side shell iwo No.2 WBT, broken accommodation ladder, pilot Ladder, Port Main Deck Railing , air Vent head, sounding pipe, fair lead, center bollard center chock. Vessel was reported incline to about 4 deg owing to water ingress in Ballast Water Tank no.2 and was compensated with Ballast Water to another tank to keep the vessel upright until Berthing. 
After discharging operation the hole appeared to Port side shell plate which measured 1.5M x 1.0M. After Class inspection as confirmed Seaworthy, MV DOUBLE PROGRESS was given a single voyage until Singapore for complete repairs. 
There are no reported other incidents as Fire, Fatalities and Oil Pollution to both MV DOUBLE PROGRESS and MV E.R TURKU. For MV E.R TURKU, her damage was not assessed as believed its Seaworthiness is kept in good shape as vessel proceeded to Berth and depart to next port.

SOLASStatus: DOUBLE PROGRESS: Unknown/unspecified, E.R. TURKU: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 4 October 2012, m/v DOUBLE PROGRESS collided with m/v E.R. TURKU while it was at anchorage in Port Kelang, Malaysia. Damages to E.R. TURKU’s starboard bow were reported.

Location: Sea of Japan West of Japan
SummaryOfEvents: THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF KOREA-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'JO PPOL 2' SANK IN SEA OF JAPAN WEST OF JAPAN CIRCA 04/10/12.

The fire started in engine room. It was noticed that smoke is going out from ER throught emergency exit. The hydraulic oil was going throught the crack of wellding on hydraulic pipe on the exhaust pipe ead it ignited. The fire spreded on cables.
After failer to extinguish the fire by portble CO2 fire extinguishes ER was closed, ventilation was shut down and started CO2 system. The fire was extinguished.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: “Sincere Navigation Corporation” indicating that on 2nd/OCT/2012, approximately at 07:12 LT, during the operation of shifting the ship to the terminal (Imminghan, UK), the carpenter JIYUE WANG (Chinese Nationality) was involved in a fatal accident, having his neck strangled by a loop of messenger line spilling over warping drum end.

SOLASStatus: LAMMA IV: Unknown/unspecified, SEA SMOOTH : Unknown/unspecified
Location: 3km (2 miles) SW of Hong Kong.(Hong Kong, China)
SummaryOfEvents:
The passenger ship LAMMA IV sank after colliding with the ferry SEA SMOOTH, near Lamma Island, about 3 km (2 miles) south-west of Hong Kong island, on Monday 01 October 2012, at around 20:30 (local time).  Thirty-eight people died, 90 were rescued and the number of missing people is unknown.
The local Fire Services Department (FSD) deployed 7 fire boats (including 1 diving support vessel), mobilized fire and ambulance personnel and over 20 ambulances.  Low visibility and on board obstacles hampered rescue efforts.
Rescue efforts continue overnight as FSD cannot rule out that there are still people inside the vessel or missing.
The SEA SMOOTH  was slightly damaged in the collision and continued on its destination.  The 99 people (95 passengers and 4 crew members) on board suffered minor injuries.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: SPDC WELLHEAD NO. 2, EREREKIRI CREEK, BONNY, NIGERIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PRODUCTS TANKDER 'AKASH' CAUGHT FIRE FOLLOWING EXPLOSION WHILST LOADING OIL AT SPDC WELLHEAD NO. 2, EREREKIRI CREEK, BONNY, NIGERIA AT 0100 HOURS LT ON 30/09/12.

UNKNOWN NUMBER OF CREW DEAD. 1 CREW MEMBER INJURED AND TAKEN TO LOCAL HOSPITAL. VESSEL SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE. REPORTED EXPLOSION OCCURRED WHILST OIL WAS BEING LOADED ILLEGALLY FROM THE WELLHEAD.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
informed that we have just received, at about 09.00 UTC; a phone call from the Master of our managed vessel M/v MSC TAMARA,  3EOC - PANAMA FLAG - IMO N° 9351579, reporting that one man fall down at sea accidentally.
The vessel is in Biscay Sea Area and is bounding from Antwerpen Belgium to Sines Portugal.
The crew man involved is Italian citizen and is rank is Bosun, name AIESE Vincenzo.
Immediately searching has started from the vessel, all shore coastal stations in the vicinity have been adviced/alerted and searching is under way with assistance of some vessels (unknown to us at present) present in the area.

After having received port clearance in the Angolan port of Luanda m/v Kampen was advised to stay on outer roads at anchorage to wait for a free berth.
While lying at anchor the deck crew was busy with maintenance works on the superstructures. An AB engaged with works aloft accidentally fall off the boatswain’s chair he was sitting in and dashed down on the main deck from a height of about eight meters.
Although direct first aid could be rendered the seafarer died of his wounds shortly thereafter.
An investigating on-scene was conducted by the vessel management to identify the underlying grounds of the accident. The objective was to reveal weak spots within the work safety procedures in the first place. The company Safety Management System (SMS) was found to provide all pertinent precautionary measures to safeguard the works of the seafarers while performing their tasks on the vessel.

Beside the commitment as per the Casualty Code to conduct a safety investigation into every very serious marine casualty the flag State chief casualty investigator has decided to initiate a full independent investigation into this fatality. The aim is to find out if the whole process of the company SMS is managed effectively or if cursory habitual practise on board of Kampen may possibly cause handling failures.
As per Chapter 20 of the Casualty Investigation Code parties involved in the commencement of the investigation have been informed with a relevant notification.

While under pilotage and berthing at Port of Diliskelesi, Turkey at approximately 15:36 (LT), Liberian flagged bulk carrier, KM KEELUNG allided with the berth and dented the ship's bow. The tug line of the bow tug broke and the bow tug was un able to pull ship's bow. As a result, the vessel's starboard bow came into contact with berth. There were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

An explosion occurred in the No. 3 cargo hold, which was loaded with coal.  There was not a sustained fire.  A crewmember working in vicinity of hatch coaming was severly burned and blown overboard.  He was recovered and later transported ashore for medical treatment.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed
Cargo1: Coal, bulk  IMO Class: MHB, Group B

Location: 30 nautical miles west of La Push, Washington State
SummaryOfEvents: On 28 September 2012, at approximately 0430 Pacific Daylight Time, the Canadian fishing vessel Viking Storm collided with the American fishing vessel Maverick in thick fog, 30 nautical miles off La Push, Washington. The Maverick capsized and sank from the impact; 3 of the 4 crew members on board survived and were rescued by the Viking Storm. The fourth crew member was never found and is presumed drowned.

Cargo vessel CELIA was anchoraged at Valencia anchorage area when the wind increased. Due to bad weather the master requested to the chief engineer the main engine to be manned and to be ready in case of emergency, but the chief enginner reported to bridge that he couldn't start the engine because of an unknow problem. Finally the vessel grounded at Saler beach.

BSLE SUNRISE was anchoraged at Valencia anchorage when the wind increased and anchor chain was self slacked from 4 shackles to 7 shackles. They started the main engine and tried to heave up the anchor, but anchor chain was response very slow. Suddenly the engine stopped because the main engine lubricating oil had lost suction. The engine started again and they cut the anchor chain. Finally the vessel grounding at Saler beach.

ShipsInvolved: Miguel de Cervantes (IMO 9320116), Volcn de Timanfaya (IMO 9281334)
SOLASStatus: Miguel de Cervantes: Unknown/unspecified, Volcn de Timanfaya: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On September 27th, 2012, at 12:00 UTC, both ships VOLCN DE TIMANFAYA and MIGUEL DE CERVANTES were moored in the Anaga dock, inside the Santa Cruz de Tenerife port.At 12:05 the force of a wind gust broke the forward mooring lines of VOLCN DE TIMANFAYA. Due to the wind, this began to open its bow from the dock, coming closer to MIGUEL DE CERVANTES.The captain of VOLCN DE TIMANFAYA commanded to drop the anchor, while the captain of MIGUEL DE CERVANTES commanded to place a Yokohama fender. Finally both ships contacted without damages. Minutes later two tugs helped to put the ships apart.

Location: 20 miles of Belang-Belang port in Mamuju
SummaryOfEvents: On 27 August 2012, the Indonesian-flagged chemical tanker SOECHI LESMANA suffered a fire in the engine room and then exploded in Mamuju waters in West Sulawesi, Indonesia, about 20 miles of Belang-Belang port in Mamuju.  One crew member died, 2 were badly injured and taken to hospital.  The rest of 20 crew members were ecacuated and taken to Marmuju.  The tanker, loaded with an unknown type of fuel was en route from Pare-Pare to Donggala in Central Sulawesi.  One crew member died in the explosion.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: BAHUGA JAYA: Non-SOLAS, NORGAS CATHINKA: SOLAS
Location: Sunda Strait (4 Nautical miles east of Rimau Balak Island), Indonesia
SummaryOfEvents:
At 03051 on 26 September 2012, Bahuga Jaya sailed from Merak bound for Bakauheni. The
ferry was on a scheduled, regular, westbound crossing of Sunda strait. The passage would be
made at its usual speed of about 10 knots2 and would take about 2 hours. The master, the
chief mate and a helmsman were on the ferry’s bridge. After the vessel was full away, the
master left the bridge. Meanwhile, Norgas Cathinka was approaching Sunda strait from the
south on a northeasterly course. The chief mate and a helmsman were on the bridge.
At 0420, Norgas Cathinka was on a heading of 049 True (T) and a speed of about 12 knots. At
the time, three eastbound radar targets on Norgas Cathinka’s port bow were detected.
Following that, two more vessels on west-northwest courses were also detected. These two
vessels were later identified as Bahuga Jaya and Gelis Rauh.
At 0436, the last of the eastbound vessel, identified as MV Caitlyn crossed Norgas Cathinka’s
bow at a distance of about 1 nautical mile (Nm)3. Bahuga Jaya was still on a collision course
with Norgas Cathinka on a bearing of about 074 (T).
At about 0440, Norgas Cathinka’s chief mate decided to take action to avoid collision. Using
the autopilot, he adjusted the heading order to 050 (T). At about the same time, Bahuga
Jaya’s chief mate also decided to take action to avoid collision. He ordered port 20 and the
helmsman executed his order.
At 0441, Norgas Cathinka’s heading was 055 (T) and turning to 060 (T) as set on the
autopilot.
At about 0442½, Bahuga Jaya’s chief mate ordered hard to port. Norgas Cathinka was less
than half a mile ahead. By this time, Norgas Cathinka’s chief mate had changed to hand
steering mode and turned the wheel to starboard to alter course more quickly.
At 0443, Norgas Cathinka’s heading was 066 (T) and turning to starboard i.e. towards the
east. Bahuga Jaya was 3 cables directly ahead of the vessel and turning quickly to port,
towards the east. The two vessels were closing rapidly at a speed where they would meet in
about 1 minute.
At 0443¼, Bahuga Jaya’s chief mate made an attempt to contact Norgas Cathinka on VHF
radio channel 16. He called the vessel’s name three times, using ‘Bahasa4’, but did not
receive any response.
Norgas Cathinka’s chief mate was still at the steering stand and he did not understand the
radio call. At 0443¾, with Bahuga Jaya about 100 m away, he turned the wheel hard over to
starboard.

At 0444¼, Norgas Cathinka’s heading was 135 (T) and turning quickly to starboard. A few
seconds later, the Norgas Cathinka’s port bow collided with Bahuga Jaya’s starboard side,
aft of the bridge. At 0444½, aware of the collision, Gelis Rauh made a distress (Mayday) call
on VHF radio channel 16.
At 05.25, the AIS of Bahuga Jaya no longer appeared in Norgas Cathinka’s radar display. The
vessel sank in position 05 52.764 S/105 51.108 E, in water about 79 m deep.
At 05.30, after moving 5 Nm from the collision position, Norgas Cathinka returned to the
collision position and soon dropped its anchor in the area.
The collision resulted Bahuga Jaya heel to port and then continuing until it capsized. There
were 10 ferries approaching the collision site and assisting the survivors. Later Search and
Rescue operation found 206 survivors and 7 fatalities. Norgas Cathinka suffered minor
damage to her bow structure.
Investigation report identifies that assumption were made on both vessels. Bahuga Jaya
assumed that no course alteration was made by Norgas Cathinka. Hence the chief mate took
action by turning to port i.e. towards Norgas Cathinka. This is not consistent with the
regulations for preventions of collision at sea (COLREGs).
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

Location: MOZAMBIQUE CHANNEL 200 MILES EAST OF BEIRA, MOZAMBIQUE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PANAMANIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'EVERTON' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE MOZAMBIQUE CHANNEL 200 MILES EAST OF BEIRA, MOZAMBIQUE IN LAT. 20 20S., LONG. 037 58E., ON 26/09/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND TO BE BROKEN UP.

SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE TO ENGINE ROOM, ACCOMMODATION AND BRIDGE. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SALVAGE CONTRACT AWARDED TO TSAVLIRIS. MV 'MORNING CROWN' SUPPLIED ADDITIONAL SUPPLIES TO CREW AND MV 'FLEUR DU CAP' PROVIDED STANDBY SAFETY COVER. SALVAGE TEAM TAKEN TO THE VESSEL ON FV 'VEGAS 12'. TUG 'TERAS HYDRA' ARRIVED ON SCENE ON 04/10/12 AND EFFECTED TOW TO BEIRA. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO DURBAN, SOUTH AFRICA.

On 25 September 2012, Wilson Blyth was loading a cargo of Barrack Modules in the port of Stjørdal.  The loading operation was being carried out by a mobile shore crane, in a particularly windy day. 

At around 1645, one of the Modules swung towards the duty AB.  He was hit and consequently lost his balance, fell over the shipside’s hand rails onto the jetty, and the quay tyre fenders. 

The crew member suffered serious head injuries.  However, he recovered in a local hospital and was repatriated several days later. 

The MSIU identified a number of contributing factors to the accident.  These included crew members not familiar with the loading of this cargo type, cargo operations in windy conditions, and limited risk identification and control measures.

On September 24, 2012, the Crude Oil Tanker Kyeema Spirit dragged her anchor in Estonian territorial waters East of Isle Aegna (Ulfs ) and subsequently run aground while trying to leave the anchorage  I . The weather conditions had been deteriorating since the vessel anchored in calm conditions on the previous day to near gale winds (14-17 m/s) and rough sea on the night of the accident.
The vessel sustained damage to her hull. There were no personal injuries and no damage to the environment. No other vessels were involved in the accident
Kyeema Spirit arrived to Estonian territorial waters in ballast condition on 23rd September and anchored 8 nm from the harbour to await berth at Port of Muuga for cargo loading. The following night the wind speed increased and the vessel s anchor started dragging. The Captain decided to leave the anchorage until the weather would improve. While manoeuvring to leave the anchorage area the vessel run aground.
The casualty was caused by human erroneous action, usage of outdated navigational chart information and adverse weather conditions.

SOLASStatus: HORIEI MARU: Unknown/unspecified, NIKKEI TIGER: SOLAS
Location: 900 kilometres off the Pacific coast of Miyagi prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
The Japanese tuna-fishing vessel HORIEI MARU sank after colliding with Panamanian bulk carrier NIKKEI  TIGER in pos 38 30 N, 149 05 E area, some 900 kilometres off the eastern Pacific coast of Miyagi, Japan, on Monday 24 September 2012, around 02:30 (local time).  Thirteen people, of the 22 crew members of the HORIEI MARU, are still missing.
Two Coast Guard planes, 1 Japanese Air Force patrol plane, several fellow fishing vessels and the NIKKEI TIGER are involved in the search. 
The NIKKEI  TIGER was undamaged and her crew (21) were reported safe

While approaching the Port of Paramaribo under pilotage, the vessel came into contact with an unidentified submerged object causing damage to the vessel's ballast tanks numbers 1 and 2. Further inspection revealed a crack 15 meters in length and 10-15 centimeters in width.

At about 2110 on 23 September 2012, a packet of aluminium ingots collapsed while a stevedore was climbing down it to shore up a packet of ingots which had been loaded previously. The ingots landed on the stevedore who died as a result of the injuries he sustained.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: SEA OF OKHOTSK 4 MILES OFF MANILY, KAMCHATKA, RUSSIAN FEDERATION
SummaryOfEvents:
THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION-FLAGGED REFRIGERATED CARGO SHIP FOUNDERED IN THE SEA OF OKHOTSK 4 MILES OFF MANILY, KAMCHATKA, RUSSIAN FEDERATION AT 2030 HOURS LT ON 23/09/12 IN GOOD WEATHER.

8 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS, RESCUED BY FV 'MRS-046' AND TAKEN TO UST-BOLSHERETSKY, KAMCHATKA. NO INJURIES REPORTED. 2 CREW MISSING. SAR OPERATION EFFECTED BY 7 F/V'S IN THE AREA AND HELICOPTERS.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Proceeding loaded from the terminal Dalia (Angola) to Algeciras, at sea in position l = 02 06'S and L = 001 05'E, at 10:10 hours UTC a sailor, who was cleaning up the lid of the hatch of the tank ballast no. 6 Port, is found dead inside the tank, on a platform 7 m below entrance.

Location: GULF OF ALASKA 40 MILES SOUTHWEST OF RESURRECTION BAY, AK, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE US-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'MOONLIGHT MAID' FOUNDERED IN THE GULF OF ALASKA 40 MILES SOUTHWEST OF RESURRECTION BAY, AK, USA IN LAT. 59 17N., LONG. 149 50W., AT 2101 HOURS LT ON 20/09/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

A USCG KODIAK BASED MH-60 JAYHAWK HELICOPTER ATTENDED THE SCENE AND WINCHED THE 4 CREW MEMBERS FROM A LIFERAFT AT 2251 HOURS LT THE SAME DAY, THEY WERE AIR LIFTED TO AN EMERGENCY MEDICAL UNIT AT SEWARD, AK. USCG SECTOR ANCHORAGE EFFECTED AN INVESTIGATION. THERE WERE 20-30 MPH WINDS AND 13 FOOT HIGH SEAS AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.

Location: PACIFIC OCEAN 150 MILES WEST OF POINT PIEDROS BLANCAS, CA, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE US-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'ALLISON C' TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM AND SANK IN THE PACIFIC OCEAN 150 MILES WEST OF POINT PIEDROS BLANCAS, CA, USA IN LAT. 35 23N., LONG. 123 53W., AT 2030 HOURS LT ON 20/09/12.

USCG C-130 AIRCRAFT PROCEEDED TO THE SCENE AND AIR DROPPED ADDITIONAL PUMPS AND SURVIVAL EQUIPMENT. CREW UNABLE TO CONTROL INGRESS OF WATER AND ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFT. SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY ANG HH-60G HELICOPTER AND TAKEN TO MOFFETT, CA FOR MEDICAL CHECKS. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED.

Location: Off Barangay Pasiagan in Bongao Town
SummaryOfEvents: On 20 September 2012, the ferry SIRANAN, carrying 27 passengers sank off Barangay Pasiagan in Bongao Town.  Seven people died and 5 were reported missing.  Search and rescue operations by members of the Philippine Coast Guard, Philippine Navy and maritime police were still ongoing off Bangao.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: KOREA STRAIT 30 MILES WEST OF OJIKA SHIMA, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CAMBODIAN-FLAGGED AGGREGATES CARRIER 'DONG HE' CAUGHT FIRE IN A HOLD IN THE KOREA STRAIT 30 MILES WEST OF OJIKA SHIMA, JAPAN IN LAT. 33 08N., LONG. 128 31E., AT 0830 HOURS LT ON 19/09/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND BROKEN UP AT TAIXING, CHINA IN DECEMBER 2012.

COASTGUARD SHIPS AND AIRCRAFT ATTENDED THE SCENE AND ASSISTED WITH FIREFIGHTING OPERATIONS. ALL 12 CREW RESCUED. NO INJURIES REPORTED.
After contact with a fixed object, E/P SERVIOLA UNO flooded and sank in Ra de Muros (A Corua).One live lost.

Fishing vessel "1095 " unmorring from berth No. 112 B, by ship engine, and to the time u-turn have contact with vessel " TOBIS ". Vessel " TOBIS " the contact time have pos. alongside the berth No. 123 A.

After being informed by the Chief Engineer that a bilge alarm had been activated, the Master ordered two seamen to accompany him to check the situation in hold no. 1. Without breathing apparatus, the Master entered the hold which was filled with pig iron. After a short while, the vessel was stopped due to the two seamen having noticed that the Master had fallen down the hold’s entry ladder. Jointly, the crew managed to retrieve the Master’s corpse from the hold but all efforts to reanimate the Captain were without success.

On September 16, 2012 at approximately 14:46, Liberian flagged bulk carrier, YM VIRTUE, touched bottom with under water objects while transiting from Paranagua/Brazil to Singapore near Indonesia. The vessel, as a result of the incident, was immersed in seawater. Lightering and salvage operations were conducted to refloat the vessel. There were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

On 15 September 2012 at 1620, Europa II had just completed its last harbour cruise for the day. During the disembarkation of the passengers, the gangplank fell off the quay and partially in the water.  Consequently, one of the passengers fell overboard.  Two other passengers almost fell in the water. 

The crew members, who were at both ends of the gangplank assisting the disembarking passengers, took immediate action to help the passenger who fell overboard and the other two disembarking passengers. 

No one suffered any injuries as a result of the accident.  However, the passenger who fell overboard was under shock and had to be treated in hospital. 

The safety investigation concluded that the mooring configuration in the prevailing circumstances was not sufficient to hold the vessel within the required range of movement.
At about 1130Hours of 15th September 2012, the vessel was abandoned at serious listing conditon due to heavy weather. The ship's master was missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
At 0100lt 15m Sep 2012, MV,YUSHO REGULUS is loading cargo SBM at Berth SHED NO.38 of Santos port, Brazil, one deep draft vessel MV.COAL HUNTER passed c10se to her side in an excessive speed while outward bound, the result was a swell and wave, which caused our vessel MV.YUSHO REGULUS to surge along the berth and breaking ship's mooring lines, then damaged two shore loaders, and some ship's appliance as follows:

On 14 September 2012, the Mexican-flagged tug CMM COATZACOALCOS took water in the engine room and foundered in the Coatzacoalcos river off Coatzacoalcos, Mexico in heavy weather conditions.

Three crew members were rescued, one member died and one was reported missing.  Tugs PAPALOAPAN, BOLUDA CRESPO, RIO USUMACINTA and OAXACA assisted with search and rescue operations.  No pollution was reported.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Mahakam River, East Kalimantan region, Indonesia
SummaryOfEvents: On 13 September 2012, the passenger ship, KM SURYA INDAH, sank in Mahakam River when sailing from Samarinda to Melak in Indonesia's East Kalimantan region.  One hundred and twelve passengers and crew were on board; 83 crew members were rescued; 22 died and 7 members were reported missing.  Rescuers were seacing for those crew members still missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: FORMOSA ELEVEN: SOLAS, PORT PEGASUS: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On September 12, 2012 at approximately 19:49 (LT), Liberian flagged chemical tanker, FORMOSA ELEVEN, while under local pilotage, was involved ina collision with Chinese flagged bulk carrier vessel, PORT PEGASUS. The bow of FORMOSA ELEVEN struck the bow of PORT PEGASUS and both vessels were damaged, but there were no reports of injuries or incidents of pollution or cargo damage.

Location: 6nm east of Berry Head, near Brixham
SummaryOfEvents: On 11 September 2012, the 14:94 m fishing ship Sarah Jayne was lost approximately 6nm east Berry Head. While loading the catch, two waves swamped the deck, leading to flooding of the fish hold and eventual capsize, resulting in the loss of the skipper.

SOLASStatus: DIANA J: Unknown/unspecified, EURUS LIMA: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: While under pilotage and tug assistance, EURUS LIMA was navigating through Puerto Barrios on September 10, 2012 at approximately 00:06 (LT). While slowly proceeding, EURUS LIMA approached DIANA J, which was also navigating from port under pilotage and towing assistance proceeding astern. The EURUS LIMA sought to proceed behind DIANA J, but was compelled to increase speed to avoid DIANA J's stern from colliding into the EURUS LIMA starboard side. Unfortunately, EURUS LIMA did not increase her speed and DIANA J did not decrease her speed soon enough as DIANA J ended up colliding with EURUS LIMA, hitting the latter vessel's aft midship on the starboard side. There were no reports of injuries or pollution.

Location: Departure Nhava Sheva, Port of Mumbai, India
SummaryOfEvents:
On 09 September 2012 at 16:35 LT container vessel Amsterdam Bridge had
just departed from Nhava Sheva (port of Mumbai, India) with the pilot still on
board when an explosion was noticed by the bridge team.
Cargo1: Containers, may include goods under IMDG code

ShipsInvolved: las palmas de gran canaria (IMO 9031997), MISTRAL EXPRESS (IMO 7915101)
SOLASStatus: las palmas de gran canaria: Unknown/unspecified, MISTRAL EXPRESS: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: While manoeuvering for getting alongside the pier the roro Vessel spanish flagged LAS PALMAS DE GRAN CANARIA lost control of the portside propeller and hit the pier as well as the berthed vessel MISTRALs aftwith minor damages to both as well as its own hull.

Location: Gulf of Tonkin, 50 miles southeast of Haiphong, Vietnam
SummaryOfEvents:
On 5 September 2012, at 2130 hrs (local time), the Vietnamese-flagged general cargo ship foundered in the Gulf of Tonkin, 50 miles southeast of Haiphong, Vietnam in heavy weather.

Search and rescue operations were effected.  The following day two crew members were rescued by a local fishing vessels, a third crew member was rescued by border patrol ship after 48 hours on 7 September 2012 and six other members were reported missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: ENGLISH CHANNEL 30 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PLYMOUTH, UNITED KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN AND NORTHERN ISLAND
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FISHING VESSEL 'CHLOE T' TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM, LOST POWER AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN THE ENGLISH CHANNEL 30 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PLYMOUTH, UK IN LAT. 49 57N., LONG. 003 59W., ON 01/09/12 IN GOOD WEATHER.

INITIAL DISTRESS CALL RECEIVED AT 1620 HOURS LT. MV'S 'MAERSK PATRAS', 'ARMORIQUE' AND 'MAIR', FV'S 'AMBER J' AND 'LADY MAUREEN' AND SALCOMBE RNLI LIFEBOAT ATTENDED THE SCENE. ALL 5 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS, RESCUED BY NAVAL SEAKING HELICOPTER AND TAKEN TO RNAS CULDROSE. NO INJURIES REPORTED.

THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'JUL' CAUGHT FIRE IN SUPERSTRUCTURE WHILST UNDERGOING REPAIRS AT A SHIPYARD AT IZMAIL, UKRAINE AT 1420 HOURS LT ON 31/08/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND SUBSEQUENTLY SOLD FOR BREAKING UP.

BLAZE EXTINGUISHED AFTER 5 HOURS BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES AND FIREFIGHTING VESSELS. 2 PERSONS DEAD AND 2 INJURED AND TAKEN TO LOCAL HOSPITAL. SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE TO 400 SQUARE METRES OF SUPERSTRUCTURE.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 31 August 2012, the fishing vessel ADVANTAGE sank 14 miles southeast of Kodiak Island.  A Coast Guard helicopter crew from Air Station Kodiak rescued 3 people from a life raft and was searching for a missing crewmember.  After several unsuccessful attempts to contact the vessel via radio the watchstanders directed the launch of an MH-60 Jaykawk helicopter crew from Air Station Kodiak.  Once the helicopter crew arrived on scene they located a life raft with 3 of the Advantage crewmembers aboard and began hoisting them to safety.

Location: OFF THE COAST OF EL SALVADOR
SummaryOfEvents:
THE BELIZEAN FISHING VESSEL 'WANG JIA MEN 99' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM, LOST PROPULSION, STRANDED ON BEACH AND SUBSEQUENTLY BROKE IN TWO OFF THE COAST OF EL SALVADOR ON 30/08/12.

ALL CREW RESCUED EXCEPT FOR CAPTAIN WHO IS MISSING.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: 27 MILES SOUTH OF FORMENTERA ISLAND, IBIZA, SPAIN
SummaryOfEvents:
CAUGHT FIRE IN EXHAUST PIPE IN ENGINE ROOM AND SANK IN THE MEDITERRANEAN SEA 27 MILES SOUTH OF FORMENTERA ISLAND, IBIZA, SPAIN AT 1300 HOURS LT ON 29/08/13.
11 CREW RESCUED FROM LIFERAFT BY YACHT 'ENDEAVOUR' AND 12TH CREW MEMBER RESCUED BY HELICOPTER 'HELIMER 207' AND AIRLIFTED TO HOSPITAL IN IBIZA WITH BURN INJURIES. SAR VESSEL 'SALVAMAR MARKAB' UNSUCCESSFULLY ATTEMPTED TO EXTINGUISH THE BLAZE.

M/V Ao Yang Xi Wang with Panama flag went ground at 0040 off Chongjin, DPR Korea due to the bad weather on 29 August, 2012,. Portside hull was seriously damaged, the engine room was flooded with sea water through the hole of the bottom of bulkhead and the sea was polluted by the oil leakage.

Location: CHOYAK ISLAND, WANDO, REPUBLIC OF KOREA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CHINESE-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'CAI XIN' STRANDED AFTER DRAGGING ANCHOR ON CHOYAK ISLAND, WANDO, REPUBLIC OF KOREA IN LAT. 34 22N., LONG. 126 54E., AT 1500 HOURS LT ON 28/08/12 IN TYPHOON 'BOLAVEN'.

ALL 16 CREW RESCUED BY COASTGUARD. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE TO HULL. UNKNOWN QUANTITY OF OIL LEAKED INTO SEA. ANTI POLLUTION MEASURES DEPLOYED.

On 28 August 2012, two Chinese fishing vessels YUEJIANGCHENGU91104 and YUEJIANGCHENGYU91105 with a crew of 34 on board, capsized and sank in East China Sea.  Two crew members managed to get to the shore and notify the authorities.  One fisherman was rescued and 31 were reported missing.

Location: SOUTH CHINA SEA 30 MILES NORTHEAST OF QUY NHON, VIETNAM
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VIETNAMESE-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'TOAN THANG 36' DEVELOPED SEVERE LIST AND SANK IN THE SOUTH CHINA SEA 30 MILES NORTHEAST OF QUY NHON, VIETNAM IN LAT. 14 11N., LONG. 109 22E., AT 1740 HOURS LT ON 26/08/12.

INITIAL DISTRESS CALL RECEIVED AT 1620 HOURS LT THE SAME DAY. MV 'DURC NAM 01' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST, RESCUED ALL 11 CREW AND TOOK THEM TO QUY NHON. NO INJURIES REPORTED.

Location: underway from Santiago to Havana Cuba
SummaryOfEvents: While underway from Santiago, Cuba to Havana, Cuba, the vessel was instructed to await for pilotage until the next morning. In doing so, the vessel got caught in the middle of Hurricane Isaac. As weather conditions worsened, the vessel's main engine was unable to restart and ran aground. Rescue assistance was rendered to crew members on board the vessel by way of helicopter.

SOLASStatus: CSAV PUYEHUE: SOLAS, KAI XUAN: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On August 25, 2012, while CSAV PUYEHUE and KAI XUAN was transiting the Yellow Sea, the two vessels observed one another approaching.  As both vessels altered course anticpating a crossing situation (KAI XUAN to port and CSAV PUYEHUE to starboard) KAI XUAN began passing CSAV PUYEHUE. While on CSAV PUYEHUE's port side, KAI XUAN turned suddenly and collided into CSAV PUYEHUE, colliding into her No. 6 bunker tank and her port stern. There were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

On 24 August 2012, at 2238, the Gozo Ferries Company Limited passenger / car ferry Malita with 126 passengers and 30 motor vehicles commenced a berthing manoeuvre at Quay no. 2 at the port of Mgarr, Gozo.  At 2240, the off-loading of the vehicles commenced almost as soon as the ship’s bow ramp unfolded and landed on the shore linkspan.  Two propulsion power thrusters used in manoeuvring Malita alongside were set on bridge control and positioned in the direction of the quay to keep her alongside during the mooring operation.  The shipside door-ramp had yet to be lowered for passengers to disembark. 

At about 2241, without any warning, the bow ramp and the vessel gathered sternway.  As the vessel started to move astern and away from the shore linkspan, the head rope parted.  The bosun, who was stationed at the bow ramp, immediately informed the master and started the process of closing the ramp.  By the time the movement of the vessel could be arrested, the ramp had slid to the edge of the shore linkspan, and rested on the ledge.  As a result of this movement, the four hinged flaps lifted almost perpendicular to the shore linkspan.  Three motor vehicles that were being driven off the ramp at the time were caught by the flaps.  The occupants of the motor vehicles suffered no physical injuries although they had been reported to be in a state of shock.  One passenger was eventually taken to hospital to receive medical assistance. 

An internal investigation was conducted by the Company, and a number of safety actions had been taken to prevent a similar future accident.
 
The Marine Safety Investigation Unit concluded that the failure of the mooring rope was the extraordinary strain on the head rope from the thrusters’ power.  Based on the findings of the safety investigation, and taking into consideration the safety actions by the Company, three recommendations have been issued, aimed to address loading and off-loading of motor vehicles and the safety of mooring operations.

On August 24, 2012 at approximately 21:25 (LT), the vessel was dragging anchor due to very strong current on low tide. While the anchor continued to drag maneuverability became increasingly difficult and the vessel Master further encountered propulsion problems with the vessel. The Master notified local Port Authorities for assistance and the Port Authority officers were able to secure the vessel with 11 shackles.

Location: RED SEA 40 MILES NORTHEAST OF SAFAGA, EGYPT
SummaryOfEvents:
THE BARBADIAN-FLAGGED BULK CARRIER 'RENOS' CAUGHT FIRE IN THE ENGINE ROOM IN THE RED SEA 40 MILES NORTHEAST OF SAFAGA, EGYPT IN LAT. 26 52N., LONG. 034 35E., AT 0300 HOURS LT ON 23/08/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND TOWED TO GADANI BEACH FOR BREAKING.

LOF SALVAGE CONTRACT AWARDED TO UNKNOWN SALVORS. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO AL-ADABIYA, EGYPT FOR INSPECTION. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND BEACHED AT GADANI BEACH, PAKISTAN ON 02/05/13 FOR BREAKING UP.

Location: CARIBBEAN SEA ON MIDDLE CAY, BEQUIA, ST VINCENT AND GRENADINES
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP OF DOMINICA 'LOVE DIVINE' STRANDED IN THE CARIBBEAN SEA ON MIDDLE CAY, BEQUIA, ST VINCENT AND GRENADINES IN LAT. 12 59N., LONG. 061 17W., PM ON 23/08/12. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.

CREW RESCUED BY LOCAL VESSELS. NO INJURIES REPORTED. BUNKER FUEL REMOVED BY SALVORS. SMALL QUANTITY OF OIL LEAKED INTO SEA.

Location: 60 MILES NORTHWEST OF CAPE KANIN, RUSSIA
SummaryOfEvents:
REPORTED PROPELLER FOULED BY FISHING NETS AND LOST POWER IN THE BARENTS SEA 60 MILES NORTHWEST OF CAPE KANIN, RUSSIA IN LAT. 68 59N., LONG. 041 08E., AM ON 21/08/13. OBSTRUCTION REMOVED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.
TUG 'PURGA' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND EFFECTED TOW TO SHELTERED ANCHORAGE OFF KILDIN ISLAND WHERE DIVERS REMOVED THE OBSTRUCTION WITHIN A FEW HOURS.
Death of Master and serious injury of an Oiler.

Location: E N BISSO SHIPYARD ON THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER AT NEW ORLEANS, LA, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE TUG 'GLADYS B' FROM THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA SANK WHILST MOORED AT THE E N BISSO SHIPYARD ON THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER AT NEW ORLEANS, LA, USA IN LAT. 29 55N., LONG. 090 08W., AT 0610 HOURS LT ON 19/08/12. SUBSEQUENTLY RAISED AND BROKEN UP.

1 CREW MEMBER EVACUATED. NO INJURIES REPORTED. APPROXIMATELY 3,000 GALLONS OF DIESEL FUEL LEAKED INTO WATER. USCG ATTENDED THE SCENE. ANTI POLLUTION BOOMS DEPLOYED.

On 19 August 2012, the passenger ferry SALWAT, carrying 12 passengers capsized near the Maziwe Islet in the Indian Ocean.  Eleven passengers were rescued with one passenger reported missing.  The accident occurred due to bad weather.  The SALWAT with a carrying capacity of 35 passengers, started to take in water after it was hit by strong ocean currents.

Location: CHILE, Playa Llo-Lleo, Puerto San Antonio
SummaryOfEvents:
ENGLISH VERSION: The "Ocean Breeze" was riding at anchor, waiting to enter the Port of San Antonio to unload the ship’s grain cargo.  During the night, the ship dragged anchor due to the storm and heavy sea and went aground in a sandbank on the Llo-Lleo beach.
The ship’s anchoring position could not be corrected on time.  The propulsion engine suffered a failure and could not be put into operation, causing a delay.
The port’s tugs which were deployed to the site to provide assistance, could not carry out the maneuver due to the heavy sea and shallow waters.
MRCC Chile coordinated the rescue operation and evacuated all the crew with helicopters provided by the Chilean Navy.
No injured persons or pollution were registered.  The ship is currently the subject of salvage operations.


VERSIÓN EN ESPAÑÓL: El Bulck Carrier "Ocean Breeze" se encontraba fondeado a la gira esperando ingresar al Puerto de San Antonio, para desembarcar un cargamento de granos. Durante la noche su ancla garreó  debido a las fuertes marejadas que afectaban el sector, encallando en una playa de arena, denominada LLo-Lleo.
La nave no logró corregir oportunamente su débil posición de fondeo y al tratar de poner en funcionamiento su motor propulsor este presentó fallas, demorando su puesta en servicio.
Los remolcadores del puerto que concurrieron a prestar ayuda no pudieron pasar los remolques debido al fuerte oleaje y al poco fondo del sector en que se desarrollaba la emergencia.
El MRCC Chile coordinó medios de salvamento, evacuando a la totalidad de la dotación por medio de helicópteros de la Armada de Chile.
No se registraron lesionados producto del siniestro ni contaminación, encontrándose actualmente la nave en proceso de salvataje.

While underway from Nuuk, Greenland to Gdansk, Poland, the vessel ran aground. The vessel refloated with tug assistance on 28 August 2012. There was no damage to the propulsion nor were there any reports of injury or pollution.

On the morning of 16 August 2012, the container ship VEGA SAGITTARIUS departed from the port of Nuuk, Greenland, heading for Aasiaat in the north-western part of Greenland.
Approximately one hour after departure, the watch keeping officer changed course in order to avoid drifting ice ahead and shortly after, the ship ran aground on a submerged rock by the en-trance to Godthåbsfjorden.
After extensive salvage work the ship was refloated on 29 August 2012 at 0532 and safely brought alongside in Nuuk.
The Danish Maritime Accident Investigation Board has made recommendations to the operator of the ship and to the charterer of the ship.

On 16 August 2012, a crew member, involved in a working accident on board the Norwegian-flagged factory trawler VOLSTAD suffered severe crush injuries and died.  The accident occurred while the trawler was located southeast of Hopen.  The crew members tried in vain to keep the injured crew member alive.  The Governor of Svalbard sent a Super Puma helicopter with healthcare professionals to the vessel, but the injured crew member was pronounced dead at 17:30 hrs.  The ship was directed to Tromsoe where it berthed in the morning of August 18 2012 for investigations.

THE JAPANESE-FLAGGED AGGREGATES CARRIER 'SADA MARU NO. 88' STRANDED ON ROCKY SHORE NEAR HIGASHIIZU, IZU, JAPAN IN LAT. 34 46N., LONG. 139 03E., AT 0420 HOURS LT ON 15/08/12. SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER IN BOW COMPARTMENT AND ENGINE ROOM. COASTGUARD VESSEL ATTENDED THE SCENE. ANTI POLLUTION BOOM DEPLOYED AS A PRECAUTION. REFLOATED WITH ASSISTANCE AND TOWED TO UNKNOWN SHIPYARD FOR REPAIRS.

At 1607 (UTC+1) on 14 August 2012, Mr X, an experienced recreational diver, fell onto the deck of the dive workboat Jean Elaine.  When he fell, Mr X was fully dressed and prepared for diving to a depth of 95m; he was wearing heavy equipment on his back and had additional diving gear attached to his front and sides. Although it was not immediately apparent, it was likely that the diving gear impacted into his abdomen during the fall and caused significant internal injuries. Having been helped back to his feet by the boat’s crew, Mr X made a positive indication that he wished to continue with the dive and he entered the water unaided. At a depth of 88m, he started an unplanned return to the surface. He lost control of his breathing and buoyancy shortly afterwards. Three of his fellow divers attempted to increase his buoyancy and administer breathing gases; however, Mr X did not start breathing again. He was attached to a lifting bag and ascended to the surface from a depth of 65m. Despite further medical treatment on board Jean Elaine and by the emergency services, he could not be revived and was pronounced dead later that evening.

Location: CARIBBEAN SEA 43 MILES NORTHWEST OF RIOHACHA, COLOMBIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CONTAINER SHIP 'HANEBURG' FROM ANTIGUA AND BARBUDA SUSTAINED MAIN ENGINE FAILURE IN THE CARIBBEAN SEA 43 MILES NORTHWEST OF RIOHACHA, COLOMBIA IN LAT. 12 02N., LONG. 073 18W., AT 0300 HOURS LT ON 14/08/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND BROKEN UP IN DOMINICAN REPUBLIC.

TUG 'DE ZHOU' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND EFFECTED TOW TO WILLEMSTAD, CURACAO ARRIVING 19/08/12 FOR INSPECTION. SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE TO MAIN ENGINE AND SOLD UNREPAIRED FOR BREAKING UP.

Vessel arrived German Bight anchorage on the 12th August waiting for terminal readiness. Having waited at German Bight anchorage, where ship had arrived from Hound Point, UK, the vessel weighed her anchor on 13th August  for a piloted river transfer up to Wilhelmshaven Germany. All pre departure checks and tests had been carried out and found in good order before the anchor was weighed and due to the fact that the vessel was at anchor for more than 24 hours, the crew were well rested. Cargo on board was 87230 tonnes of crude oil, draft was 13.45m meters, even keel. During transit from anchorage to Wilhelmshaven the vessel's movements were tracked and monitored by the VTS in the area, first German Bight Traffic and later Jade Traffic. Pilot had also requested radar control from ashore, intending to take every precaution for a safe transit up the river. This service is normal practice when transiting up to Wilhelmshaven with a deep draft vessel. Visibility was good during the transit. During the first two (2) hours of the passage, the tide was rising and vessel adjusted it's speed. All the way to the starboard buoy no 17 during this voyage, the prepared voyage plan was followed. The vessel navigated safely in the German Bight traffic area towards the river Jade. However after the starboard buoy no 17, the vessel was on the starboard side of the fairway. Jade Traffic had at this point, acknowledged the deviation and informed the vessel. When the vessel turned at starboard buoy no 19, the steering course was given as 165 ° and shortly corrected to 160 ° to compensate for the setting by the current which had been against m/t Katja during her passage proceeding in the river Jade. After the turn the current came more in from port side and affected the vessel far more than expected. The vessel slowly slid to the bottom of the river and finally ran aground between buoy 19 and 21. It was later confirmed by the Chief officer that there were no injuries, pollution and that there was no ingress of water in ballast tanks and cargo tank ullages were unchanged. The ship initially tried to use its own engine astern and ahead and rudder movements from port to starboard in order to refloat the vessel. This attempt however failed but vessel later refloated with tug assistance on 14th August and resumed passage to Wilhelmshaven.

Location: NO.1 LOWER HOLD/CHINA SHIPPING INDUSTRY (SHANGHAI CHANGXING) CO. LTD
SummaryOfEvents: At 1705lt on Aug 13th 2012,bosun went down No.1 cargo hold tween deck to check watertightness ofNo.1 hatch cover,fell down from No.1 after part tween deck to No.1 hatch cover bottom,cause his head touch the bottom oftank top ofNo.110wer hold, found bled from his mouth and nostril, no response to calling,can measure his pulse and breath, at about 1753lt on Aug 13th 2012, when send to shanghai changxing hospital by ambulance, the doctor announce he was dead due to doesnot heartbeat and breath.

The FV Lady Eileen departed Quilty Pier, Co. Clare at approximately 07:00hrs on 13th August 2012, on a fishing trip with two crewmembers onboard. The ship failed to return at its expected time of 17:00hrs – 19:00 hrs.
Initially the alarm was raised locally and when no sighting of the ship could be seen, the Coast Guard was alerted at 20:56 hrs. Rescue Helicopter R115, Doolin Coast Guard Unit, Kilkee Coast Guard Unit, Kilkee Rescue Unit and Aran Island Lifeboat where tasked for the search operation.
At 22:45 hrs Doolin Coast Guard located debris 0.25 miles west of Spanish Point. At 23:08 hrs Doolin Coast Guard spotted fish boxes and other debris and detected a strong smell of diesel between Spanish Point and Cream Point.
The search was called off for the night at 01:20 hrs on 14th August 2012 and resumed at first light on 14th August 2012

At 05:46 hrs on the 14th August, a fishing ship came a cross four net marker buoys believed to be from the lady Eileen.
Shortly before 12:00 hrs, on the 14th August 2012, members of the Burren Rescue team dived on to the Lady Eileen and located two bodies in the vicinity of the wheelhouse of the ship.
The bodies were brought to the surface and removed from the scene by member of the Kilkee Rescue Unit
A post mortem examination confirmed that both men died from drowning
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 10 August 2012, the engine room of the 23.7m twin-rig stern trawler Audacious flooded while the vessel was fishing, in calm weather conditions, 45 miles east of Aberdeen. The crew were unable to stop the ingress of water and abandoned ship shortly before the vessel sank at 1554.

Location: TAIWAN STRAIT 28 MILES SOUTHEAST OF XIAMEN, CHINA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CHINESE-FLAGGED CONTAINER SHIP 'XIN SHE KOU' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE TAIWAN STRAIT 28 MILES SOUTHEAST OF XIAMEN, CHINA IN LAT. 24 16N., LONG. 118 28E., AM ON 10/08/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND SUBSEQUENTLY SOLD FOR BREAKING UP.

RESCUE TUG 'DONG HAI JIU 113' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST WTH FIREFIGHTING OPERATIONS. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY 0230 HOURS LT THE FOLLOWING DAY. NO INJURIES REPORTED. TOWED TO XIAMEN FOR INSPECTION. SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE TO ENGINE ROOM. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO SHIPYARD AT SHANGHAI, CHINA WHERE ARRIVED 17/08/12 FOR FURTHER INSPECTION.

In Navigation from Chiwan to Singapore on 09/08/2012 at 22:30 UTC, the Ch. Cook informed the Bridge (Ch. OFF. on duty) that Cat Boy Flavien Benessy Rodriguez didn't came on work in usual time 06:00. Cook also told to Ch. Officer that he immediately calls Flavien in cabin and there was no reply from him. 
At 22:40 UTC Ch. Off, immediately advice the Master of the situation and ask to come on the bridge to relieve the Ch.Off. In order to search in cabin of Catering Boy. 
But Catering Boy was not IN. Once Master on the bridge-Ch.Off., together with Cook, Steward and went to check the crew mesroom, galley and garbage store. 
In 22:45 on a deck-starboard side next to the garbage store, the c10th (shoes and trousers) of Flavien was founded (see attached photo).
22:55 Ch. Off advised Master about all situations, Master gave order to call all crew to contribute in Search according to ISPS Search List 
23:30 after investigating and checking of all spaces and accommodations on ship we couldn't found Flavien. Master advises Company about situation and we proceed WITH IAMSAR Operations. 
At 23:35 UTC Ch Eng and other engine members finished search in Engine room. No sing óf missing crew member. They have checked allengine spaces, steering gear, engine casing, emergency generator room and tunnels. 
23:40 we sent PAN PAN PAN to all vessels by VHF for M.O.B. 
23:41 Sent PAN PAN PAN to all vessels by INMATSAT C FOR M.O.B.

Location: BLACK SEA 40 MILES NORTH OF CIDE, TURKEY
SummaryOfEvents:
THE MOLDOVAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'YUKKA' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE BLACK SEA 40 MILES NORTH OF CIDE, TURKEY IN LAT. 42 29N., LONG. 032 57E., AT 1540 HOURS LT ON 09/08/12. SUBSEQUENTLY SANK ON 12/08/12 WHILST UNDER TOW BOUND EREGLI, TURKEY.

CREW UNABLE TO EXTINGUISH BLAZE. ALL 13 CREW RESCUED BY COASTGUARD VESSEL 'TCSG-96'. 1 CREW MEMBER SUSTAINED SERIOUS INJURIES AND TAKEN TO HOSPITAL IN INEBOLU. TAKEN IN TOW OF TUG 'MARINE TUG 1' BOUND EREGLI, TURKEY BUT SUBSEQUENTLY SANK 5 MILES WEST OF EREGLI AT 1140 HOURS LT ON 12/08/12 IN LAT. 41 16N., LONG. 031 19E.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

Location: ATLANTIC OCEAN 18 MILES NORTHWEST OF HENTIES BAY, NAMIBIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE MAURITIAN-FLAGGED CABLE LAYER 'CHAMAREL' CAUGHT FIRE IN ACCOMMODATION IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 18 MILES NORTHWEST OF HENTIES BAY, NAMIBIA IN LAT. 22 0S., LONG. 014 00E., AT 2000 HOURS LT ON 08/08/12. WRECK BROKEN UP IN SITU.

ALL 58 CREW ABANDONED SHIP AND WERE RESCUED BY FPV 'NATHANIEL MAXUILILI' AND UNKNOWN FISHING VESSEL AND TAKEN TO WALVIS BAY, NAMIBIA. 6 CREW SUSTAINED MINOR INJURIES AND WERE TAKEN TO A LOCAL HOSPITAL. FIRE SPREAD TO REST OF VESSEL WHICH SUBSEQUENTLY STRANDED APPROXIMATELY 25 MILES NORTH OF HENTIES BAY ON 09/08/12. SOME OIL POLLUTION REPORTED IN SEA. SMIT MARINE ATTEMPTING TO PUMP OUT REMAINING BUNKER FUEL.

Location: ANCHORAGE 25 MILES EAST OF PARANAGUA, BRAZIL
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PANAMANIAN-FLAGGED BULK CARRIER 'TIMIOS STAVROS' SUSTAINED EXPLOSION IN THE ANCHORAGE 25 MILES EAST OF PARANAGUA, BRAZIL IN LAT. 25 36S., LONG. 048 08W., PM ON 07/08/12. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

2 CREW DEAD. PROCEEDED TO BERTH AT PARANGUA ON 08/08/12 FOR INVESTIGATION. REPORTED INCIDENT OCCURRED DURING WELDING OPERATIONS.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: BULK JAPAN: SOLAS, WILF SEYMOUR: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 06 August 2012, at approximately 1400 Eastern Daylight Time, the bulk carrier Bulk Japan was involved in a close quarters situation with the tug Wilf Seymour while the tug was pushing the barge Alouette Spirit in the Gulf of St. Lawrence near Sept-Îles, Quebec.

On 04 August 2012 approximately at 11:15LT a fire erupted in the engine room of m/v JUPITER while fitter and oiler conducted maintenance repairs on the main sea water pump No. 2. Fitter asked to increase ampere from welding machine and it caused an electrical shock subsequently fire. A big flame reached fitter causing serious burns on his face, neck and trunk. Crew members immediately flooded the Engine room to extinguish the fire and fitter was taken to a hospital on a helicopter.

Location: Bahía Espíritu Santo al Oeste a 210 MN, Punta Herrero-Puerto Chico México
SummaryOfEvents: El día 31 de julio del 2012., la nave se encuentra fondeada en el anclaje de Balboa; la misma zarpo con 16 tripulantes a bordo,  los cuales 15 son de nacionalidad panameña y 1 de nacionalidad colombiana, con destino a México, Ciudad del Carmen para realizar sus operaciones de carga de combustible (MDO), a las 1620 hora local. La embarcación recibe piloto abordo para realizar su tránsito por el Canal de Panamá de Sur a Norte. El día primero (1ero) de agosto del 2012, la embarcación se encuentra libre de las esclusas de Gatún y a la 0100 del mismo día se desembarca el piloto del canal continuando la misma con su rumbo hacia México. El día 2 agosto la nave continua su viaje sin ninguna novedad se mantenía un cielo despejado,  mar y viento moderado. El día 3 de agosto la embarcación recibe comunicación telefónica de la compañía informando del mal tiempo que se aproximaba.  El día 4 de agosto el segundo ingeniero y el cadete de máquinas entregan la guardia al primer ingeniero y a la cadete Dayra Wood  Pino, la cual sufre un lamentable accidente perdiendo la vida.

Location: SOUTH CHINA SEA 10 MILES WEST OF CAPONES POINT, LUZON, PHILIPPINES
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PUSHING TUG 'KOSCO 202' OF THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM AND DEVELOPED LIST TO STARBOARD IN THE SOUTH CHINA SEA 10 MILES WEST OF CAPONES POINT, LUZON, PHILIPPINES AT 0105 HOURS LT ON 02/08/12 IN TYPHOON 'GENER'. SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP.

TUG WAS TOWING UNKNOWN BARGE WHEN TOW LINE BROKE. ALL 7 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFT AND WERE RESCUED BY COASTGUARD VESSEL 'SARV-002'.

Location: Close to the shore on the south part of Clare Island, Clew Bay, Co. Mayo
SummaryOfEvents:
On 14th August 2012 the “Gurteen Lass”, fishing number WT 239P, departed
from Portnakilly Pier, Clare Island. Mr.X, owner of the vessel, was
on board and he advised those on shore he wished to check a string of lobster
pots between Portnakilly and the south eastern point of the island.
Later, the same day, when the vessel failed to return to port, a search was
organised. Wreckage was sighted on the shore near an area referred to as
Bachelor’s Island, on the south coast of Clare Island and the emergency services
were notified.
 A short while later a body was sighted in the water. The body was recovered
and the identity was confirmed. The emergency services were stood down.

ShipsInvolved: ALEXANDER TVARDOVSKIY (IMO 9057290), UKD BLUEFIN (IMO 9143427), WILSON HAWK (IMO 9064906)
SOLASStatus: ALEXANDER TVARDOVSKIY: Unknown/unspecified, UKD BLUEFIN: Unknown/unspecified, WILSON HAWK: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: When manoeuvring in an enclosed basin, the cargo vessel collided with a port dredger which was then pushed in to another vessel alongside. The cargo vessel, which had a pilot on board, was manoeuvring astern at the time of the collision. Defects within the bridge control system resulted in the crew operating the propulsion machinery manually at the local controls in the engine room. Despite orders being passed via the bridge telegraph for the ahead gear to be selected, the astern gear remained engaged. Due to the age of the vessel, propeller direction indicators were not required to be fitted in the engine room, and the one on the bridge was not monitored. All three vessels were damaged.

Location: Pointe du Champs du Port, Cötes D'armort
SummaryOfEvents:
Le 31 juillet 2012, vers 18 heures 40, le navire de transport à passagers GUILLEMOT (PL 925104), avec 60 personnes à bord, heurte à 8 noeuds le plateau rocheux de la « pointe du champ du port », situé à proximité du port des Hôpitaux (commune d’Erquy).
De nombreux passagers sont projetés sur l’avant et seize d’entre eux sont  légèrement blessés.  Après s’être assuré de l’absence de voie d’eau et du bon fonctionnement de la propulsion et de la barre, le capitaine envisage dans un premier temps de débarquer ses passagers au port des Hôpitaux.
Il prend en définitive la décision de regagner le port d’Erquy proche du lieu de l’incident et informe les passagers de la situation. Le CROSS Corsen n’est pas informé.
Le matelot et un médecin présent à bord prodiguent les premiers soins aux blessés.
Le capitaine avise par téléphone son armateur puis le CODIS 22.
Vers 19h00, le GUILLEMOT accoste au ponton en eau profonde du port d’Erquy, les premiers blessés sont pris en charge par le centre de secours avec mise en place d’un PC médical.  Neuf blessés sont évacués sur les hôpitaux de Saint-Brieuc et Dinan et un blessé est évacué par hélicoptère sur l’hôpital de Saint-Brieuc. Les six autres sont traités sur place.
Après consultations toutes les autres personnes regagnent leur domicile. Une plongée effectuée plus tard permettra de constater une déformation au niveau du « saumon » tribord. Le permis de navigation a été maintenu après que le bureau Véritas, contacté par les soins du CSN, ait examiné les avaries et confirmé le certificat de Franc-bord

Location: 6 MILES NORTH OF BOZCAADA ISLAND, TURKEY
SummaryOfEvents:
STRANDED IN THE AEGEAN SEA 6 MILES NORTH OF BOZCAADA ISLAND, TURKEY IN LAT. 39 57N., LONG. 026 03E., AT 1935 HOURS LT ON 30/07/13. SUBSEQUENTLY REFLOATED, INSPECTED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.
NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. TURKISH COAST GUARD DESPATCHED TUG 'KURTAMA 2', LIFEBOAT 'KIYI EMNIYETI 3' AND ANTI-POLLUTION VESSEL 'TAHLISIYE II' TO ASSIST. REFLOATED ON 01/08/13 AND ANCHORED SOUTH OF BOZCAADA ISLAND FOR INSPECTION.

Location: BREAKWATER AT NAVOTAS FISHING PORT, MANILA, PHILIPPINES
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FILIPINO-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'OCEAN INTEGRITY' STRANDED ON THE BREAKWATER AT NAVOTAS FISHING PORT, MANILA, PHILIPPINES IN LAT. 14 38N., LONG. 120 56E., AT 0650 HOURS LT ON 30/07/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL, TOOK WATER AND DEVELOPED LIST. ALL CREW RESCUED. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. COASTGUARD VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE.

Location: off Tablas Strait in Romblon, Sibuyan Sea
SummaryOfEvents:
The passenger ship, SUPER SHUTTLE FERRY 1 was sailing to Batangas City from Dumaguit via Odiongan town in Romblon when it encountered rough sea conditions.  Upon taking shelter at Looc Bay in Tablas Island, the ship ran aground at around 7 pm.  The Master was said to have declared “abandon ship” when the vessel started taking in water. He then directed all passengers to transfer to life rafts.
All 57 passengers and 48 crew members were said to have been rescued and accounted for. However, one of the passengers died shortly after they were brought to shore.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 29 July 2012, at 1708 Eastern Daylight Time, the bulk carrier Common Spirit struck the corner of the dock at sections 16 and 17 in Trois-Rivières, Quebec, while manoeuvring under the conduct of a pilot. The vessel was being assisted by 2 local tugs at the time. There were no injuries or pollution, but the vessel and the dock sustained damage requiring repairs.

SOLASStatus: Torre Giulia: Unknown/unspecified, Torre Giulia: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Le Torre Giulia, thonier senneur de la Compagnie Française du thon Océanique, a appareillé de Port Louis l’île Maurice) à la suite d’un arrêt technique le 3 juillet 2012, à destination de ses lieux de pêche. 
Le 28 Juillet 2012 en début de matinée, le vent du sud-est pour environ 20 nœuds génère une houle de 205 m. Vers 9 :00, à la position 02°55’S/055°01’E, le navire largue son skiff pour effectuer un coup de senne sur un DCP (dispositif concentrateur de poissons). Vingt minutes après commence le relevage de la senne.
Pendant le virage de la senne, au cours d’une manœuvre destinée à positionner le navire par rapport au filet, la remorque du skiff, qui est frappée sur un anneau fixe sur l’AR du pavois tribord, déforme la tape horizontale d’accès au local barre. Dans ce local sont aussi entreposées des pièces (des cartes électroniques) particulièrement sensibles à l’humidité.
Averti, le chef mécanicien  décide d’intervenir. Il se rend sur place accompagné du second et du troisième mécanicien. Les deux officiers mécaniciens vont chercher des outils tandis qu’il reste sur Place.
Au même moment, le skiff commence à tirer. Pendant  cette manœuvre ; il passe de tribord vers bâbord. La remorque balaye l’arrière du thonier et frappe le chef mécanicien à la poitrine.
A son retour, quelque minutes plus tard, le second mécanicien trouve le chef inanimé sur le pont. Il donne l’alerte.
Malgré les soins qui lui sont prodigués immédiatement, l’équipage ne parvient pas à le ranimer. Il décède peu après.
Le capitaine décide alors de faire route sur le port de Mahé au Seychelles où le Torre Giulia arrivera le lendemain en milieu de journée.

Location: between Republic of Korea and Tsushima Island, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: while at sea on 27th July 2012, at about between 0500 Hrs - 0800 Hrs (LT), in GPS position Latitude 34º 36’ N; Longitude 129º 08’ E had a casualty where by the 1st Engineer was missing and lost at sea.

On 25th July 2012, the vessel “MT Bunga Alpinia” arrived at PETRONAS Methanol  (Labuan) Sdn. Bhd.(PMCSB) Her last port of call was Jubail, Saudi Arabia, where 
she had loaded methanol into tank no. 3W, 4W, 7W and 8W. In Labuan, she was  scheduled to load methanol into tanks 1P, 2W, 5W, 6W and 9W. 
25th July/ 0700 hours: Bunga Alpinia dropped anchor at Labuan and commenced cargo loading preparation. 
25th July/ 1536 hours: The vessel was safely secured to jetty and the loading master and chief officer completed Ship/Shore safety checklist. 
25th July/ 1750 hours: Commenced first foot loading in tanks 1P, 2W, 5W, 6W and 9W. 
25th July/ 1945 hours: Ceased first foot loading (1P, 2W, 5W, 6W, 9W) and samples taken for analysis. 
25th July/ 2115 hours: Full loading commenced at agreed rate of 650 tons/hour in 1P, 2W and 6W. 
26th July/ 0200 hours: Load at 6W tanks reached 800 ton each. At this point, loading was stopped at 6W, changed to 5W as per plan and continued at 664 t/hr. 
26th July/ 0230 to 0233 hours: Weather Condition: Drizzle and intense lightning in 
distance.  (i) Freak lightning strike forward of the vessel. (ii) Pump man reported to 2nd Officer, by radio, that there was a fire at 1 
Port PV valve. 
(iii) 2nd Officer radioed fire report to PCMSB Terminal Central Control Room and ordered loading to be stopped. 
(iv) 2nd Officer closed pump delivery valves on 1P and 2 wing tanks by remote control from the ship CCR (Cargo Control Room). 
(v) 2nd Officer repeated radio messages to PCMSB control room to stop loading due to fire on deck. 

26th July/0234 hours: Loading stopped by PCMSB control room. 
26th July/ 0237 hours: Fire explosion in tanks 1 and 2 followed by a second explosion in tanks 5 and 6. 
26th July/ 0240 hours: Captain ordered abandon ship.
26th July/ 0655 hours: Another explosion was heard from ship. PCG instructed to shut gas feed system to neighboring and shut down GRT 1 (Gas receiving terminal 1).
26th July/ 1403 hours: Fire was put under control. 
The incident resulted in five fatalities; all of them were the ship crews. It also caused minor oil pollution which was later controlled by Marine Department and the appointed contractor. 
The vessel was declared as “Constructive Total Loss” (CTL).
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At about 1650hours 25th July 2012, the Hong Kong, China registered supply tug boat "Hai Yang Shi you 699" was flooded and finally sank at 22°06.76'N, 114°16.30''E south off Hong Kong water due to heavy weather.

1700LT, on 24th July 2012,a Panama Registered Bulk Carrier MVJin Yang Guan (IMO:8747654) loading with a cargo of Direct Reduction Iron exploded in its No.1 cargo hold while its sailors was preparing to open the hatch covers of No.1 cargo hold during its berth in Tianjin Port. Five People were burned and the hatch cover.

At around 0530H UTC/ 24 July 2012, Oiler no.1 Furio who's on duty in engine room, called the bridge and informed the OOW C/O Pajarillaga that he met 3/E Ferdinand Yana in the alleyway near the hospital going out through the starboard access in mooring deck with his left hand blooded suspected wounded and required first aid. After Oiler no.1 made a call through telephone in fire station, he went out and look for 3/E Ferdinand Vana but nowhere to be found. The OOW sent the AlB on watch to assist in searching 3/E Vana. OOW called master, Chief engineer, 1st Engr. Master made the public address to search and traces of blood stain is seen in the alley way starboard side access going out to mooring deck. Traces of blood stain stopped at the starboard near the starboard handrail near provision crane. Master ordered release manoverboard buoy in starboard side wing ordered williamson turn. Activated the SSAS button and all crew posted lookouts and others keep searching. MRCC Capetown also informed by telephone and 1ater email. Upon inspection at 3/E Yana's cabin, plenty blood stain on his bed and floor. His cabin now is locked. Searching is ongoing with in constant communication with MRCC Capetown. 
Even after great efforts and with the assistance of MRCC Capetown, Regrettable Vessel still could not find missing crew, 3/E Ferdinand A. Vana, Vessel terminated the searching/rescue operation on 25th/July/2012, and resume her original sailing. 
Termination Time: 0545H UTC/LT 25th July 2012. Position: Lat. 35-28.5 S 006-49.8 E
ShipType1: Other Bulk Dry (cement, woodchips, urea and other specialized) Carrier

SOLASStatus: DA XIN HUA HUANG PU: Unknown/unspecified
Location: NORTH EAST TIP OF BAILI DAO ISLAND 18 MILES SOUTHEAST OF MACAU
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CHINESE-FLAGGED CONTAINER SHIP 'DA XIN HUA HUANG PU' STRANDED AFTER DRAGGING ANCHOR ON THE NORTH EAST TIP OF BAILI DAO ISLAND 18 MILES SOUTHEAST OF MACAU IN LAT. 22 00N., LONG. 113 46E., ON 24/07/12 IN A TYPHOON. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU AND SUBSEQUENTLY BROKE UP AND SANK.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. ALL CREW RESCUED. SUSTAINED SEVERE HULL DAMAGE. BUNKER FUEL AND POLLUTANTS REMOVED BY SALVORS.

Le port de plaisance de Saint-Quay-Portrieux est doté d’un navire de servitude à propulsion électrique, l’Alessandro Volta, produit par la société E3H.
Alors que des opérations de maintenance, ponctuées par des essais, ont été effectuées la veille sur cette embarcation, une violente explosion se produit le 24 juillet  2012 au matin à la mise en route du moteur bâbord. Sous l’effet du souffle, la coque s’ouvre en deux et le marin, seul à bord, est projeté à plusieurs mètres. Il est grièvement blessé et l’Alessandro Volta est partiellement détruit. 
A la suite de cet accident, la totalité des embarcations produites par la société sont retirées du service
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: While approaching anchorage at Isyspinten, the vessel ran aground. A zodiac vessel was launched to take sounding around the vessel able to successfully refloat the vessel. There were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

On 23 July 2012, at approximately 0130 (UTC +1), the fishing vessel BETTY G, capsized while beam trawling.  All three crew members were rescued approximately 10 hours later.
The vessel capsized as a result of the load in the starboard trawl net releasing suddenly.  BETTY G progressively flooded and sank.  The crew acted swiftly and deployed the liferaft, which ultimately saved their lives.  No distress message was transmitted and no alarm was raised, even though the vessel was fitten with an emergency position indicating radio beacon (EPIRB) and a MOB Guardian.

While the vessel was conducting cargo discharge operation along Berth #13 at Port Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, at approximately 13:25 (LT) the vessel's auxiliary engine's #2 LO filter pressure guage connection was broken from vibration. The pressure guage fell off.  Hot lube oil under pressure began spashing to the ceiling above the auxiliary engine #2 and partially towards insulated exhast pipes at the inlet of the turbo charger of Engine #2 causing widely and rapidly spreading fire. The shore fire team arrived on board and managed to extinguish the fire using CO2 sprinkler apparatus. There were no incidents of pollution reported, however, there was an injury reported. Ukranian vessel Electrical Engineer, Leonid Puzanov, was rescued by the vessel's chief engineer. When the ambulance arrived, Puzanov had no direct flame skin burns, but he was shaking and in a lot of pain (most likely results from the high temperature and poisonous smoke inhallation).
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'HUNG GYONG' REPORTED TO HAVE FOUNDERED ON 21/07/12

On 14 July 2012, the Maltese registered container vessel Zim Rio Grande departed Mundra, India bound for Haifa, Israel via the Suez Canal.  The vessel was fully laden and was also carrying dangerous cargo. 

On 20 July at 1300 (LT), the second engineer, who was on his way to the forecastle deck, observed smoke from one of the containers stowed in Bay 34 (Figure 1).  The master was immediately informed and took control of the situation. 

At the time, the vessel was in the Red Sea in position 24° 42.0’N  036° 11.3’E.  She was on a course of 330°(T), making 19.5 knots.  The air temperature was 40°C whilst the sea temperature was 33°C. 

As there was neither any activity nor hot work in the vicinity of Bay 34, the reason for the smoke was not immediately apparent. 
 
The master immediately altered the vessel’s course to avoid wind blowing smoke in the direction of the ship’s accommodation.  He also reduced speed and instructed the chief mate to check the stowage plan and identify the container. 

The chief mate determined that the source of smoke and fire was Container ZIMU 1046577 with a Class 4.2 - UN 3341 cargo. 

The safety investigation concluded that the most likely cause of the fire and smoke was an exothermic decomposition of thiourea dioxide cargo. 

One recommendation was made to Transport Malta, aimed to raise awareness on the potential hazards associated with the carriage of this cargo.

On 20 July 2012, at 09:45 hrs (local time), an explosion and fire started aboard an offshore supply ship in Abuloma Jetty in Port Harcourt, Nigeria, killing more than 30 people.  The 3 sole survivors were highly injured and taken to the local hospital.
The explosion is believed to have been caused by a short circuit during maintenance works, while the ship was berthed in Abuloma Jetty.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship
