THE INDIAN-FLAGGED WELL STIMULATION VESSEL 'VESTFONN' CAUGHT FIRE IN TANK WHILST UNDERGOING REPAIRS IN DRYDOCK AT MORMUGAO, INDIA AT 1550 HOURS LT ON 18/07/12. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES. 1 SHIPYARD WORKER KILLED AND 1 SUSTAINED SERIOUS INJURIES AND TAKEN TO LOCAL HOSPITAL. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN. FIRE STARTED DURING HOT WORKS. POLICE INVESTIGATION AND REPAIRS EFFECTED.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Between Zanzibar and Dar es Salaam, United Republic of Tanzania.
SummaryOfEvents: The Tanzanian passenger ship SKAGIT, with approximately 287 people on board (281 passengers and six crew), capsized, and reportedly sank, off the coast of the United Republic of Tanzania, while en route from Dar es Salaam to the island of Zanzibar on Wednesday 18 July 2012.  The ship left Dar es Salaam at noon (0900 GMT) for what normally would be a two to four hour trip to Zanzibar’s largest island.  The ship ran into high winds and heavy seas which caused it to list heavily and ultimately capsize. Survivors reported that the engines failed as the ship rolled. Twenty-four bodies were recovered, 145 people were rescued and 118 were reported still missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Type of incident :        Engine room fire.

     Estimate of damage :
       Totally down of function of engine room machines and
       equipment due to covering with fire extinguishing water
       and burnt out of some parts in engine room, etc.

On her voyage from San Antonio (Chile), the general cargo ship Brielle had arrived in the port of Ensenada in La Plata (Argentina) on 13 July 2012 at 23:00 hours LT. The vessel carried a part load of construction material of which pieces were stowed on deck on pontoon type hatch covers, and others in the vessel’s tween deck folding lids. This cargo was destined for La Plata. 
To safeguard this cargo for getting shifted while the vessel was in transit beside standard lashing and securing some construction parts were partly secured by steel stoppers and lashing rings welded on deck.
To discharge the cargo this securing stoppers and securing bolts had to be grinded off the steel plates on which they were welded. To do this job, a landside company was instructed by the vessel’s charterer. When the workers of this company approached the vessel, the chief mate showed the foreman the work to be done without verifying any authorization and hot work permit issuance. While doing the job, a fire broke out during which three of the working gang were injured and one died in the cargo hold where the fire had started. There was no bodily harm to any crew. All hands were saved through effective cooperation with landside fire brigades and rescue resources.

The flag State marine safety investigation Authority has initiated a full casualty investigation into this very serious marine casualty as per Chapter 6 of the Casualty Code. The main objective thereby is to identify the root cause of the occurrence and to highlight potential means which could have prevented it.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed
Cargo1: General, may include dry bulk and DG

SummaryOfEvents:
On 14 July 2012, a fire broke out in hold No. 4 (triggered by an explosion) onboard the container ship MSC FLAMINIA, 1,000 miles west of Cornwall.  The ship, carrying 25 people was en route from Charleston to Belgium.
The oil tanker DS CROWN was the first on the scene and recovered 24 people from a lifeboat   One crew member died from burns sustained, three were injured while fighting the fire and one crew member is reported still missing.  
After the crew had abandoned the ship, MSC FLAMINIA was left drifting in mid-Atlantic.  The full extent of the fire is still unknown, however nearby ships in the region have reported a large plume of smoke rising from the burning ship.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Immediately after leaving port under foggy conditionsCyprus Flagged HSC ALGECIRAS JET hit the ground with minor damages to its port side hull, returning to Tarifa port for inspection.

Location: AEGEAN SEA ON KOULOURA ISLET, GREECE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'YAAKOB II' SUSTAINED MECHANICAL PROBLEMS AND STRANDED IN THE AEGEAN SEA ON KOULOURA ISLET, GREECE IN LAT. 37 17N., LONG. 026 48E., AT 2230 HOURS LT ON 12/07/12. SUBSEQUENTLY ARRIVED AT ALIAGA, TURKEY ON 25/08/12 FOR BREAKING UP.

SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO FORWARD HULL AND TOOK WATER. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. COASTGUARD VESSELS AND TUG 'AEGEAN PELAGOS' ATTENDED THE SCENE. ANTI POLLUTION BOOM DEPLOYED. TEMPORARY REPAIRS AND PUMPING OUT EFFECTED. REFLOATED ON 15/07/12 AND ANCHORED FOR INSPECTION. SUBSEQUENTLY PROCEEDED TO PIRAEUS, GREECE FOR FURTHER INSPECTION.

ShipsInvolved: ARUNI RICKMERS (IMO 9270828), Aruni Rickmers Schiffahrts.. (IMO 9270828), BLUE ANGEL (IMO 9071765)
SOLASStatus: ARUNI RICKMERS: Unknown/unspecified, Aruni Rickmers Schiffahrts..: SOLAS, BLUE ANGEL: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
On 12 July 2012, at 11:30 hrs, the Maltese registered bulk carrier Blue Angel, was involved in an allision with the German registered container ship Aruni Rickmers. At the time of the accident, Aruni Rickmers was on anchor in the South Outer Harbour, Busan.

Blue Angel had sailed from Luoyuan, China in ballast on 10 July 2012 for Busan. The plan was to take bunkers before proceeding to Tacoma, USA. End of sea passage was logged on 12 July 2012 at 09:48 hrs. Her destination was South Outer Harbour. Busan VTS has directed the ship to drop her anchor in N4 Anchorage Area.
However, upon anchoring at 11:20 hrs, Busan VTS instructed the master to relocate her anchorage as it was deemed to be very close to Aruni Rickmers.
While weighing up the anchor, the master ordered engines on "dead slow astern" but found himself in close quarter situation with a bunker-barge supplying bunkers to a ship astern of Blue Angel. In quick successions, the master ordered "dead slow ahead", "slow ahead", and "full ahead" on the main engine in order to clear the bunker barge. However, this manoeuvre brought Blue Angel even closer to Aruni Rickmers. A subsequent "hard to starboard" helm and various engine movements were not sufficient enough to clear her from Aruni Rickmers.

At 11:30 hrs, Blue Angel made heavy contact with Aruni Rickmers in position 35° 02.21'N  129° 03.64E, in the N4 Anchorage Area. Aruni Rickmers sustained minor damage to her bulbous bow.
However, Blue Angel suffered extensive hull damage.
Although there were no reported injuries or pollution, her port side shell plating in way of cargo hold no. 3 was punctured and a number of side shell plating, frames and brackets were either deformed or dented.
It was concluded that the immediate cause of the accident was Blue Angel's anchoring in very close proximity of Aruni Rickmers. Two safety recommendations were made to the managers of the ship with the scope of addressing the hazards related to anchorage in waiting areas.

Location: off the French Island of Mayotte, Indian Ocean
SummaryOfEvents: On 12 July 2012, during the night, a boat carrying 24 people, from Anjouan in the Comoros, capsized off the Indian Ocean French Overseas Territry of Mayotte.  At least 7 people died with 6 others feared missing.  Authorities reported that 11 people had been rescued.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 11 July 2012, the Changqing 16, loaded with 10,168 tons of iron ore from Majishan Island capsized in the Yangtze River in China.  A total of 24 crew members were thrown into the water; 2 members died and 7 were reported missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: SEA OF JAPAN OFF THE YEONPYEONG LIGHTHOUSE, JEJU, REPUBLIC OF KOREA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE BELIZEAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'LONG SHAN' STRANDED IN THE SEA OF JAPAN OFF THE YEONPYEONG LIGHTHOUSE, JEJU, REPUBLIC OF KOREA IN LAT. 33 31N., LONG. 126 58E., AT 0115 HOURS LT ON 10/07/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

NO INJURIES REPORTED. SUSTAINED 20 CENTIMETRE CRACK IN HULL AND TOOK WATER. 5000 LITRES OF OIL LEAKED INTO SEA. COAST GUARD VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE. REMAINING BUNKER FUEL LIGHTERED AND ANTI POLLUTION MEASURES DEPLOYED. REPORTED NOT FINANCIALLY VIABLE FOR REPAIR.

On 10 July 2012, a propeller accident on board supply ship PACIFIC AVENGER resulted in a crew member being thrown from the ship.  The accident occurred off Angola.  The crew member was rescued, however the injuries sustained were too severe and the crew member died en route to the hospital in Luanda.

On 9 August 2012, the fishing vessel DENARIUS suffered a major fire.  Prior to the incident, the vessel's main engine had been running with severely retarded timing for several hours, resulting in a build-up of unburnt fuel within the exhaust system.  This fuel ignited; the resulting heat transferred through areas of poor insulation to wiring close to the exhaust trunking, causing the electrical insulation to catch fire.  Dense smoke and fire then spread quickly, forcing the crew to abandon to liferafts.  
Approximately 40 minutes later the cew were rescued by helicopter and taken to Lerwick, where they were treated for minor smoke inhalation.  Once the fire had burnt out, DENARIUS was towed to port where she was declared a constructive total loss and scrapped.

Location: SEA OF JAPAN 180 MILES SOUTHWEST OF NAKHODKA, RUSSIAN FEDERATION
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CAMBODIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'STAR' SUSTAINED CRACKED KINGSTON VALVE AND TOOK WATER IN THE ENGINE ROOM IN THE SEA OF JAPAN 180 MILES SOUTHWEST OF NAKHODKA, RUSSIAN FEDERATION IN LAT. 42 45N., LONG. 132 55E., AT 1700 HOURS LT ON 06/07/12. SUBSEQUENTLY SOLD FOR BREAKING UP.

8 OUT OF THE 16 CREW RESCUED BY MV 'VASILY GOLOVNIN'. REMAINING CREW ASSISTED WITH SALVAGE OPERATION. TUG 'LAZURIT' PROCEEDED TO ASSIST AND EFFECTED TOW TO NAKHODKA ARRIVING ON 08/07/12 FOR INSPECTION.

SOLASStatus: MI MONTSE: Unknown/unspecified, STOLT SPRAY: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On 05/07/2012 the chemical vessel STOLT SPRAY was sailing near the Alboran sea, with destination to the port of Le Havre (France). The fishing vessel MI MONTSE had been fishing in that area all the night and returned to port, with no lights at all. At 05:17 the vessel STOLT SPRAY realised that there were a fishing vessel very close, about 100 m, and turned the rudder all to starboard. The fishing vessel changed neither her speed nor her course. At 05:18 both vessels collided.

SOLASStatus: Martnez Segundo: Unknown/unspecified, Sierra Lara: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On July 4th, 2012, at 16:25 LT, the cargo vessel SIERRA LARA left the port of Vigo (Spain) with destination to IJmuiden (Netherlands). Minutes later, when the pilot got off, the vessel increased her speed to 11 knots and set course 248, going out of the Vigo estuary. At the same time the fishing vessel MARTNEZ SEGUNDO left the port of Bouzas (southern side of the Vigo estuary) with destination to the port of Cangas de Morrazo (northern side of the Vigo estuary). The vessel had a speed of 6 knots and a course of 312. Some minutes before the collision the vessel SIERRA LARA watched the fishing vessel and tried to alert her and put the rudder hard to starboard, while the fishing vessel kept her course and speed. At 16:50 both vessel collided. Only the fishing vessel suffered minor damages and her master some injuries. Some minutes later both vessel continued their travels.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:

Location: Vicinity of Northen Hei Gun To, Yanai city, Yamaguchi Pref., Japan
SummaryOfEvents: While Chemical Tanker CHEM HANA was proceeding in the vicinity of Northen Hei Gun To, two crews collapsed in a cargo hold. They were taken to hospital, only to be confirmed dead.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

At 04 :43 hrs on 23 July 2012, while on passage from Belfast to  Greenock , the 89m feeder container ship Coastal Isle ran aground on the Island of Bute. The grounding resulted in significant damage to the forward section of the ship, including minor breaches to the forward ballast tanks.

During a voyage between Marseilles and Algiers, a steward, coming back to his cabin (01h00 in the moning), had to cross a watertight door that was closed because of navigation in poor visibility conditions. 
He opened partially the door to pass, the door shut more rapidly he was expecting and trapped his left leg.
The steward is seriously injured and the decision is taken to evacuate the seaman.
After contact with the Palma MRCC (01h47), he will be transfered, in the bay of Palma, on board the support vessel Marta Marta (03h57), then to the medical services and the hospital of the town.
At 07h00 he will be taken to the operation theatre.
He will remain 11 days in the hospital, and then 8 months off.

Location: 1 MILE OFF CANJULAO, LAPU-LAPU CITY, PHILIPPINES
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FILIPINO-FLAGGED AGGREGATES CARRIER 'B & E UNO' STRANDED WHILE MANEUVERING TO BERTH, TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM, DEVELOPED LIST AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK 1 MILE OFF CANJULAO, LAPU-LAPU CITY, PHILIPPINES IN LAT. 10 18N., LONG. 123 57E., AT 2100 HOURS LT ON 01/07/12.

CREW ABANDONED SHIP AND SWAM ASHORE, LATER RESCUED BY SERVICE BOAT CLN. VESSEL SUBMERGED BUT WITH MASTHEAD STILL ABOVE WATER. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SHEEN OF OIL REPORTED ON SEA. ANTI POLLUTION BOOMS DEPLOYED. SALVAGE CONTRACT AWARDED TO OMEGA STEEL AND MARINE SERVICES. SOME FUEL AND CARGO LIGHTERED. REFLOATED IN DEC 2012 BUT SANK AGAIN 2 DAYS LATER. SALVORS DISMANTLING WRECK USING DIVERS TO AID REMOVAL.

On the morning of the 1st July 2012 two ferryboats were moored alongside each other at the ferry bertha at Kilroanan Harbour, Inis Mor. The MV Ceol Na Farraige moored  starboard side alongside the pier and the MV Draiocht Na Fareaige moored to the port side of the MV Ceol Na Farraige.

The engineer of the MV Draiocht Na Farraige was standing in the wheel house of the MV Ceol Na Farraige tallying the passenger boarding the MV Draiocht Na Farraige. He moved to improve his viewpoint and in doing so lost his balance and fell down the stairway, striking his head against the door at the bottom
The emergency services were immediately alerted and the engineer  was airlifted to Galway hospital where he subsequently died.

On 1 July 2012, a rubber boat, carrying 55 people, deflated and sank in the Mediterranean Sea.  The boat was en route to Italy from Libya, however was driven back by strong winds.  The only survivor was taken to a hospital in Zarzis, Tunisia.  It was reported that the boat nearly reached the coast of Italy.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: St Marine Shipyard Tuas Road Singapore
SummaryOfEvents: TO BE PROVIDED LATER

On June 29, 2012 at approximately 02:55, Liberian flagged oil tanker, FAIR ARIS, while under pilotage, was involved in a collision with a local tug boat, PORTALASH. The vessel was approaching the jetty and the vessel's engine reportedly continued dead slow ahead even though the vessel operators ordered for the vessel to stop. The vessel's propellers did not stop and ended up colliding into PORTALASH. PORTALASH, unfortunately sunk as a result of the casualty. There we no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

THE PANAMANIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'SEAWIND' TOOK WATER AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK WHILST ANCHORED OFF MUCURIPE, FORTALEZA, BRAZIL IN LAT. 03 42S., LONG. 038 30W., AT 2215 HOURS LT ON 28/06/12.

INGRESS OF WATER REPORTED PM ON 27/06/12. RESCUE VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE AND ANTI POLLUTION BOOMS DEPLOYED. SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN 10 METRES OF WATER WITH SUPERSTRUCTURE AND MASTS STILL VISIBLE ABOVE THE SURFACE. VESSEL HAD BEEN AT ANCHOR SINCE MAY 2011 WITH ENGINE PROBLEMS. SOME OIL LEAKED INTO SEA. NO INJURIES REPORTED. REMAINING BUNKER FUEL AND LUBRICANTS REMOVED BY SVITZER SALVAGE.

In the morning of 28 June 2012 the tugboat SKULD was one of five tugs engaged in berthing the oil
rig ENSCO 72 in Esbjerg, Denmark. While changing position in the tow with the towline still attached,
SKULD collided with the rig. The collision caused a severe flooding of SKULD which brought the
vessel close to foundering. With the assistance of another tug the crew succeeded in bringing the
vessel alongside berth and, by means of external pumps brought to the vessel by shore authorities,
in stabilizing the situation. During the collision a fuel oil tank was damaged and an estimated 20 m3 of
marine diesel oil was leaked to the water.
This report does not contain any safety recommendations.

THE PASSENGER SHIP 'SEAMASTER' STRANDED AT KOREDOR, WILLEMSTAD, CURACAO IN LAT. 12 06N., LONG. 068 57W., PM ON 27/06/12. SUBSEQUENTLY REFLOATED AND BROKEN UP IN CURACAO IN MARCH 2014.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. BUNKER FUEL REMOVED BY SALVORS. REFLOATED ON 29/06/12 WITH TUG ASSISTANCE AND TOWED TO SAFE ANCHORAGE IN CARACAS BAY FOR INSPECTION. VESSEL HAD BEEN LAID UP AT ANCHOR IN ST. ANNES BAY FOR SOME TIME AND IS FOR SALE.

SOLASStatus: FRISIA ALLER: SOLAS, PACIFIC PEARL: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: While under pilotage, FRISIA ALLER was navigating from Singapore anchorage bound for Haiphong, Vietnam. Once the pilot boarded FRISIA ALLER, the pilot ordered half speed between 13-14 knots. While the vessel was passing a buoy the pilot ordered the vessel hard to port but the bow was still turning starboard due to the shallow water strong current. As a result of the vessel's continued course towards starboard, FRISIA ALLER collided into another vessel PACIFIC PEARL.

In order to avoid collision with a small vessel which intended to cross my vessel's head, my vessel altered course to starboard substantially, resulted in her much deviation from original route, and then stranding happened.

Location: OFF THE HORSBURGH LIGHTHOUSE IN THE SINGAPORE STRAITS
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PANAMANIAN-FLAGGED BULK CARRIER 'SST' STRANDED ON THE MIDDLE ROCKS OFF THE HORSBURGH LIGHTHOUSE IN THE SINGAPORE STRAITS IN LAT. 01 19N., LONG. 104 24E., AT 0430 HOURS LT ON 26/06/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND ARRIVED CHITTAGONG ON 03/12/12 FOR BREAKING UP.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO FORWARD HULL AND TOOK WATER. SALVAGE OPERATIONS EFFECTED UNDER LOF CONTRACT. TUGS 'SALVISCOUNT', 'SALVIXEN' AND 'TTB SALVOR' ASSISTED WITH SALVAGE OPERATION. SOME CARGO LIGHTERED TO BARGES. REFLOATED ON 30/07/12 AND TOWED TO ANCHORAGE OFF SINGAPORE FOR INSPECTION WHICH REVEALED SERIOUS HULL DAMAGE.

The vessel was moored when there was a sewage spill in the bilge. Three crew men went to the site to fix the problem. All of them were intoxicated by inhalation of gases and the skipper died. It was found that the concentration ofsulfhydric acidwas 56 parts per millon. The cause of the spill was thatahose bilge pump was broken.

El buque portacontenedores "Condor" navegaba el Canal Messier, área patagónica chilena, cuando su máquina propulsora sufrió la rotura de una de las cañerías de retorno de combustible, de uno de los inyectores del cilindro N°1.
Debido a las malas condiciones de viento y mar que afectaban la zona y a la cercanía de costa, su capitán determinó no parar la máquina hasta encontrar aguas más seguras.
Transcurridos aproximadamente 20 minutos desde la falla, se produjo un incendio en el motor principal debido a que parte del combustible entró en contacto con el múltiple de escape de gases.
El incendio no pudo ser controlado con los extintores portátiles debiéndose activar el banco fijo de CO2, el cual logró extinguir sin dificultad el fuego.
Al quedar la nave al garete por efecto del viento reinante, esta derivó hasta varar con la escarpada y profunda costa del sector, sin que el ancla tuviera un efectivo trabajo. Sucesivos frentes de mal tiempo produjeron averías en la hélice y vías de agua en la sala de máquinas y sectores de proa, sin que se apreciara contaminación en el sector. No se registraron lesiones a las personas.
La nave quedó imposibilitada de navegar y debió ser remolcada hasta el astillero para su reparación.

Motor vessel Flash, a Maltese registered bulk-carrier, ran aground off Ile de la Galite, Tunisia on 25 June 2012. At midnight, the second mate relieved the third mate from the navigational watch.  The vessel was on autopilot steering 083°.  At 0020, the second mate noticed that the vessel was deviating from the planned course and set the autopilot on a new heading of 086°.  Subsequently, he sat down on the bridge chair and shortly afterwards he fell asleep.  The navigational officer was alone on the bridge and no look-out was posted. 

As Flash approached the next way point, North of Ile de la Galite, the current started to set her south in the direction of Galitons de l'est.  Just before 0100, the Electronic Chart Display and Information System's alarm sounded.  The officer of the watch, however, remained asleep.  When he woke up a few minutes before grounding, it was already too late to reduce speed or change course.  At 0353, Flash ran aground and remained stranded on the rocky shoals of Galitons de l'est in position
37° 33.69'N  008° 57.17'E. 

The vessel sustained extensive damage in the fore and bottom part of the hull but there were no resulting injuries and pollution. 

The MSIU safety investigation highlighted several safety issues, which contributed to the grounding including: 
    
The officer of the watch had become increasingly fatigued.  He had been working for over eight months without a break and had adopted a sleep pattern where he would normally not sleep before the midnight watch; 
No dedicated look-out was posted.  The officer of the watch was alone on the bridge when he fell asleep; 
The master's instructions to post a look-out only when deemed necessary, without regard to the Company's safety management system and relevant international requirements, caused ambiguity and confusion to the officer of the watch. 

Taking into consideration the safety actions already taken by the Company, one recommendation has been made with the scope of ensuring that OOWs make best use of the hours of rest in order to ensure that they are fit to take over the watch.

El 25 de Junio de 2012 a las 0140 horas la M/N "TACORA" y el Wellboat "SEIGRUNN" ex "Allipén", se abordaron mientras navegaban el Golfo de Corcovado, en circunstancia que ambas naves se habían detectado visualmente y por radar con suficiente antelación. Ambas naves hicieron acciones evasivas en el último momento las cuales no fueron efectivas por la cercanía a que se encontraban.  No se gobernó conforme a las reglas del COLREG ni a lo planeado como margen mínimo de aproximación. Los oficiales de guardia no dieron oportuno aviso de la situación de peligro a sus capitanes. 
Las condiciones de visibilidad, viento y mar eran buenas.

A car ferry named "GAYRETTEPE" collided with a small fishing boat shortly after departing the pier ( about 200 meters off the pier). small boat was shattered and two persons who present in boat fell into the sea. 1 person died and other one injured.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: GULF OF TONKIN 1 MILE NORTHWEST OF DONGFANG, HAINAN, CHINA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VIETNAMESE-FLAGGED BULK CARRIER 'NAM LONG 01' SANK AFTER SUSTAINING ELECTRICAL FAILURE IN THE GULF OF TONKIN 1 MILE NORTHWEST OF DONGFANG, HAINAN, CHINA IN LAT. 19 07N., LONG. 108 36E., AT 0650 HOURS LT ON 20/06/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

ALL 14 CREW RESCUED BY LOCAL FISHING VESSEL. NO INJURIES REPORTED. COASTGUARD VESSEL '1813' AND OTHER RESCUE VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE.

THE HONDURAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'JIREH' STRANDED ON A REEF OFF MONA ISLAND, PR, USA IN LAT. 18 04N., LONG. 067 55W., AT 0650 HOURS LT ON 21/06/12. WRECK BROKEN UP IN SITU DURING OCTOBER 2012.

NO INJURIES AND POLLUTION REPORTED. 80 PASSENGERS SWAM ASHORE. REMAINING 20 PASSENGERS STAYED ON BOARD AND WERE SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED. USCG VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE. SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE TO HULL. SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP IN SITU BY RESOLVE MARINE GROUP BY THE END OF OCTOBER 2012.

Location: PACIFIC OCEAN 40 MILES NORTHEAST OF CHICHI JIMA, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FISHING VESSEL 'CHUNG YOUNG NO. 53' CAUGHT FIRE IN THE PACIFIC OCEAN 40 MILES NORTHEAST OF CHICHI JIMA, JAPAN IN LAT. 28 11N., LONG. 141 29E., AT 1630 HOURS LT ON 18/06/12.

THE 23 CREW WERE RESCUED BY KOREAN FISHING VESSELS THAT WERE IN THE VICINITY. COAST GUARD PATROL BOAT ALSO ATTENDED THE SCENE. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. INVESTIGATION EFFECTED.
Members of crew were realise drilling on the boat deck, when the rescue boat launching mechanism failed, and two people who were on board,fell abruptly onto the seawater

On 13 June 2012, the ship JOCIEL-2, with 50 passengers on board, sank near El Nido, Palawan due to inclement weather.  Three passengers were killed and several others were reported missing.  All 16 crew members and 22 of the passengers were rescued.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: The fishing vessel contacted contacted m/v " KURKSE " port side. As result of the collision m/v " KURKSE " bulwark was dented. The fishing boat damaged the bow. No serious damages to both ships. Master of the fishing vessel was found drunk.
Algarrobo encountered adverse weather on June 11 and 12, 2012. The vessel rolled and pitched heavily. As a result, Algarrobo sustained structural hull damage. No injuries or pollution were reported.

THE FISHING VESSEL 'RYBOLOV-1' CAUGHT FIRE AFTER EXPLOSION WHILST UNDERGOING REPAIRS AT SEVASTOPOL, UKRAINE ON 12/06/12. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

2 CREW SERIOUSLY INJURED AND TAKEN TO HOSPITAL WHERE 1 DIED THE FOLLOWING DAY. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On June 10, 2012, E.R. ATHINA was anchored at Aberdeen Bay, Hong Kong when the crew members were conducting their routine Sunday drills. The crew members decided to run the Fast Rescue Craft and touch up the paint job on E.R. ATHINA. The routine operation turned tragic when Bosun, Kurida Pjero, while providing the paint touch up on the vessel, was pinned in between the side of the ship and the FRC railing. Unfortunately, the injuries Pjero sustained in the incident proved fatal as Pjero was pronounced dead shortly after the emergency medical team had taken him to a local medical facility.

A bosun was fatally injured when he was crushed between the ship's hull and the lifting frame of the ship's fast rescue craft. The bosun was the FRC's coxswain and the FRC was being positioned alongside the supply ship's port quarter to repair a small area of damaged paintwork. The FRC was set against the port quarter by the prevailing swell and tidal stream and the bosun was possibly trying to push the FRC away from the hull.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: Vessel Sea Dove depart from La Ceiba, Honduras on June 7, 2012 destination to San Andres Island, Colombia with a viriety of cargo, included 5,000 cement blocks. The vessel have a crew of 9 persons and they have 1 passenger 10 persons in total. Approximately 54 miles from San Andres they found rough seas with waves of 5 to 7 feet, winds of 25 km/h from east. at that moment engine #2 start with problems and not allow the master to give bow to the waves. Waves hit deck and the concrete blocks receive water because they where without any cover from the elements, that water start to collapse the blocks and mooring lines break. All cargo on deck start displacement and vessel capsized and sunked. From 10 persons on board were rescued 4 and 2 were disembarked by Master before departure but without knowledge of Harbour Master and 4 persons remain disappeared.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship
Cargo1: Variety of cargo included 5000 concrete blocks

Location: off the island of Abaco, north of the Bahamas
SummaryOfEvents:
The passenger boat GLORY TIME capsized and sunk off the island of Abaco, north of the Bahamas on Sunday 10 June 2012.  She was en route to the United States, carrying 28 people.  Five were rescued, 11 bodies were recovered and 12 are reported still missing.  The sea was very rough and the boat began to take in water, evenutally capsizing, forcing everyone to scramble for their lives.

Authorities were notified on Sunday at 20:00 hrs, that the boat's engine kept cutting off, which slowed the vessel down, as it was in rough seas near crown Haven in North Abaco.  The Marsh Harbour Police Station were also alerted at 12:10 am (local time) on Monday 11 June 2012.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 21:00 hrs, on the 9 June 2012, the owner and sole occupant of the RIB departed Crosshaven Co. Cork to return the boat to its mooring in Ringaskiddy Co. Cork.  On travelling through the inner channel between main land and Spike Island and standing along side the helm console on the approach to Paddy's Point was suddenly thrown from the boat.  The boat's engine did not cut out and continued running, travelling in an approximate 50m diametre circle.  The owner of the boat was struck several times, sustaining injuries to the forehead, back of the head, back and losing an arm.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: ESTUARY OF THE DEMERARA RIVER OFF VREED EN HOOP, GEORGETOWN, GUYANA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'MISS ELLISA' CAPSIZED AND SANK IN THE ESTUARY OF THE DEMERARA RIVER OFF VREED EN HOOP, GEORGETOWN, GUYANA PM ON 08/06/12. 

6 CREW RESCUED AND 1 CREW MISSING. LARGELY SUBMERGED HULL LYING ON STARBOARD SIDE. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO WESTERN EDGE OF GEORGETOWN HARBOUR FOR DIVERS INSPECTION. WRECK DEMOLISHED WITH EXPLOSIVES ON 23/06/12.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Container vessel, named "MSC LUGANO", crashed into Pier Number17 during the berthing maneuver. Material damage occured ( a distortion with 1,5 meters width and a torn with apprx. 10 cm length) . No any injury or pollution reported

THE AUSTRALIAN-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'LUROY' CAUGHT FIRE WHILST MOORED AT TRIABUNNA, TAS, AUSTRALIA AT 1500 HOURS LT ON 07/06/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR.

BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY LOCAL FIRE SERVICES. NO INJURIES REPORTED. VESSEL COMPLETELY BURNT OUT. REPORTED BLAZE STARTED WHILST THE VESSEL WAS BEING PREPARED FOR RECYCLING WHEN A FIRE THAT HAD BEEN LIT IN A STEEL DRUM FOR WARMTH SPREAD OUT OF CONTROL.

Location: Near light buoy No. 7, Fukuyama port, Hiroshima Pref., Japan
SummaryOfEvents: One crew fell into a cargo hold and was fatally injured on the general cargo ship JUNIPER PIA proceeding to JFE Steel No. 2 export berth, Fukuyama Port, Hiroshima Prefecture.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: JOSEPHINE MAERSK: SOLAS, SPRING GLORY: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 5 June 2012 at 22:34:40 hours, the Hong Kong flagged bulk carrier SPRING GLORY and the Danish flagged container ship JOSEPHINE MÆRSK collided in the eastern approaches to the Singapore Strait, approx. 7 nm NE of Horsburgh Lighthouse. Prior to the collision, SPRING GLORY, loaded with 80,400 mt iron ore, navigated eastbound on the course 046° at a speed of 10.4 knots and had just l eft the traffic separation scheme (TSS) of the Singapore Strait. JOSEPHINE MÆRSK, loaded with general cargo in containers many of which were refrigerated containers, navigated westbound and was about to enter the TSS of the Singapore Strait. According to the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea, SPRING GLORY was the ship to give way, and JOSEPHINE MÆRSK was the ship to stand on. The officer of the watch on SPRING GLORY had, on its radar, noticed JOSEPHINE MÆRSK approaching on a crossing course about 10 minutes prior to the collision. However, options for drastic ship manoeuvres were limited because of the traffic situation so the officer of the watch hesitated and waited for actions to be taken by JOSEPHINE MÆRSK to avoid a collision. During the last minutes prior to the collision, he attempted to communicate with JOSEPHINE MÆRSK, and when he finally took an evasive action by giving helm hard to port, it was too late to avoid a collision. The officer of the watch on JOSEPHINE MÆRSK observed visually SPRING GLORY approaching at a distance of approx. 2 nm on a crossing course, about five minutes prior to the collision. During the time until the collision, he confirmed his observation by the use of binoculars, answered briefly calls from SPRING GLORY ascertaining the identity of that ship, found the distance between the ships on the radar, checked his own position on the GPS and plotted it into the chart. He misunderstood a message on the VHF to increase the speed that was actually meant for another ship and that contributed to him not conducting any effective manoeuvre in due time. He called the master for assistance and took an evasive action by giving helm hard to starboard; however, too late to avoid a collision. The collision caused damage to both ships and to the cargo of JOSEPHINE MÆRSK. In JOSEPHINE MÆRSK a fire in the electrical installations of some refrigerated containers was caused by the collision. No one was injured and there was no pollution of the environment. The report contains information about actions taken by both shipping companies.

Location: ATLANTIC OCEAN 2 MILES EAST OF THE NASSAU SOUND ENTRANCE, JACKSONVILLE, FL, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FISHING VESSEL 'ATLANTIC BREEZE' STRANDED, TOOK WATER AND SUBSEQUENTLY SANK IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 2 MILES EAST OF THE NASSAU SOUND ENTRANCE, JACKSONVILLE, FL, USA AT 0650 HOURS LT ON 05/06/12. WRECK RAISED AND REMOVED IN JULY 2012.

ALL 3 CREW RESCUED BY USCG RESCUE BOAT AND TAKEN TO MAYPORT, FL. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. WRECK RAISED BY MOBRO MARINE USING FLOATING CRANE ON 05/07/12 AND LOADED ONTO BARGE FOR TRANSPORTATION TO SCRAPPING FACILITY.

SOLASStatus: SHOYO MARU: Unknown/unspecified, TENKO MARU NO. 5: Unknown/unspecified
Location: 1 MILE SOUTHWEST OF FUTAGAMI JIMA, MATSUYAMA, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE JAPANESE-FLAGGED PUSHING TUG 'SHOYO MARU' SANK AFTER COLLISION WITH MV 'TENKO MARU NO. 5' IN THE INLAND SEA 1 MILE SOUTHWEST OF FUTAGAMI JIMA, MATSUYAMA, JAPAN IN LAT. 33 55N., LONG. 132 30E., AT 2200 HOURS LT ON 04/06/12.

ALL 7 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFT AND RESCUED BY COASTGUARD VESSELS. NO INJURIES REPORTED. TUG WAS PUSHING A LOADED BARGE AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.

While alongside in Crotone, Italy, M/V MEDUM experienced an explosion in the engine room. During maintenance on the fuel oil system, a disconnected pipe right in front of the fuel oil heater must have saturated the air causing dense smoke that led to an explosion. 
The situation was resolved by local fire fighters and crew efforts.
With the exception of the Chief Engineer who had minor burns, nobody was injured and the vessel was able to continue its voyage after minor repairs.
In the light of the incident's nature, the Antigua and Barbuda Chief Casualty Investigator decided not to investigate further.

On 03 June 2012 at approximately 1130 Pacific Daylight Time, the Royal Canadian Marine Search and Rescue vessel Lewis-McPhee, with 4 crew members on board, capsized during exercises in Sechelt Rapids, British Columbia. Two of the crew members were recovered by another vessel; the remaining 2 crew members were later found dead under the capsized vessel.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: north west coast of the Elba Island
SummaryOfEvents:
The Panama registered container ship MERSA 2 grounded on the north west coast of the Elba Island while on passage from Marina Di Carrara, Italy to Bejaia, Algeria. The grounding was recorded on the 1st June 2012 at 04.50 hours (UTC+2)

1.2	The MERSA 2 was heading South Easterly in the Mediterranean in line with the west coast of Italy without any change of course or speed until heating the coast of Elba Island at position 42º 48´ 27´ N – 010º 08´09´E

1.3	The MERSA 2 was on a voyage between Marina di Carrara (Italy) to Bejaia (Algeria) loaded with two thousand nine hundred and seventy tonnes (2970.16) of steel bars distributed on two cargo holds. Hold no. 1 with 849.91 tonnes and hold no. 2 with 2,121.25 tonnes.
At 04.50 hrs (UTC+2) the vessel suddenly stooped after grounding in the Isola D´Elba
THE SENEGALESE-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'AMA ASABA' REPORTED TO HAVE FOUNDERED IN JUNE 2012.
To m/v " PERSEUS " was damaged on the main reverse reduction gearbox. The crew not possible to repaired the gear and ship mast by towing line to follow to the port of Klaipeda.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: informed that today at approx. 10:45 am I have been advice by the Captain of the Carnival Dream that while the vessel was in Roatan – Honduras, a serious incident occurred where the wire rope of the STBD side Rescue boat # 1 broke while the boat was being hoisted, roughly at the top of the crane, just before entering in the rigging position, however it is not confirm, consequently the rescue boat fall in the water with 4 persons on board. The distance between the water and the rescue boat at the time of the fall was about 8 meters.

On 30 May 2012, at 1000 Newfoundland Daylight Time, the passenger ferry Beaumont Hamel experienced an electrical failure, resulting in loss of propulsion and steering while approaching Portugal Cove, Newfoundland and Labrador, and struck the wharf. The vessel sustained damage to the bow visor, and caused minor damage to the wharf. One minor injury was reported.

SOLASStatus: FURNESS MELBOURNE: SOLAS, Riga II: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 2250, about 18 miles north of Bowen Qld, a collision occurred between the southbound bulk carrier Furness Melbourne and the northbound private yacht Riga II.

The yacht was dismasted and one minor injury was reported.

The ship remained on scene to await further assistance for the yacht and was released to continue its voyage to Portland after a local VMR boat arrived at the location. The yacht was towed to Bowen

Location: 300 nm SW of Dezhnev Cape, on the boundary of Anadyr Bay in Bering Sea
SummaryOfEvents: On 26 May 2012, in the early hours of the morning, the Russian factory trawler KAPITAN BOLSUNOVSKIY sank around 300 nm SW of Dezhnev Cape, on the boundary of Anadyr Bay in Bering Sea.  All 91 crew members were rescued by a passing ship.  The area where the accident happened is free of navigational dangers.  It is presumed that the ship sank either after colliding with another ship or striking an iceberg.

Reported overdue on Thursday 24th May 2012. 0903 MRCC mount search by local vessels in  the vicinity. 1200 Search extended with aerial search observation by scheduled airline. Friday 25th May Aerial search using RAMSI aircraft and surface craft failed to find any trace in Search Area. Saturday 26th May 1700 hrs liferaft located. 1800 hrs four more liferafts tethered together located. Sunday 27th May 0200 hrs Rescue vessel completes picking up survivors. 33 men, 10 women and 6 children. No loss of life and only minor injuries. 1700 hrs All survivors disembarked at Kirakira.

THE GREEK-FLAGGED TUG SANK AFTER COLLISION WITH TUG 'LEON' WHILST MOORED AT KERATSINI, PIREAUS, GREECE AT 1820 HOURS LT ON 23/05/12.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. ANTI POLLUTION BOOM DEPLOYED AS A PRECAUTION. VESSEL HAD BEEN LAID UP UNMANNED FOR 2 YEARS. WRECK REFLOATED ON 19/06/12 AND LAID UP UNREPAIRED.

SOLASStatus: CIUTAT DE BENICARLO: Unknown/unspecified, MSC ELOISE: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
The Panama registered container ship MSC ELOISE was in collision with a Spanish registered fishing boat CIUTAT DE BENICARLÓ at 08.10 hrs LT (UTC + 1) on Wednesday 23rd May 2012.
Neither visual damages nor pollution was observed and only small scratches on the hull coating were seen on the vessel´s parallel body.
The vessel resumed her voyage to Valencia, Spain on the same day at 09,30 hrs LT whilst the fishing boat was moving away back to shore.

THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'CRANZ' STRUCK BUOY AND STRANDED WHILST DEPARTING VIEROW, GERMANY AT 2030 HOURS LT ON 22/05/12. SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP AT GRENAA, DENMARK IN JUNE 2012.

PROPELLER FOULED BY ANCHOR CHAIN ON BUOY. REFLOATED IMMEDIATELY AND TOWED TO BERTH AT VIEROW FOR DIVERS INSPECTION. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. SUBSEQUENTLY ARRIVED AT GRENAA, DENMARK ON 26/05/12 FOR BREAKING UP.

On 19 May 2012, the accommodation area of the Indonesian-flagged bulk carrier, SARASWATI caught fire whilst anchored of Suralaya, Indonesia at 2245 hrs(local time).

The blaze was brought under control within two hours with the assistance of tugs GUNUNG BATUR and GUNUNG CIPALA.  Twenty-seven crew members were rescued and eight were reported missing.  The accommodation sustained serious damage.  The fire continued to burn intermidttently.  The bulk carrier foundered in 35 metres of water due to an ingress of water from the fire fighting operations.  Anti-pollution measures were deployed.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: off the French Island of Mayotte, Indian Ocean
SummaryOfEvents:
On Saturday 19 May 2012, at 17:00 hrs (local time), an unknown fishing vessel sank off the French island of Mayotte, in the Indian Ocean.  The vessel was carrying around 43 people from the Comoros Islands.  Nineteen people were rescued, 5 bodies were recovered and the remaining people are reported as still missing.

The vessel ran into trouble when it tried to pass through a passage, but ran onto the coral reefs that surround Mayotte, causing the boat to flip over several times throwing the motor, fuel and many passenger overboard.

The Overseas Territory Ministry activated a maritime safety plan and the necessary aerial and nautrical means were put in place.  The helicopter and coast guard boat were searching for the other survivors.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
Bulk Carrier MV “Ocean Diamond” on loading copper concentrates in bulk from Chilean ports sailed for China on 05 April 2012.  

She reached on 13 May 2012 at her first discharge port, Qingdao roads and anchored on arrival. On 18May vessel docked and after the port formalities and draft survey, #2 and 4 cargo holds were opened for discharging.  

The cargo supervisor and stevedores boarded the vessel at noon. They were checked at gangway by ship’s crew in compliance to ISPS code. 

Chief Officer advised cargo supervisor about the cargo stowage and associated health hazards of cargo. Cargo in # 2 and 4 hold was for Qingdao port while #1, 3 and 5 for 2nd discharge port, Nantong. 

Cargo discharging from #2 and #4 holds commenced on 18 May afternoon using shore cargo gears and continued till 0600hrs on 19 May 2012. At the end of shift stevedores disembarked the vessel. 

At 0700hrs, stevedores of next shift boarded the vessel and their security check carried out at the gangway. Cargo in #2 hold middle area had reached tank top levels hence labor was deployed for sweeping and collecting cargo to continue discharging.

The ship crew had kept the hatch entrance covers of #1, 3 and 5 closed with wing nuts screwed tight but their lids were not locked.  

At 1000hrs a stevedore reported the duty AB that 3 stevedores were missing and suspected that they might have entered #3 cargo hold. 

Duty AB and Boson with help of stevedores opened #3 CH at1005hrs and saw that 3 stevedores lying unconscious in cargo hold. 

All the 3 victims were taken out from cargo hold and transported to hospital by port ambulance. At the time of shifting 3 labors to ambulance, 2 were unconscious but breathing, unlike of 3rd labor.
The investigation of accident revealed the following: 
•	Lack of supervision by In-charge of Stevedores, their lack of familiarity with ship’s lay out and lack of training in identification of warning sign and posters used on board ships. 

•	Stevedores’ incapability in deciphering instructions in English, not understanding markings on hatch entrance and their inattentive, inobservant and careless approach  while entering cargo hold #3

•	Ship’s crew failure in securing all not – to – be - discharged hatches in that port.

•	Lack of communication and instructions by ship’s crew to stevedore regarding dangerous properties of cargo in absence of thorough ventilation
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
In the morning of 19 May 2012, the Turkish cargo ship EROL SENKAYA, loaded with 2200 tons of olive seeds, capsized and sank between the island of Zakynthos and mainland, Greece.  Of the 10 crewmembers on board; 6 were rescued by the Greece Coast Guard; 1 body was recovered and 3 crew members were still reported missing. Search and Rescue teams, along with five boats and a helicopter are looking for the missing crew members.  
It is not known what caused the accident.  Greek Authorities confirm that weather conditions were fair in the area when the ship went down and suspected that a load of timber that it was carrying shifted in the cargo hold.  No pollution has been reported, however there is some concern that some pollution will be released from the 10 tons of fuel oil still on board.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: Bara Pemdez: Unknown/unspecified, BARA PEMDEZ: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
Le caseyeur BARA PEMDEZ quitte le port de l’île de Houat à l’aube du 18 mai 2012 pour se rendre sur ses lieux de pêche situés à la Pointe du Skeul, au sud-est de Belle-Île.
La mer est très forte, avec un vent de secteur ouest et une houle formée.
Alors qu’il est en train de relever une filière de casiers à crabes et qu’il se trouve travers à la lame, à toucher la côte, une grosse déferlante fait vraisemblablement coucher le navire et projette les deux marins à l’eau.
L’alerte est donnée par la balise.
Les deux corps sans vie seront retrouvés quelques jours plus tard.
Le navire dérive à la côte toute proche où il est rapidement détruit par la mer.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
At 1218 on 17 May 2012, about 600 kilometres NE from Cairns, the bulk carrier ID Integrity suffered a main engine breakdown in the Coral Sea while it was on passage from China to Townsville, Queensland. The crew could not repair the main engine and the ship drifted in a westerly direction towards the Great Barrier Reef.

On 19 May, Australian tugs were despatched to assist the disabled ship as it drifted closer towards the outer edge of the Great Barrier Reef. On 20 May, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority's tug Pacific Responder had ID Integrity under tow with another two tugs  in attendance. The ship was towed to Cairns, where it was anchored at 1400 on 23 May for inspection and repairs.

Location: 9 miles south of Portland Bill England
SummaryOfEvents: At about 10 :00 hrs on May 2012, the 11:64m wooden potting ship Purbeck Isle foundered with the loss of her skipper and his two crewmen moving their whelk pots from their winter grounds in Lyme Bay to their summer grounds in deeper water south of Portland Bill. Purbeck  Isle went down so suddenly that the skipper and his crew were unable to raise the alarm, collect their lifejackets or manually release and inflate the ship’s liferaft. Due to the environmental conditions it is likely that all three fishermen had perished by the time the coastguard was informed that Purbeck isle was overdue.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: During mooring procedure a line broke and hit two of the shore workers on duty.  As a result one was injured and the other died.  Room for escape was inadequate and lighting was insufficient.

SOLASStatus: GREAT WEALTH: SOLAS, Zhe Xiang Yu 27009: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 0430Hours 13th May 2012, the Hong Kong registered bulker carrier collided with a Chinese fishing vessel "Zhe Xiang Yu 27009", one fishingman overbaorded and missed, both vessel sustained minor damage.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: SANKO ELEGANCE: SOLAS, SUMBER KENCANA XI: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: During heavy heavy wind and rain conditions (the wind at the time of the incident were blowing between 45-50 knots), Liberian flagged vessel, SANKO ELEGANCE, was involved in a collision incident with a local barge, SUMBER KENCANA. The said weather conditions had come quite suddenly and the engine room crew members were instructed to start up all engines and thrusters as the vessel's anchor had begun to drag. The crew members managed to regain control of the vessel, but not before colliding with local oil barge SUMBER KENCANA XI. Vessel incurred considerable damage, however, there were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported

Location: 60 NAUTICAL MILES NORTH OF SAN JUAN PUERTO RICO
SummaryOfEvents: while on voyage between Cristobal – Barcelona, in position 19 27.22N / 066 04.25W on 11th May 2055 UTC, subject vessel experienced explosion in No.5 Fuel Oil Tank (starboard) leading to flooding of No.5 Fuel Oil Tank (starboard) & No.5 Cargo Hold

Location: Gulf of Mexico, 18 miles southwest of Marsh Island, LA, United States of America
SummaryOfEvents:
On 10 May 2012, the fishing vessel, LUCKY DIAMOND, registered by the United States of America caught fire and foundered in the Gulf of Mexico, 18 miles southwest of Marsh Island, LA, the United States of America at 1040 hrs (local time).

One crew member was injured and rescued and three other members were reported missing.  Sheen of oil was observed on the water.  USCG vessels attended the scene.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: LUSITANIA G: Unknown/unspecified, UBC LAGUNA: SOLAS
Location: River Plate, Argentina near Recalada pilot station
SummaryOfEvents: While under pilotage UBC LAGUNA, the Officer on Watch informed the Master of oncoming vessel, Italian flagged vessel, LUSITANIA G. The pilot began communicating with LUSITANIA G crew members in their own language. As LUSITANIA G drew closer, the Master of UBC LAGUNA maneuvered the vessel to avoid what appeared to be the imminent risk of a collision. Although the course alteration averted the collision, the vessel ran aground and was immobile for over two hours after being stranded. There were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

On 09 May 2012 at approximately 2030 Pacific Daylight Time, the small fishing vessel Pacific Siren, loaded with prawn gear, heeled to starboard and capsized off Banks Island, British Columbia. All 3 crew members abandoned the vessel into a small inflatable boat and were stranded at Terror Point on Banks Island for 9 days until they were rescued by the Canadian Coast Guard.

On May 8, 2012, while the vessel was docked at the Port of Bremerhaven, Germany, the vessel was undergoing hot work by the vessel's crew members and the local shipyard workers. At approximately 09:26 (LT) a fire outbreak (but no explosion) was reportedly observed in the vessel's pump room. The local fire brigade was notified and aided in the fire extinguishing effort on the part of the crew members, but a total of 11 individuals, including 2 crew members were injured as a result of the incident. The investigation continues, but there are no reports of any incidents of pollution.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On 06 May 2012, at about 0800 hours, the Deck Cadet  was found missing onboard the Bulk Carrier MV “OCEAN LORD”. The Master mustered his men and a thorough search onboard the vessel for the missing Cadet was carried out. However, the Cadet was nowhere to be located

SOLASStatus: LOAMAR SEGUNDO: Unknown/unspecified, LOAMAR SEGUNDO: Unknown/unspecified
Location: ATLANTIC OCEAN WEST OF CAPE VERDE ISLANDS
SummaryOfEvents:
THE SPANISH-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'LOAMAR SEGUNDO' SANK AFTER DEVELOPING LIST IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN WEST OF CAPE VERDE ISLANDS IN APPROXIMATE LAT. 16 50N., LONG. 026 28W., ON 06/05/12.

MRCC SPAIN RECEIVED DISTRESS SIGNAL AT 1009 HOURS LT ON 06/05/12 AND DIRECTED NEARBY MT 'NAVIG8 LOUCAS' TO THE SCENE. 11 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO 2 LIFE RAFTS AND WERE RESCUED BY 'NAVIG8 LOUCAS'. NO INJURIES REPORTED. CAUSE OF SINKING UNKNOWN.
DURING BOORING PROCEDURE A LINE BROKE AND HIT TWO OF THE SHOREWORKERS ON DUTY.  aS A RESULT ONE WAS INJURED AND THE OTHER DIED.

On May 5, 2012 at approximately 06:10 (LT), the vessel sustained a fire outbreak in its cargo hold. After the Master was alerted and the fire alarm had been activated. The vessel, at the time was underway from Port Klang, Malaysia to Nhava Shiva, India. However, because of the fire outbreak, the vessel altered course to Mangalore, India. Over the course of the altered transit to Mangalore and upon arrival, the crew members managed contain the fire using the CO2 emergency sprinklers. The next day, the P&I club representative and the crew members inspected the area and found that there was no smog, the fire had been extinguished, and the cargo hold had been properly cooled down from the fire. The cargo hold and immediate areas surrounding were affected by the fire, however, there was no structural damage to vessel. There were no reports of injuries or incidients of pollution.

MV “Jindal Tarini” year 2005 China built general cargo vessel, after discharging her last cargo of timber sailed from Kolkota, on 17April 2012 and arrived at Tuticorin port anchorage, India on 24 April. 
On 29 April she docked port side at berth #1 to load cargo i.e. salt bags for Indonesia. 
The vessel has 2 hatches with 8 panels and fitted with 2 sets of derricks each. 
On 04 May at 11:45hrs, the vessel commenced loading salt bags in #2cargo hold. By 5th morning 592mt of cargo was loaded in the same and draft recorded was 1.50m forward and 4.90m aft. 
On 05 May, Second Officer was OOW in port from midnight till morning 06:00hrs. By this hrs #1hatch was to be opened for cargo loading as the stevedores were to resume work at 06:00hrs. 
At 05:30hrs, Second Officer gave wake up call to Chief Officer, Boson and AB. 10 minutes later, Chief Officer along with Second Officer, Boson and two ABs, started rigging up derrick #1 for opening hatch #1 manually because of its non-functional hydraulic motor. Post necessary hatch panels arrangements and checks for manual operation on hatch panels, the crew were to come down to monitor safe opening of hatch cover. Chief Officer and an AB were to be on starboard side and 2nd Officer with another AB on port side. All crew members came down and took their positions on main deck but the AB  stood on #1 derrick crutch post bracket attached to hatch track way on port side. 
Boson pulled the pull wire using derrick #1 and the hatch panels began to open. The AB  standing on derrick parking boom bracket lost his balance and fell on #1 panel. Before he could stand and jump on main deck he got trapped between 1st and 2nd panel on parking track way (stowage bay). 
When 2nd Officer and Bosun saw the AB between the panels, the opening operation was stopped. The wire was then rigged to close hatch cover by pulling # 1 panel to rescue the victim. He was then drawn out and laid on a stretcher. Incidentally the Port ambulance was in the vicinity and its driver on seeing the commotion of accident parked the vehicle near to ship’s gangway. The casualty was immediately transported to port hospital by the ambulance where he was declared dead. 
The report concludes that during hatch cover opening operation the inappropriate positioning of AB on the derrick boom crutch post bracket at a very close distance to hatch track and his momentary loss of concentration were the main cause of the accident.

On 04 May 2012 at approximately 1730 Pacific Daylight Time, the small fishing vessel Jessie G, loaded with prawn gear, rolled to starboard while rounding Cape Beale, British Columbia and was unable to recover. All 6 crew members on board were rescued by the Canadian Coast Guard fast rescue craft Bamfield 1. The Jessie G subsequently grounded and was later salvaged and towed to Port Alberni, where it was declared a constructive total loss.

InitialEvent: Crewmember fell through open manhole cover
SummaryOfEvents: Crewmember seriously injured after falling through open manhole cover into void space.  Died of from injurys.

On the evening   of 3 May 2012, the German-flagged  ferry Nils Holgersson sailed into the port of Travemunde, where she was to make fast with   her stern at pier 6a of the Skandinavienkai. The turning manoeuvre in the Siechenbucht (turning basin) necessary for this failed because the two pod propulsors were still being operated in “Sea mode”. Because only one hydraulic pump was activated per propulsor, instead of two. The ship’s command was unable to stop in the turning basin and the ferry headed towards the opposite pier at a speed over ground of 6.51 kts. The Danish ferry URD, whose crew was occupied with making proparations for the scheduled voyage to Liepaja, was made fast there at pier. Most of the passengers and the cargo were already on board. 
The collision occurred at 18:14 hrs. The port side of the URD was pressed in by the bow of the Nils Holgersson, causing the URD to take on water and heel to port. It was possible to stabilise the ship by flooding the forward ballast water tanks, which enabled the evacuation of people and much of the cargo via stern ramp.
The Nils Holgersson was able to move to her berth under her own power after the controls were switched to harbour mode.
Nobody came to physical harm and the environment was not damaged due to the collision.

InitialEvent: CASUALTY NOT NAMED ABOVE DEATH OF CREWMEMBER
SummaryOfEvents:
At the time of the incident the “M.V. CARNIVAL CONQUEST” had on board a compliment of 1147 mixed nationality crew members, including the Master who was an Italian Nationality. The Vessel was on a routine cruise voyage from New Orleans, calling Cozumel in Mexico, and was to proceed to Grand Cayman.
At Cozumel the vessel was upright, drawing 8.37 meters forward, 8.32 meters Aft, Sea water density being 1.025 gms/cc. GMo 2.45. The vessel had on board Diesel Oil 112.00 M/Ts, Heavy Fuel Oil 2430.60 M/Ts, Water ballast 2693.40 M/Ts, Fresh Water 4626.20 M/Ts along with 3188 passengers most of whom had gone ashore for sight seeing.
The weather condition prior to the time of the incident, i.e. in the port of Cozumel, was partly cloudy and clear with gentle to moderate breeze, wind force 3 on the beaufort wind force scale (i.e. wind speed about 7-10 knots), calm seas with no swell, good visibility, barometer pressure 1010mb, air temperature 28º C (i.e.82.5º F) and humidy being 65%.
As a consequence of the casualty, the Buffet Garde Manager was found dead in the pit of the “G”” elevator, on zero deck.
There was no damage to the vessel, the water tight integrity of the vessels was intact and not jeopardized, there was no pollution as a result of this incident nor any damage to any property reported.
Soon after the accident the Master informed the local authorities via the local agent, Panama Maritime Authority, and there after he called the designated persona shore (DPA) and updated him of the incident.

Location: Baltic Sea, South of the Island of Fehmarn
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 10:24 hrs on 30 April 2011, Bremen Rescue Radio was notified by VHF radio that a person on the German sailing yacht Special One had fallen overboard. The accident occurred en route from Burgtiefe, Fehmarn during a training voyage to the Danish port of Bagenkop (Langeland).

The accident happened at the beginning of the voyage. At the time of the accident, the sailing yacht was located close to the shoreline some 2 nm south of the port of Burgstaaken (Fehmarn).

Problems were experienced with the mainsail due to inattentiveness during a turning manoeuvre. The main sheet had run out to the mast; the skipper then went on the starboard side and the assistant skipper on the port side forward to the mast to clear the ends of the mainsheet. 

While making his way back from the bow, the assistant skipper fell overboard; however, he was still holding onto one end of the sheet and therefore did not lose contact with the sailing yacht. Two or three other sailors were able to keep the man-overboard at the side of the ship at about amidships by holding onto his hands and the inflated lifejacket. In an attempt to pull him back on board, the lifejacket was pulled upward over the head of the man in the water. When the attempt to haul the casualty on deck amidships failed, he was pulled to the stern, where they tried in vain to assemble a folding bathing ladder, which was not fixed to the hull. The skipper secured himself to the backstay with a safety line/lifebelt and tried to recover the casualty by reaching for his hands from the improperly mounted ladder. One of the ladder joints broke during this recovery attempt, and the skipper fell overboard, too. Hauling him back on deck proved difficult. During this recovery attempts the casualty drifted away and in spite of the Special One executing several manoeuvres, it was no possible to re-establish contact with the lifeless person floating in the water.

After the skipper was back on deck, he went below deck, transmitted a distress alert and then used the VHF radio for the distress communications.

The fishing trawler Tümmler was near the scene of the accident and became aware of the emergency at 10:27 hrs due to the radio traffic. Her crew managed to establish a line connection with the lifeless person floating in the water. However, the crew of the fishing trawler did not manage to recover and lift the body on deck, either. The person was only recovered with considerable difficulty at about 10:53 by the crew of the inflatable dinghy belonging to the Fehmarn police boat and then taken to the port of Burgstaaken on Felmarn. The casualty was pronounced dead by the summoned emergency doctor at the port.

An unknown boat, en route from Dhubri to Fakirganj, India capsized, broke in two and sank in the Brahmaputra River on Monday 30 April 2012.  The boat was carrying 350 people, despite having an operating capacity of 225.  One Hundred and five bodies were recovered, an estimated 150 people were rescued and 100 are reported still missing.  Weather conditions were particularly fierce with strong winds and pre-monsoon rain.

Divers and disaster rescue soldiers worked through the night to pull bodies from the Brahmaputra River.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: ARABIAN GULF 30 MILES NORTHEAST OF RAS LAFFAN, QATAR
SummaryOfEvents:
THE QATARI-FLAGGED TUG 'AL DEEBEL' CAUGHT FIRE AFTER EXPLOSION IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE ARABIAN GULF 30 MILES NORTHEAST OF RAS LAFFAN, QATAR IN LAT. 26 01N., LONG. 052 04E., AT 1700 HOURS LT ON 29/04/12.

6 CREW AND 1 MAINTENANCE WORKER DEAD. 4 CREW INJURED. 12 RESCUE VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED AND INJURED CREW TAKEN TO HOSPITAL IN RAS LAFFAN. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO PORT FOR INSPECTION. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN.

On 25 April 2012, the 36-ft fishing trawler SEA BIRD, carrying 1,0000 litres of diesel sank one-and-half miles from Langstone Harbour, off the Hampshire coast.  The skipper and his crewman were rescued by a Portsmouth RNLI Lifeboat, after sending a Mayday call to Solent Coastguard.

The fishing vessel NEW FRANCISCO JAVIER left the port of Nouadhibou on 23/04/2012 early in the morning.She was a licensed fishing boat which operated normally anchored against the current with pots and lines. On 24/11, after holding several other positions of anchorage, the vessel anchored about 15 miles off SSW Buoy landfall of Nouadhibou, within the contour of 40 meters (l = 20 36 '16 N and L = 017 14' 64 W ). At 12:46 hours the skipper decided to change the position. During heaving up the anchor he engaged the motor some bits ahead just to help the maneuver with the intention of releasing the tension of the anchor line and let ease the rope. The headway proved to be excessive, as the vessel followed her way and the rope entangled with the propeller, due to which the propeller was blocked, shutting down the main engine. When propulsion ran out , the ship kept stern to the current. No crew went down to the engine room to check for any major breakdown. The skipper went to the bridge to contact the hospital ship (B / H) ESPERANZA DEL MAR and request help, when he observed through the access hatch to the engine room that it was flooded. The skipper decided to leave the ship communicating it to B / H ESPERANZA DEL MAR and sending a distress call to the ships in the area by VHF on channel 16. The eight crew members of the B / P NEW FRANCISCO JAVIER jumped from ship into liferafts being rescued later by two Polish flag factory vessels and moved to the vicinity of the bay of Cabo Blanco, where authorities collected to land them in Puerto Artesano. The B / P NEW FRANCISCO JAVIER was afloat broadcasting its position automatically through the "blue box" until the day April 26, 2012 at 02:51 hours, being in the position l = 20 02 ', 96 N, L = 017 26 ', 68 W, 35 miles to 198 from the point where the accident occurred. On June 30, 2012, after more than two months after the accident, the tanker Marshall Islands flag B / T CAPE BANTRY informed services Maritime Rescue and Canary Navarea coordinator II, in France, the sighting of a boat adrift at 11:10 am in position l = 10 17 ', 7 N, L = 033 00', 6 W, later it was confirmed that she was the B / P NEW FRANCISCO JAVIER. The vessel was in apparent relative good condition. (See the Figure 2 in the attached Report). No Recommendations were rised because most of issues were a matter of law enforcement and such items are out of the scope of the Directive.

On 23 April 2012, the 20-m Plymouth (United Kingdom)-flagged tug AQUARIUS sank in heavy seas off France, leaving one man missing feared dead.  Ten minutes after the distress call was made the tug sank; two of the three crewmembers managed to get into a life raft while the third crewmember was reported to have disappeared.

Location: Offshore northwest coast of the United States
SummaryOfEvents: Bosun fell overboard while stowing the pilot ladder after the pilot was disembarked.  The crewmember was not found during SAR operations.

On 20 April 2012 at 07:40 am, the fishing vessel JAMES COLLINS was proceeding home to Porturlin, engine revs about 1.700 rpm, 3/4 of full speed.  The bilge alarm sounded and after pumping out the bilge it sounded again shortly afterwards.  The skipper went into the fish hold and lifted the covering boards over the bilge containing the pump and the propeller shaft.  The engine was not stopped or put into neutral and the shaft was turning.  In order to clear the debris, the skipper put his foot beside the turning shaft, at which point the skipper's waterproof leggings got caught by the coupling on the shaft and his left leg was wound around the shaft about two times.  The engine was quickly stoped.  
A mayday call was sent out at 07:59 and the crew proceeded to extract the skipper's leg from the shaft.  At 08:24, the lifeboat crew from Ballyglass arrived and rendered medical assistance.  The skipper was airlifted to Sligo General hospital.  The leg did not require amputation and is reported to that the skipper's leg will recover with full function and movement.

Dry cargo ship Amstelborg at berth in  Borusan Port of Turkey,   on Wednesday's strong SW winds, broke lines and hit the quay, ended with a hole in the hull. The vessel struck the dock at the pier and  tear occurred along the shell  approximately 2 meters in length. An estimated 25-30 tons of fuel from 155 tons total on board, leaked to the harbor, causing an environmental disaster. 
Continued fuel leakage from the ship turned around, barriers are established.

Location: NEAR GUISHAN ANCHORAGE, DONG GUAR CHINA
SummaryOfEvents:
Chemical Tanker, M.V. “Namhae Pioneer II”, set her sails on 15 April 2012 from Campha, Vietnam to Dong Guan port in Guonzhao province of South China. She had 13 crewmembers on board. She was due to arrive at her destination on 20 April 2012.
On the day of arrival at fairway of Dong Guan port in the morning hours on 18 April 2012, the bridge was manned by Chief Officer along with duty AB. and the engine room by Second Engineer with a rating. Vessel had reported her ETA, pilot boarding ground around 0800hrs on 18 April 2012 for her transit through ZHUJIANG KOU channel and subsequent berthing in Dong Guan port for discharging her cargo.
The OOW was preparing vessel for arrival port. The assistant third officer was to be called for his stations on bridge for arrival port. It was 0520hours near Guishan anchorage when duty AB went to give call to assistant third office for reporting on bridge. At this time the vessel was in position of Latitude 21º53.1´N Longitude 113º50.0´E. The duty AB found the cabin of assistant third office locked and no response from inside his cabin. The duplicate key of cabin from chief officer was used to open his cabin but assistant third office was not in cabin. Duty AB looked around for him inside and around accommodation but could not find. This was informed to bridge also Master was informed accordingly.
Master then took over command on bridge and raised the emergency alarm. The crew was mustered and asked to search the entire vessel for the missing assistant third office. At the same time company was informed of the incident. The vessel continued on her passage to receive pilot, however, search on board for missing crew continued. Search was proceeding until vessel was alongside at Hai Teng berth of Dong Guan port at 1300hrs on 18 April 2012.
As the crew was not found after the extensive search on board, it was assumed that he was missing and the matter was reported to shore authorities to conduct search & rescue at sea for the missing crew.

Location: 70 nautical miles off the coast of Thanh Hoa province
SummaryOfEvents:
The Vietnamese-cargo ship DUY PHUONG 68, transporting 2,400 tons of rice from An Giang province in the Mekong Delta to Hai Phong collided with cargo ship QUANG ANH 54, which was carrying 900 tons of cement, about 70 nautical miles off the coast of Thanh Hoa province, on 17 April 2012 at 03:30 am (local time).

The DUY PHUONG 68 sunk immediately after the collision, while the QUANG ANH suffered a hole in its stern.  The 12 sailors aboard DUY PHUONG were taken to QUANG ANH and successfully managed to arrive at the Nghi Son Port in Thanh Hoae in the afternoon of the same day.

The incident is being attributed to bad weather and poor visibility and pending further investigation.

SOLASStatus: SHINYO-MARU No.2: Unknown/unspecified, YONG CAI: SOLAS
Location: About 3.5 km NNE off from Rokkosaki lighthouse, Ishikawa Pref., Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
Both ships came into collision in the waters off Noto Peninsulam, Ishikawa Pref., Japan.
Subsequently the fishing vessel capsized leaving the skipper of SHINYO-MARU No.2 dead and the other crew missing.

On 26 April 2012, NICOLAI MAERSK arrived at Jebel Ali, Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Shortly after arrival at 1515 hours the ship began loading and unloading containers.

During the stay in Jebel Ali, the ship was to receive lubricating oil both in bulk and in drums. The drums were to be hoisted on board by means of the aft stores crane. The lubricating oil in bulk was to arrive by truck and be pumped on board at the bunker station on the upper deck close to the gangway.

In order to receive the oil, preparations were made to hoist on board the bunkering hose for lubri-cating oil. The intention was to use the fuel oil hose and Suez boat handling davit for hoisting the hose for the lubricating oil. While preparing the crane, the 2nd engineer for some reason mounted the emergency operation crank fitted on a shaft that is directly connected to the electric motor powering the crane.

When mounting the emergency operation crank, he activated the lowering function on the remote control switch box whereby the crank started rotating at very high revolutions. The crank was hurled off and hit the engineer causing fatal injuries.

WHERE ONE CREW MEMBER DIED DURING THE BERTHING OPERATION MANOEUVRING ROPE, AT PORT OF LE HAVRE, FRANCE, ON APRIL 15TH
During routine tank cleaning, an O/S entered a cargo tank containing an oxygen deficient atmosphere.

Location: NORTH SEA 13 MILES WEST OF KRISTIANSUND, NORWAY
SummaryOfEvents:
THE NORWEGIAN-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'RAMNFJORD' STRANDED ON ROCKS AND DEVELOPED LIST TO PORT IN THE NORTH SEA 13 MILES WEST OF KRISTIANSUND, NORWAY IN LAT. 63 06N., LONG. 007 17E., EARLY AM ON 12/04/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER. REFLOATED AND TOWED TO STOKKSUND, NORWAY FOR DEMOLITION.

SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER IN STARBOARD BUNKER FUEL TANK AND ENGINE ROOM. ALL 7 CREW ABANDONED SHIP AND WERE RESCUED BY MV 'ACERGY VIKING' AND A RESCUE HELICOPTER. NO INJURIES REPORTED. APPROXIMATELY 20 TONS OF OIL LEAKED INTO THE SEA. SALVAGE CONTRACT AWARDED TO BUKSER OG BERGING. REMAINING FUEL REMOVED USING TUG 'BB OCEAN'. REFLOATED WITH ASSISTANCE FROM FLOATING CRANE ON 28/08/12 AND TOWED TO AVEROYA.

s per information received from Lloyd's sub-agents Taranto, fully cellular containership East Castle (8328 gt, built 1983), from La Spezia, which arrived at Taranto on Apr 8 for loading steel coil, has spilled about 20 tonnes of heavy fuel. At the present time, no damage has been reported to the vessel. Clean-up operations are underway under the supervision of Taranto harbour-master. Presently, it is confirmed the pollution is confined into an area of about 800 square metres

A fire started in the engine room while the fishing vessel was underway. The fire alarm did not operate and the crew escaped from the accomodation on to deck. THe EPIRB was manually operated and the crew deployed and entered a liferaft. THey were rescued by rescue helicopter. The vessel was lost.

Tthe fishing vessel MAR DE DIOS run aground after losing power and was lost. Both crew members wererescued from the seaby another fishing vessel, AXEXO PRIMERO, a few minutes after the accident without injuries.

On April 7, 2012 the fishing vessel BASIBINA was fishing about 10 miles away from the Palams port. Around 13:00 the master detected a leakage in the engine room and started one bilge pump. A few minutes later the master noticed that flooding was increasing and that he needed to evacuate the crew as soon as posible. The master sailed towards the closer vessel, the fishing vessel GERMAN GRAS that was only 4 miles far away. Before getting to the fishing vessel GERMAN GRAS, the water inflow to the BASIBINA's engine room stopped the engine. The crew decided to launch the liferaft to the sea and go onboard, while the fishing vessel GERMAN GRAS went closer and rescued them.

While throwing the fish nets from the fishing vessel NGEL PADRE, one crew man's leg got tangled up into the net and the man was dragged into the sea. Two sailormen tried to help the man, but finally was rescued by another fishing vessel, SIEMPRE TECO, that was close to them. The man was taken to the hospital in Bilbao were was found to have the two legs broken.

SOLASStatus: KRAIRATCH DIGNITY: Unknown/unspecified, TRUONG HAI STAR: Unknown/unspecified
Location: GANH RAI BAY OFF VUNG TAU, VIETNAM
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VIETNAMESE-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'TRUONG HAI STAR' SANK AFTER COLLISION WITH MV 'KRAIRATCH DIGNITY' IN GANH RAI BAY OFF VUNG TAU, VIETNAM IN LAT. 10 21N., LONG. 010 03E., AT 2330 HOURS LT ON 09/04/12 WHILST UNDER PILOTAGE.

ALL 16 CREW RESCUED BY LOCAL VESSELS. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SOME OIL POLLUTION REPORTED IN SEA. SOME OF THE CARGO OF 66 CONTAINERS FELL INTO SEA AND DRIFTED. 13 CONTAINERS RECOVERED BY RESCUE SERVICES.

Location: West Thurrock Thames, Vopak Terminal Berth No. 1
SummaryOfEvents: Marshall Islands flagged vessel, SUMMER, came into contact with Liberian flagged tanker, POLITSA LADY after the latter vessel had completed discharging all of its cargo. While SUMMER was unberthing and preparing for departure, SUMMER came in contact with POLITSA LADY, damaging the No. 5 starboard ballast tank.

ShipsInvolved: JOSCO LILY (IMO 9342671), Lu Rong Yu Shui 285 (-)
SOLASStatus: JOSCO LILY: SOLAS, Lu Rong Yu Shui 285: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 1739hours 9th April 2012, Hong Kong, China registered cargo vessel "Josco Lily" collided with Chinese fishing vessel "Lu Rong Yu Shui 285" at position 36°11.3'N, 124°14.6''. One fishingman overboarded and missed.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

ShipsInvolved: Lady Ozge (IMO 9499553), LADY OZGE (IMO 9499553), PERE MILO (-), Pre Milo (-)
SOLASStatus: Lady Ozge: Unknown/unspecified, LADY OZGE: Unknown/unspecified, PERE MILO: Unknown/unspecified, Pre Milo: Unknown/unspecified
Location: WEST OF BELLE ISLAND - BAY OF BİSCAY
SummaryOfEvents:
Collision between tanker “Lady Ozge” and trawler “Pere Milo”
 
The ship accident happened in the Bay of Biscay close to Belle-Ile, France. Chemical tanker “Lady Ozge” collided with the small 12 meter trawler “Pere Milo”, and the small vessel quickly sank. The trawler had a crew of two people, one of them was rescued by “Lady Ozge” and later airlifted by a helicopter to the a hospital with mild hypothermia. The search for the other member of the crew is still continuing. There were no information for any damages to the tanker. “Lady Ozge” was on route from Saint Nazaire to Dunkirk, with a cargo of sunflower oil. Currently the tanker proceeded to Lorient.

ShipsInvolved: CAPE R (IMO 9005417), EUROCARGO SALERNO (IMO 9175494), JOLLY INDACO (-)
SOLASStatus: CAPE R: SOLAS, EUROCARGO SALERNO: Unknown/unspecified, JOLLY INDACO: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Messina Terminal of the Port of Genova
SummaryOfEvents: At approximately 08:20 and 08:40, two vessels, JOLLY INDACO and EUROCARGO SALERNO respectively, came into contact with what was then Liberian flagged vessel, CAPE RACE, causing damage to CAPE RACE's aft starboard quarter corner of her bulwark.
During the houling of the fishing gear, one of the fisherman, that were attending the heave up of the net fell down to the water.He could not be rescued.

On April 4, 2012 at approximately 22:20 (LT), while MATRIX I was at anchorage in position Lat: 06, 19.9N ; Long: 003, 26.4E, approximately 2.5 nm SE from fairway buoy, a service and supply, M/V SOA collided into MATRIX I seemingly at full speed causing the considerable damage to MATRIX I's starboard hull and the starboard ballast tank no. 2. There were no injures or incidents of pollution reported.

Location: Pacific Ocean off teh Galapagos Islands, Ecuador
SummaryOfEvents:
On 4 April 2012, the Ecuadorian-registered fishing vessel TUNA I foundered in heavy weather in the Pacific Ocean, off the Galapagos Islands, Ecuador.

Two crew members died, three were reported missing and 14 were rescued.  The rescued crew were taken to hospital in Manta, Ecuador and were treated for serious sunburn.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 4 April 2012, the Bolivian-flagged Ro-Ro cargo ship SEA FLOWER, carrying used vehicles and other goods broke out in a fire in Miragoâne, Haiti.
