One person was killed and another injured.  Firefighters arrived at the scene 1 hour after the incident.  The cargo of used vehicles and other goodes was damaged

At 20:08 on 3 April 2012, the cargo ship Carrier ran aground on the coast of North Wales. The ship had been loading limestone at Raynes Jetty (attached to Raynes Quarry at Llanddulas) when the weather deteriorated rapidly. The master decided to finis loading and put to sea; however, strong winds and large waves overwhelmed the ship while it was manoeuvring away from the jetty, causing it to be driven onto the shore.
Carrier suffered substantial damage and was declared a total constructive loss. Approximately 33000 litres of gas oil was spilled into the sea. Some delays were caused to the shore-based rescued operation, due to a lack of serviceable search and rescue helicopters, but ultimately the crew were rescued from the stricken ship without injury.

Location: East China Sea, West off Amami Oshima.
SummaryOfEvents: At about 0804Hours 3rd April 2012, Hong Kong, China registered vessel "new Lucky VII" capsized and sank at the area west off Amami Oshima due to heavy swell.  total six crew missed, and 11 crew members were rescued.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Vessel hit the shore crane during berthing maneuver. The crane toppled down and one dock worker who stands on quay was injured slightly. Light material damaged occured to the ship and not reported any environmental pollution.

The vessel berthed in the port of Hamburg in order to discharge project cargo which was lashed on deck. Below deck, a charge of cellulose in packages was stowed. After discharging the project cargo, a local company started to flame cut the left over parts of the already removed stoppers that should secure the cargo. The company was authorized by the port of Hamburg to conduct hot works, so the burning off commenced. 
After some steel residues were burnt off, the vessel had to shift astern by a couple of hundred meters to free the berth for another vessel. The hot work conducting group decided to use this time to make a break at their vehicle on the pier. 
On arrival the new position, the company’s superintendent noticed smoke developing at the cargo hold ventilation exhausts. After informing the captain, he detected the smoke source in a hold. The ventilation flaps of the cargo hold were closed by the crew, so that CO2 could be released into the hold.
While the crew was delegated to different measures including the cooling of the hatch covers in the affected area, the fire brigade arrived on the pier and from sea side.
After two hours, a hatch was opened and the smouldering area could be identified. Fire fighters entered with hand held fire extinguishers to keep the reigniting under control. After cooling with foam from the top, it was possible to use a shore crane for emergency discharge. The cellulose packages were finally drenched on the pier and extinguished.
In the light of the incident's nature, the Antigua and Barbuda Chief Casualty Investigator decided not to investigate further.

ShipsInvolved: Basilisk (Pleasure Craft, Port of Singapore) (-), CREST TITAN 2 (IMO 9558830)
SOLASStatus: Basilisk (Pleasure Craft, Port of Singapore): Unknown/unspecified, CREST TITAN 2: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
COLLISION BETWEEN THE SRS MV CREST TITAN 2 (IMO NO. 9558830) AND PLEASURE CRAFT (PORT OF SINGAPORE) BASILISK (SZ11641F), SUNGEI JURONG, SINGAPORE, 31 MARCH 2012 AT ABOUT 0927HRS
On the morning of 31 March 2012, a collision took place inside Sungei Jurong between the piloted Crest Titan 2 (LoA 49.6m) and pleasure craft Basilisk (SZ11641F_LoA 13.5m). The collision occurred in good visibility and the weather was fine.
The collision caused 4 passengers from Basilisk to fall overboard. Three of them were rescued within minutes while the body of the fourth was found the next day. Of the three rescued, one was pronounced dead on the scene. The other two were warded and subsequently discharged without any serious injuries.
Investigations revealed that the main cause was the lack of proper look-outs on both vessels. Crest Titan 2 was unaware of Basilisk or of the collision until advised by MPA. This could be due to the relatively smaller Basilisk approaching Crest Titan 2 from the blind sector inherent in the bridge design (Crest Titan 2). The Class C (entry-level) harbour pilot was concentrating on an inbound vessel in the East Jurong Channel and too was unaware of Basilisk.
Basilisk was unaware of Crest Titan 2 until moments before the collision. Despite hard helm and increase speed, it was to no avail as Crest Titan 2 collided into the port quarter of Basilisk. Both vessels were on converging courses and making more than 5 knots (exceeded the speed limit_river)  when the collision occurred.
It appeared that the steersman of Basilisk displayed the human error of lack of situational awareness while the Master of Crest Titan 2 displayed both lack of situational awareness and incorrect identification .

Location: 74nm SE off Tubbataha Reef, Sulu Sea, Philippines
SummaryOfEvents: On 30 March 2012, late in the night, the passenger ship AZAMARA QUEST, with more than 1,000 people (590 passengers and 411 crew members) aboard was stranded off the southern Philippines, after a fire broke out in one of its engine rooms.  The ship restored propulsion the following night and safely reached the harbour of Sandakan city in Malaysia's eastern state of Sabah on Borneo Island on Sunday 1 April 2012.  One crew member was seriously injured and 5 suffered smoke inhalation.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: 3/E Chang Shao Fei joined vessel Excellent Pescadores on 27 Mar. 2012 whilst the ship was in transit Panama Canal. On 29 Mar. 2012 whilst the ship was proceeding for Longview U.S.A. in Caribbean Sea, at 20:00 hrs LT, 3/E did not appear to relieve l/E from the watch duty, searching ship for the missing engineer was then started, after two hours of a futile searching of the ship was passed, Captain repolted the man missing to company, 23;00 company instructed the master making a U-turn from course 298 to 118 degree to backtrack the sea to conduct a mission of searching for the missing 3/E. Company also iJúormed MRCC ofCOSTA RICA about the missing crew and requested help to search and rescue the missing crew. on 31 Mar, 2012 at 00:00 h1's, ship master announce the failure of the searching and reported company to agree an end of the searching mission. Master ofthe ship had contacted MRCC, COSTA RICA and been told that they had sent ship out to the place the 3/E was assumed probably missing from the ship, but still alJ the efforts seem without reward.
At 10:20 hrs on 29 March 2012, two crewmen fell 22m into the water from Saga Sapphire's No 5 lifeboat while the ship was secured port side alongside in Southampton. They sustained minor injuries

Location: The Railway Bridge over the Limfjord between Aalborg and
SummaryOfEvents:
The cargo ship RAMONA sailed into the Railway Bridge on 28 March 2012 at 2226 hours. There
were no injuries, but very serious material damage to the bridge and minor damage to the ship.
It had been agreed between the ship and the bridge keeper that passage could take place at 2226
hours. The time matched the train traffic across the bridge and the ship's speed was adjusted accordingly.
The bridge keeper’s disposition of the timing up to the passage at 2226 hours was based on specific
attention to a train crossing the Railway Bridge and his experience and routine with the typical
timing in connection with bascule openings and ship passages. This led to a very narrow time margin
from the train crossing the Railway Bridge to the immediately subsequent opening process for
the vessel's intended passage through the bridge.
The ship sailed faster than predicted by the bridge keeper and arrived at the Railway Bridge earlier
than the bascule could be opened. When the bridge keeper noticed this and informed the ship that
it had to stop, the ship was too close to the bridge to do so.
The light signals on the Railway Bridge had no effect on the master's dispositions and manoeuvres
as they were not turned on while there was still time and room to manoeuvre. Therefore the master
decided to adhere to the verbal agreement on the time of passage.

The vessel was grounded near to port entry during berthing maneuver. No injury or environmental pollution occured. Underwater survey was carried out and no any serious damage observed. Ship's cargo was discharged by transshipment and the vessel was freed on May 30th at around 05:00 a.m

On the 28th March 2012, the Bulk Carrier “TAUNTON” was at Tubarao, Brazil, Anchorage, where it had arrived on 20 March 2012 from Caofeidan, China via Singapore, for stores & bunkering, and was then waiting to load cargo of iron ore in Brazil which would be destined for Sohar, Oman.

On that morning the A/B (Able Bodied Seaman) Yusuf Akyazi was working picking up “Stage” with the Bosun (a platform made of a wooden plank with transverse bearers and fitted with an above waste-height flat bar cage provided to keep people working safely inside).

For the two previous days, the ship’s crew had used two of these Stages for the purpose of safely chipping & painting around the aft Engine Casing.

A/B Yusuf Akyazi had been working the last two days inside a Stage.

On the 28th March, the third day of work, the Bosun decided to keep A/B Akyazi on the Funnel Deck to chip & paint the handrails around the deck area.

The Stage remained from previous day about 2 meters below funnel deck level.

The Bosun, having returned from forecastle area, after handing-out jobs to other crew members, following the Tool Box Meeting at about 09:00 hours, started with A/B Akyazi to pull the Stage up to Engine Casing Top. The intention was to shift the Stage towards the Forward Bulkhead of Engine Casing for another A/B to work inside it, while A/B Akyaki would continue to chip & paint the deck area handrail.

As A/B Akyazi was working on top of Engine Casing, he was wearing a Safety Belt but without it being attached to the ship’s structure.

The Bosun and A/B pulled about two times (lifting the Stage about a half metre). 

While pulling, the Bosun, being left handed, was positioned with his back toward A/B Akyazi, as he was using his left arm to pull and using his leg against the handrail, when he heard a noise similar to that the Stage would make when hitting the casing / bulkhead. He also felt a change in the rope tension. When he turned round and looked down he saw A/B Akyazi falling down on top of the entrance to the Steering Gear Casing, hitting his shoulder and then falling further down to the Poop Deck. 


Nobody saw how his fall started, or how he was pulling on rope to raise the Stage, but it was assumed that he was bending over the handrails most probably while standing on the first tier round bar, above the deck.

There was no scream or shout when he was falling.

A minute after the fall he regained consciousness and was conscious until the boat arrived to take him to hospital (about 2.5 hours). He was talking with crew members asking questions about how he fell. He walked to gangway with assistance of crew (about 25 metres) then the stretcher was used to lower him to the boat.

He died later in the hospital ashore on 3rd April 2012.

Location: Alongside, Kobe Rokko Terminal PC-5, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 27 March 2012, a drill with the vessel’s rescue boat was planned while the vessel was alongside
in Kobe, Japan. When the second of the two crewmembers entered the boat at the embarkation
level, the jaw end of a swivel connected to the rescue boat’s hook failed due to a damaged
split pin, and the boat fell approximately 18 meters to the sea with the two crewmembers on board.
One able seaman (AB) was killed instantly when the boat hit the water. The other crewmember
was severely injured but with the prospects of a full recovery.
This report contain a safety recommendation to the Danish Maritime Authority
The ship manager has taken preventive measures.

Location: LAKE ONTARIO 8 MILES SOUTH OF PRINCE EDWARD POINT, ON, CANADA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE TUG 'PATRICE MCALLISTER' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN LAKE ONTARIO 8 MILES SOUTH OF PRINCE EDWARD POINT, ON, CANADA IN LAT. 43 46N., LONG. 077 02W., AT 0229 HOURS LT ON 27/03/12 IN GOOD WEATHER. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

5 CREW SUSTAINED MINOR INJURIES AND RESCUED BY CGCS 'CAPE HEARN'. CHIEF ENGINEER SUSTAINED SERIOUS INJURIES, AIRLIFTED TO HOSPITAL IN TORONTO AND SUBSEQUENTLY DIED. TUG 'BOWDITCH' EFFECTED TOW TO CLAYTON, NY, USA LATER THE SAME DAY. SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE TO ENGINE ROOM AND ACCOMMODATION. SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO NEW YORK BY TUG 'ROWAN M. MCALLISTER' FOR REPAIRS. CAUSE OF FIRE WAS IGNITION OF OIL FROM FRACTURED OIL LINE FITTING.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SOLASStatus: GAS ARCTIC: SOLAS, SPRING BOK: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
Two vessels were in collision on a misty morning off Dungeness, while proceeding on similar courses in the SW lane of the Dover Strait Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS). When the vessels had passed Dover the lookouts on both had been stood down, although the visibility in the area remained poor. The vessels were making differing speeds; the faster, a 12,000tonne refrigerated cargo vessel was making 19 knots while the other, a 3,000 tonne LPG tanker, was making 8 knots. The master of the cargo vessel was the officer of the watch (OOW); on the bridge with him were his son and another relative, who were both on board as passengers. The master detected the tanker radar at a range of 6 miles, right ahead, but did not use the automatic plotting aid to acquire the target's information. 
As the range between the vessels continued to decrease, the master of the tanker who had gone to the poop deck happened to look up and saw the cargo vessel very close astern. With collision imminent, he ran to the bridge and put the helm hard to port. The cargo vessel's master had no time to take action as the tanker had been in the blind sector created by the deck cranes of the cargo vessel and the vessels collided. Following the collision both vessels contacted the coastguard and were directed to port for survey. Both vessels sustained shell damage above the waterline, which required repair work before they could resume commercial service. Fortunately, there were no injuries.

While departing from the berth, the Master of the "Susan Borchard" allegedly gave helm and engine orders without the knowledge of the pilot on board. The vessel made contact with the berth at her stern and then collided with the "Celia" on an adjacent berth. There was damage to both vessel and the berth.

The passenger ship PATHEIN THU, carrying 100 passengers, en route from Pathein Township on the Pathein River foundered as it was about to dock at a jetty near Ngapudaw Township on 22 March 2012 at 1400 hrs.  Ten passengers died, three were still reported missing and 72 were rescued.

The police and volunteers continued to search for the missing passengers.

The cause of the accident is still being investigated.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0250<#_ftn1> on 22 March 2012, the fishing vessel SIGRID was located approximately 10 nm west of Sylt. The two crewmen had just set the trawl again when the skipper noticed smoke in the bridge.
After an initial attempt to suppress the fire by means of a portable fire extinguisher, he left the bridge because the density of the smoke was continuously increasing. Consequently, he was also unable to send a distress call on VHF.
The two fishermen lowered a life raft into the water and used it to abandon the burning vessel.
Using signal lanterns, they made the crew of the fishing vessel THEODOR STORM, which was fishing in sight of them, aware of the situation. The THEODOR STORM alerted MRCC<#_ftn2> Bremen and picked up the fishermen from the SIGRID.
The rescue cruisers MINDEN and VORMANN LEISS, the boat of Waterway Police (WSP) HELGOLAND, the fishing vessel WEGA, the multipurpose vessel NEUWERK and the tug NORDIC arrived at the burning SIGRID in the course of the next few hours.
After it had been announced that the fire was extinguished in the morning at about 0600, the trawl had to be hauled in by the NEUWERK. The SIGRID could then be towed back to the port of Havneby by the WEGA.
The SIGRID was made fast there at about 2015 in the evening.
Nobody came to physical harm and the environment was not damaged. The vessel was later declared a constructive total loss and scrapped.

At about 02:50 hrs on 22 March 2012, the fishing ship SIGRID was located approximately 10 nm west of Sylt. The two crewmen had just set the trawl again when the skipper noticed smoke in the bridge. 
After an initial attempt to suppress the fire by means of a portable fire extinguisher, he left the bridge because the density of the smoke was continuously increasing. Consequently, he was also unable to send a distress call on VHF.
The two fishermen lowered a life raft into the water and used it to abandon the burning ship.
Using signal lanterns, they made the crew of the fishing ship Theodor Storm, which was fishing In sight of them, aware of the situation. The Theodor Storm alerted MRCC Bremen and picked up the fishermen from the SIGRID. 
The rescue cruisers Minden and Vormann Leiss, the boat of Waterway Police Helgoland, the fishing ship Wega, the multipurpose ship Neuwerk and the tug Nordic arrived at the burning SIGRID in the course of the next few hours.
After it had been announced that the fire was extinguished in the morning at about 06:00, the trawl had to be hauled in by the Neuwerk. The SIGRID could then be towed back to the port of Havneby by the Wega. The SIGRID was made fast there at about 20:15 hrs in the evening.
Nobody came to physical harm and the environment was not damaged. The ship was later declared a constructive total loss and scrapped

On 20-03-2012 at 2158Hours at Shanghai port (31°2.418’N; 122°12.259E), during the outbound transit of Hong Kong, China Registered M.V. “Medi Salerno”, the Bosun was reported fallen overboard while picking up the starboard pilot combination ladder. Search and rescue operations were conducted by the vessel crewmembers as well as the local authority. The missing crew was found dead later.

Location: Off Keelung port in the north of Taiwan, China island
SummaryOfEvents: On 19 March 2012, at 0430 hrs (local time), the ship HAI HSIANG NO 8 loaded with 4,000 tons of soil and a crew of 15 sank off Keelung harbour.  At 0426 hrs, the crew informed Keelung harbour authorities that the ship was listing and of their intension to return to harbour.  Rescue authorities and other ships in the vacinity were immediately alterted by the Control Centre and requested to help with rescue efforts.  The ship sank quickly.  Six bodies were recovered, 7 were rescued by searchers, who are still looking for the 2 missing crew members.  An initial investigation shows that the ship's first engineer was not aboard during the incident. According to customs data, the ship should have had a crew of 16.  The cause of the incident is unclear, however, local media reported that the ship may have been overloaded.  Heavy fog and rough seas may have also caused the accident, according to local media outlets.

Location: EAST CHINA SEA 5 MILES NORTHEAST OF KEELUNG, TAIWAN, CHINA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'OCEAN GLORY' DEVELOPED A 15 DEGREE LIST AND SANK IN THE EAST CHINA SEA 5 MILES NORTHEAST OF KEELUNG, TAIWAN IN LAT. 25 13N., LONG. 121 50E., EARLY AM ON 19/03/12 IN DENSE FOG AND ROUGH SEAS.

6 CREW DEAD AND 2 MISSING, 7 CREW RESCUED BY THE TAIWAN COAST GUARD. SEARCH AND RESCUE OPERATION EFFECTED FOR THE MISSING CREW MEMBERS.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: While discharging a cargo of Toulene an explosion occurred in the forepeak.  The resulting fire burned for approximately 2 to 3 hours before being extinguished.  Several crewmembers sustained minor burns; one was seriously injured.  On 24 March 2012 while the crew was removing firefighting water from the bowthruster space a second explosion occurred.  Three crew members were injured, one of whom died.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: VIGOR MARINE SHIPYARD, EVERETT, WA, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE TUG 'INVADER' FROM THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA DEVELOPED SEVERE LIST TO STARBOARD AND PARTIALLY SANK WHILST UNDERGOING REPAIRS IN DRYDOCK AT THE VIGOR MARINE SHIPYARD, EVERETT, WA, USA PM ON 17/03/12.

INCIDENT OCCURRED AFTER DRYDOCK STARTED SINKING AND EVENTUALLY TOUCHED BOTTOM AT APPROXIMATELY 1200 HOURS LT ON 18/03/12. NO INJURIES REPORTED. SLIGHT OIL SHEEN REPORTED IN SEA. ANTI POLLUTION MEASURES DEPLOYED. REFLOATED ON 26/03/12 BY GLOBAL DIVING AND SALVAGE. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR.

Location: Taiwan Strait, 25 miles southeast of Jiangyin port, Fuqing, China
SummaryOfEvents:
On 15 March 2012, the Singaporean-flagged container ship BARELI stranded and broke in two in the Taiwan Strait, 25 miles southeast of Jiangyin port, Fuqing, China at 2147 hrs (local time).

The forward hull partially sank.  Twenty-one crew members abandoned the ship and were rescued by rescue tug DONG HAI JIU 113.  No injuries were reported.  Salvage operations were effected by Shanghai Salvage Bureau.  A substantial quantity of oil spilled in the sea.  Anti-pollution measures were deployed.  Some of the containers fell into the sea.  As of 9 April 2012, 1,223 containers had been lightered with the assistance of a floating crane.  The majority of the bunker fuel was removed by salvors.

Underway from Bergen to vessels homeport Haus, Osteroya, the highs speed craft "Sea Respons" caught fire underway and had to be abandoned. It was only the skipper onboard who evacuated to the vessels raft and was picked up by a local ferry. "Sea Respons" was later considered a total loss and the skipper himself sustained personal injury after inhalation of toxic smoke from the fire on board.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On Thursday March 15, 2012, Liberian flagged chemical tanker, STOLT VALOR, caught fire and exploded while the crew was engaged in cleaning residual benzen from the cargo tank number 7. Of the 25 crew members on board STOLT VALOR, 24 abandoned ship and were rescued by a nearby United States naval warship. The missing crew member, xxx, was presumed dead.

Location: Stewart Island in the Foveaux Strait at the southern end of New Zealand
SummaryOfEvents: In the early morning of Thursday, 15 March 2012, the fishing vessel EASY RIDER was hit by a rogue wave and sank near Stewart Island in the Foveaux Strait at the southern end of New Zealand.  Eight of the crew members lost their lives, while one member survived.  Rough seas, heavy rain, winds up to 65 kilometres (40 miles) per hour and water temperatures of 13 degrees centigrade (55 degrees fahrenheit) were a contributing factor.  It was 14 hours before authorities knew the ship was missing and it is believed that no lifejackets were worn.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: 4.7 miles west of the tainwei jiao lighthouse on the shore of sanwei in guangzhou south of china
SummaryOfEvents:
The liquid chemical freighter Kenos Athena, with 18 crew members, including
the captain on board, set sail on March 9, 2012 from Pier 1 in the port of
Ulsan (Onsan) having loaded 7,000 T of sulfuric acid. It was sailing toward
the port of Zhuhai, China, at true bearing of about 210° and speed of about
10 knots when central bottom ballast tanks 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5, the port and
starboard bottom ballast tanks 3 and 5, and the pump rooms took in
seawater. On March 13, 2012 at 17:50, the Kenos Athena sank about 4.7
miles west of the Tianwei Jiao lighthouse on the shore of Sanwei in
Guangzhou south of China, at N 22° 44' 28" E 115° 43' 38".

At about 1430 Hours 13 March 2012 during the voyage from France to USA, the bosun fell down to the tanktop of cargo hold No.7 from the hatch coaming due to the rubbish davit failure while he was hoisting the cargo residues from tanktop of No.7 cargo hold.

The 296 meter long, 180407 dwt bulk freighter Hebei Universe went aground on the Black Sea near Zonguldak, Turkey.   The vessel was approaching the port to unload 94338 gt of coal at the local power station when it suffered engine failure.   The vessel was refloated and the cargo of coal unloaded.  No reports of injuries, damage or pollution released.

InitialEvent: SINKING CAUSING MISSING AND DEATH OF PEOPLE ON BOARD
SummaryOfEvents: Portsmouth, UK, Mar 13 -- General cargo Yuan Tong (5505 gt, built 1990) sank alongside the port of Zhoushan at 0630 hrs, today. Forty people were on board the vessel at the time of incident. Thirty two people were rescued, one person was killed and seven are still missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: JAVA SEA SOUTH OF SELETAN POINT, SOUTH KALIMANTAN, INDONESIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE INDONESIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'SINAR JOMBANG' CAUGHT FIRE IN ENGINE ROOM IN THE JAVA SEA SOUTH OF SELETAN POINT, SOUTH KALIMANTAN, INDONESIA AT 0255 HOURS LT ON 13/03/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND BROKEN UP.

BLAZE EXTINGUISHED BY CREW BY 14/03/12. NO INJURIES REPORTED. ANCHORED TO AWAIT ASSISTANCE. LOCAL AUTHORITIES RELUCTANT

The Bangladesh passenger ship, SHARIATPUR-1, was sailing to Ddhaka from neighbouring Shariatpur district when she sank after colliding with a small oil tanker, in Munshiganj district, about 20 miles from the capital.  The SHARIATPUR-1 was carrying more than 250 passengers aboard; 35 passengers were rescued by a passing ship, MITALI, 31 were reported as dead, with scores still missing and the list of casualties feared to rise further as more bodies were reported as being trapped inside the ship.  
The rescue operation continued into the night, as emergency teams stuggled to lift the ship to the surface and bring it to the river bank to complete the search.  An investigation has been ordered into the cause of the incident.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: SUMMARY On March 12th at 14:00 local time the CCS of Tarifa heard through channel 16 of VHF to the CCR Cdiz talking with the fishing boat RUMBO AL MAR which reported the sinking of the fishing boat ANDALUCIA SECOND, approximately 24 miles SW of the Lighthouse of San Sebastian, and which was carrying on board the three crewmembers of the damaged fishing boat. The rescue boat SALVAMAR SUHAIL was sent to the scene of the accident to assist the shipwrecked persons, which was not necessary because the fishing boat RUMBO AL MAR reported that it did not require assistance, for this reason SALVAMAR SAHUAIL and HELIMER 206 remained at the site of the incident to see the wreckage remains and possible pollution in the area. A gas-oil stain of approximately 70 x 30 meters was observed and remains of the damaged fishing vessel such as cork boxes and remains of the fishing gear. On the other hand, the fishing boat RUMBO AL MAR went with the three crewmembers of the damaged fishing boat to Puerto de Santa Mara where it arrived at approximately 14:00 hours. CONCLUSIONS The Commission concluded that the events leading to the loss of B/P ANDALUCIA SEGUNDO did not take place in the manner in which they were reported by their crewmembers. Nor has the Commission been able to examine the vessel, as it has not been found in the place the Crew stated the sinking happened neither in its surroundings. Therefore, and in the absence of any other elements of judgment, the Commission has not been able to establish a reasonable hyposthesis for the loss due to technical reasons of B/P ANDALUCA SEGUNDO. No Recommendations were produced.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On Saturday 11 March 2012 between the hours of 0350 and 0400, the motor vessel Kadri, experienced increasing weather conditions and sea state whilst navigating off the coast of Estonia. At one point in time, the vessel rolled heavily, first to starboard side then port side. 

This resulted in two crew members, the second mate, and the chief engineer, both on the bridge at the time, being flung from their stationary positions.  The second mate sustained severe rib injuries. 

The chief engineer suffered a severe head injury and was bleeding profusely.  First Aid was administered and communications established with shore emergency response parties. 

Having assessed the injuries of the two crew members, and after consulting with a medical doctor from the Emergency 

Medical Centre ashore, it was decided to initiate a MEDEVAC.  However, before arriving ashore, the chief engineer succumbed to his injuries.  The second mate was hospitalised and received the necessary medical treatment. 

Three recommendations have been made to the managers of the vessel intended to address risks and other important facets of the safety management system.

In the early morning of past March 10th 2012, the Italian Tanker named GELSO M whilst approaching the Italian Port of Augusta, , in segregated ballast condition, in simple terms ran aground while attempting a lee shore port arrival in a severe cyclone sailed right through the centre of the Cyclone “Athos”, when the bad weather forecasted by the weather bulletin become a Mediterranean Storm.
The given area of interest was strongly under the influence of the mentioned developing depression. The sustained wind speeds reached up to strong gale force (9Bf) widely spread with gusts temporary increasing to storm (10Bf) and wave height over the area did increase accordingly to a significant
height of 5 to 6 meters, resulting in maximum waves between 9 and 10 meters.
On being advised that the port was closed the master attempted to abort the port approach but found great difficulty in turning through the weather and sea conditions without the main engine over speed tripping due to the propeller being heaved out of the water as a result of the extreme motion of the vessel with the inability to attempt to change the angle of drift to clear the vessel from the headland resulting in vessel not brought under control.
A series of unsuccessful attempts were made to turn the vessel away from the coast but eventually she grounded with both anchors run out.
There were no person injuries. All crew members, 19 persons including the Italian Master (10 Italians, 5 Filipinos, 4 Rumanians) , were rescued by the Italian Coast Guard Helicopters , following instruction from the unified command structure at S.ta Panagia harbour as there was no other way to safely get them to the shore.

Location: Caribbean Sea, 24 nm North from Dominican Republic
SummaryOfEvents: On March 10, 2012 at approximately 05:42 (LT), Liberian flagged refrigerated cargo ship, TIMOR STREAM, was involved in a collision with United Kingdom flagged general cargo ship, SEAGATE. The TIMOR STREAM's Master indicated in his report that while the vessel was transitting Caribbean Sea, he suddenly saw SEAGATE crossing TIMOR STREAM's course from port to starboard at a distance of only several meters. The Master further indicated that before he had time to react, TIMOR STREAM had collided with SEAGATE. TIMOR STREAM sustained little damage, however, SEAGATE was significantly damaged as a result of the casualty. Although the combined amount of hull damage on the vessels was quite significant, there were no injuries reported and the environmental impact was reportedly "extremely minimal".
ShipType1: Other Dry Cargo (livestock, barge, heavy cargo, etc.) Carrier

SummaryOfEvents:
Fully cellular containership Celina, being en-route within the Norwegian inland Fjords 
from Alesund to Flora Saga ran aground off Gangsoy island on 09 March 2012 at 20:30 LT. There was no pilot on board. The vessel grounded due to a navigational error caused by the masters, who hold a PEC (Pilot Exemption Certificate). The grounding occurred while the chief mate was standing the navigational watch with the master giving advice on course and speed to be kept.
The vessel was deployed on a tight schedule and more than one call per day on near by terminals with only little sea passages to cover were an almost regular part of the service.
The grounding occurred during darkness at moderate weather conditions with good visibility but strong winds. There were no fatalities or major injuries but the vessel experienced severe water ingress. Shortly after the accident the master sent a mayday and the Coast Guard and selvage tugs got involved. Minor oil spills observed from a surveillance air craft were immediately battled with oil spill response resources put on scene by the Coast Guard. Major environment degradation could be defended. Celina remained stuck on the rocks until 18 March to be than lifted by higher tides after having partly been relieved from containers and bunkers.
The flag State CCI (Chief Casualty Investigator) has decided to undergo a full independent investigation into this serious marine casualty, after the consultation with Norway, being the coastal State, resulted in no agreement for a joint investigation. Relevant notifications (Part II, chap. 5 and 20 of the Casualty Investigation Code) have been sending out. 
Without a prematurely statement before a conclusion on the underlying causes of the casualty has been reached it appears to be obvious that the bridge team may have been affected by fatigue.

Location: About 10 km west off from Iwai Shima, Yamaguchi Pref., Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
General cargo ship JNS-2, which was proceeding from Fukuyama toward Korea, was in collision with fishing vessel CHOHO-MARU in operation.
CHOHO-MARU consequently capsized and the skipper fell into the sea. The skipper was pulled from the sea but confirmed dead.

Location: Approaches to Port of Kingston, Jamaica
SummaryOfEvents: While approaching the pilot station at the fairway buoy in Kingston, Jamaica, the Master could not find the Chief Engineer. A 4-day search was carried out under the supervision of the Jamaican RCC with no results.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

ShipsInvolved: Stena Feronia (IMO 9136022), STENA FERONIA (IMO 9136022), Union Moon (IMO 8416839), UNION MOON (IMO 8416839)
SOLASStatus: Stena Feronia: Unknown/unspecified, STENA FERONIA: Unknown/unspecified, Union Moon: Unknown/unspecified, UNION MOON: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: The outbound vessel UNION MOON collided with the inbound ferry STENA FERONIA in the vicinity of the fairway buoy.

Location: Belimbing Gulf, south of Pulau Betuah, Lambar, Indonesia
SummaryOfEvents:
On 7 March 2012, the Indonesian-registered general cargo ship SERUNTING I, in heavy weather, foundered after stricking a rock in the Belimbing Gulf, south of Pulau Betuah, Lambar, Indonesia at 1400 hrs (local time).

Seventeen crew members were reported missing and one crew member was rescued by local fishermen.  A search and rescue operation was effected by ships and helicopters.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On March 6, 2012 while transiting the Gulf of Tartary, the vessel ran aground in an icy patch approximately 23 nm from Vanino, Khabarovsk Krai, Russia. The vessel began having problems with its steering. Although the vessel was steered hard to port, the rudder blade was actuall a few degrees to wards starboard. The vessel required towing assistance for rudder reapairs.

Location: ELEFSINA BAY 1 MILE SOUTH OF ELEFSINA, GREECE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PRODUCTS TANKER ' ALPHA 1' CAPSIZED AFTER STRIKING SUBMERGED WRECK IN ELEFSINA BAY 1 MILE SOUTH OF ELEFSINA, GREECE IN LAT. 38 01N., LONG. 23 32E., AT 0942 HOURS LT ON 05/03/12.

SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER. PARTIALLY SUBMERGED HULL STILL VISIBLE. 3 COASTGUARD VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE. 10 CREW RESCUED. 1 CREW MEMBER TAKEN TO HOSPITAL AS A PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE. BODY OF CAPTAIN RECOVERED BY DIVERS LATER THE SAME DAY. SOME OIL POLLUTION OBSERVED IN SEA. ANTI POLLUTION BOOMS DEPLOYED. DIVERS SEALED HULL OPENINGS TO PREVENT FURTHER OIL LOSS. REMAINING OIL PUMPED OUT BY SALVORS.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
THE INDONESIAN-REGISTERED DECK CARGO SHIP 'SINAR BANJAR' STRANDED AFTER BREAKING MOORINGS AT LINAU, INDONESIA IN LAT. 04 50S., LONG. 103 24E., AT 1400 HOURS LT ON 04/03/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. ALL 11 CREW RESCUED AND TAKEN TO LOCAL NAVAL BASE.

On 3 March 2013 at 0400 hrs (local time), a fire broke out in the engine room of the stren trawler, JUNG WOO No. 3, registerd by the Republic of Korea, whilst moored at Montevideo, Uruguay.

Local fire services proceeded to assist.  Two crew members died, six members were injured and the remaining crew members were evacuated.  The vessel was towed to outer harbour for continued fire fighting operations.  The blaze had spread to other areas of the vessel, which was subsequently burnt out.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 2-3-2012 at 2309Hours at Zijinshan Shipyard (32°15’N, 119°46’E), when the ship and the shipyard staffs were preparing the auxiliary composite boiler (working pressure:0.70Mpa, steam rate: 800kg/hr) for the final inspection (including the safety valve relief pressure setting) of the boiler survey, the boiler exploded. One company technical supervisor, 2 crewmembers and 1 shipyard staff were killed and 12 crewmembers were injured.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SOLASStatus: BOYUN 018: Unknown/unspecified, UNIDENTIFIED PANAMANIAN CARGO VESSEL: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On March 2 2012 the bulk freighter BOYUN 018 collided with a Panama-registered cargo vessel in waters off Zhuhai City, in the Pearl River Delta, at around 21.00 hours, during foggy weather conditions. The BOYUN 018 sank following the collision, with ten crew members on board. Two of the crew members had been rescued by 14.00 hours the following day, but eight were still missing despite search and rescue operations involving six ships.
The collision also led to a minor fuell spill after a fuel tank of the Panamanian vessel was damaged, though the authorities reported that the spill had been addressed and the clean-up operation was underway.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SOLASStatus: BO YUM 018: Unknown/unspecified, DREAM DIVA: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: Bulk carrier Bo Yun 018 came in contact with roll on roll off Dream Diva (41662 gt, built 2007) in the waters of South China’s Zhuhai city at 2100 hrs, Mar 2. As a result of the collision Bo Yun 018 sank. Two crew members out of the ten on board Bo Yun 018 have been rescued as of 1400 hrs, Mar 3 and search for the remaining eight crew members are on going. There was also a slight fuel spill after a fuel tank on Dream Diva was damaged as a result of the collision. The local maritime authorities said that the spill had been contained and the cleaning work was under way

Location: ISE BAY OFF FUTAMI, MIE, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE JAPANESE-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'DAIRYU MARU NO. 5' DEVELOPED LIST AND SANK AFTER STRIKING SUBMERGED ROCKS IN ISE BAY OFF FUTAMI, MIE, JAPAN IN LAT. 34 32N., LONG. 136 47E., AT 0130 HOURS LT ON 02/03/12.

SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER. INTIAL DISTRESS CALL RECEIVED AT 2040 HOURS LT ON 01/03/12. COASTGUARD VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE. ALL 4 CREW RESCUED. NO INJURIES REPORTED. APPROXIMATELY 300 LITRES OF OIL SPILLED INTO THE SEA. ANTI POLLUTION MEASURES DEPLOYED.

Location: GULF OF TONKIN 135 MILES SOUTHEAST OF HAI PHONG, VIETNAM
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VIETNAMESE-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'TRA LY 18-ALCI' SANK AFTER TAKING WATER IN THE GULF OF TONKIN 135 MILES SOUTHEAST OF HAI PHONG, VIETNAM IN LAT. 19 00N., LONG. 107 27E., AT 0731 HOURS LT ON 29/02/12.

ALL 8 CREW RESCUED BY MV 'HOANG VU 01' AND TAKEN TO CAM PHA, VIETNAM. NO INJURIES REPORTED.

Anchored vessel GEORGETE K. was dragged and ran aground about 30 meters from the shore owing to gale. The vessel was waiting for dismantling. The ship was rescued by Tüpras Tugboats on February 28th at 13:40 local time, and towed to Aliaga Ship Dismantling Region. There is no any report of injury or environmental pollution.

Location: 2 MILES NORTH OF MAKHACHKALA, RUSSIAN FEDERATION
SummaryOfEvents:
THE RUSSIAN-FLAGGED PRODUCTS TANKER 'INZHENER NAZAROV' CAUGHT FIRE IN SUPERSTRUCTURE WHILST MOORED 2 MILES NORTH OF MAKHACHKALA, RUSSIAN FEDERATION  IN LAT. 43 01N., LONG. 47 30E., AT 1235 HOURS LT ON 28/02/12. SUBSEQUENTLY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.

13 CREW RESCUED AND 1 CREW MEMBER DEAD. MT 'NEFTERUDOVOZ-47M', TUG 'FAVORIT', NAVAL VESSEL 'VLS-98' AND BORDER PATROL VESSEL 'PPS-800' ASSISTED WITH FIRE FIGHTING OPERATIONS. BLAZE EXTINGUISHED LATER THE SAME DAY. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO CREW ACCOMMODATION AREA. TOWED TO BERTH AT MAKHACHKALA ON 29/02/12 FOR INSPECTION. PROCEEDED TO BERTH AT ASTRAKHAN, RUSSIA FOR REPAIRS.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
Multi purpose vessel MCL Bremen was berthed starboard side in the port of Antwerp. The vessel had commenced to load loose pipes in a centre tweendeck after cargo discharge had been completed the day before. At this stage the vessel was in an almost light condition.
The stevedores had started the pipe stowage on port side ship’s tweendeck wall toward the vessel’s centre line to than proceed with a second, third and fourth on-top layer stowage without having the first layer stowage completed beyond the centre line up to the starboard side hold wall. The stevedores had chosen this mode of stowing because the vessel at that time had a slight port list, an almost normal condition caused by the two vessel’s deck cranes mounted on deck port side foreword and aft. This slight portside list kept the loose pipes in their origin stow position with no need to be secured and prevented from rolling with wedges placed along their  length. 
The pipe loading was in progress uneventful till the vessel’s deck crew was asked by the stevedores to put a 20 foot container with lashing material ashore which was yet placed on deck in front of the vessel accommodation. 
The container was lifted with the vessel’s aft crane and shifted ashore. The process of swinging the container around and to drop it on the wharf caused the vessel to cease from listing to port and heeled to starboard. As a consequence thereof the tweendeck top layer of still unsecured pipes got rolling and buried two stevedore workers. 
The cargo operation was stopped immediately and the two casualties removed from the pipe debris. They were hospitalized but there they both could only be declared death.
Cargo1: general, break bulk, containers, may include DG

SummaryOfEvents:
While C/S Costa Allegra was underway from Nosy Be (Madagasca) bound to Port Victoria (Sheychelles) a fire broke on board, in the electric generetor room. 
The blaze was quickly extinguished by mean of fire fighting appliances. 
Costa Allegra got adrift without any power due to a subsequent failure of the emergency generator.
She remained adrift on emergency batteries only.
The ship was towed to Port Victoria where arrived on 1 March, 2012.
All passengers were safely disembarked.
None was injuried. No pollution at sea.

THE LITHUANIAN-FLAGGED SUCTION DREDGER 'CHABIRA' TOOK WATER AND SANK WHILST MOORED AT KLAIPEDA, LITHUANIA AT 0130 HOURS LT ON 27/02/12. WRECK REFLOATED ON 15/10/12 AND REMOVED, SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP.

NO INJURIES REPORTED. ANTI-POLLUTION BOOM DEPLOYED AS A PRECAUTION. CAUSE OF SINKING UNKNOWN. WRECK REFLOATED ON 18/10/12 WITH ASSISTANCE FROM A FLOATING CRANE AND TOWED AWAY FOR BREAKING UP.

On February 26, 2012 at approximately 04:47, Liberian flagged container ship incurred a fire in the vessel's engine room caused by an explosion in the auxiliary engine No. 2. The crew members managed to extinguish the fire using breathing apparatuses and fire extinguishers, and, shortly thereafter, water. The vessel, after the incident, required towing assistance, but there were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

While loading a cargo of steel rolls on board the vessel during cargo operation at the Port of St. Petersburg, Russia the vessel, under the assistance of 3 tugs, was moving astern into a turning area. After the vessel had turned, the vessel lost movement in the middle of that turning area. The vessel had run aground in an ice pillow that had formed during cargo operations. High power heaters were rented to re-float the vessel. There were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

While under tug and pilotage, the vessel cleared the berth by tug boat PAWLINA and began shifting from port side to starboard side. During this shifting and due to excessive force, the close fairlead was completely sheared off from its original location caused by damage to the fairlead foundation, vent heads, deck and railings. One of the posts that was supporting the free-fall life boat was sheared off by the tug line, causing the life boat to fall into the water. Although damage to the vessel and vessel equipment was extensive, there were no injuries reported.

At approximately 15:32 hrs, while TAMINA was anchored, Singaporean flagged vessel TITAN ORION collided into TAMINA's starboard side resulting in damage to TAMINA's hull and her anchor and deck equipment.

Location: ATLANTIC OCEAN 11 MILES SOUTHEAST OF KENNEBUNKPORT. ME, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FISHING VESSEL 'PLAN-B' TOOK WATER AND SANK IN THE ATLANTIC OCEAN 11 MILES SOUTHEAST OF KENNEBUNKPORT. ME, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA IN LAT. 43 17N., LONG. 070 17W., AT 0730 HOURS LT ON 21/02/12 IN GOOD WEATHER.

USCG CUTTER 'TAHOMA', OTHER USCG VESSELS AND AN MH-60J HELICOPTER PROCEEDED TO THE SCENE AND RESCUED BOTH CREW. NO INJURIES REPORTED. OIL SHEEN REPORTED ON SEA.

On February 20, 2012 at approximately 04:48, the vessel was transiting the Suriname Rive toward Paraname for a cargo loading operation. The pilot was on board the vessel and the Master, duty officer, look out and helmsman were all aware of the traffic in that area and moderate visibility from the rain showers. A barge approached the vessel and attempted to cross in front of the vessel's bow. The vessel attempted to sound the whistle to warn the barge of the imminent collision. The vessel also attempted to alter course to starboard in attempt to avoid the collision. Unfortunately, the barge collided into the vessel in the aft part of the wheel house section. There were no reports of injury or pollution.

Location: TAIWAN STRAIT NORTH OF CHI-PEI TAO, PENGHU, TAIWAN, CHINA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE LPG TANKER 'OBERON' STRANDED IN THE TAIWAN STRAIT NORTH OF CHI-PEI TAO, PENGHU, TAIWAN, CHINA IN LAT. 23 48N., LONG. 119 36E., EARLY AM ON 19/02/12 IN STRONG WINDS. WRECK SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP IN SITU.

SUSTAINED SERIOUS DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER. SOME OIL POLLUTION REPORTED IN SEA. 5 COAST GUARD AND POLICE HELICOPTERS ATTENDED THE SCENE AND ASSISTED WITH RESCUE OF THE 16 CREW. NO INJURIES REPORTED. FUEL AND CARGO PUMPED OUT BY RESOLVE SALVAGE AND DEMOLITION OF WRECK IN SITU COMMENCED JUNE 2012. REMOVAL OF WRECK COMPLETED OCTOBER 2012.

Location: Off the coast of Chongwu, Fujian Province, People's Republic of China
SummaryOfEvents:
The cargo ship Xinyuanshun 6, which was on its way to Shandung Province carrying 5,000 tonnes of pottery clay, sank off the People's Republic of China's south-eastern coast at about 03.00 hours on 18th February 2012.
Eleven boats and two helicopters were involved in the rescue, battling strong winds and rough seas.  Only one crew member was rescued; the bodies of eight crew members were found and a further two were missing.The vessel might have capsized after goods slid to one side of its hold.  Authorities are probing the cause of the sinking, and are on the alert for an oil spill.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On the 16 February 2012 night the French motor yacht YOGI bound to Cannes was
underway in the Aegean Sea with an eight member vessel operation crew.
Weather conditions were relatively good (following sea and wind) and both engines
were running; the average speed made good was close to 14 knots (cf. 7.6).
An abnormal cooling freshwater temperature rise and a leak on the starboard engine
exhaust, obligated the master who was on watch to stop this engine. Soon after, as the port engine was overheating, it shut down automatically while the chief engineer, on watch, was asking the master to reduce the motor speed. The master informed the designated person ashore.
The vessel was then drifting, broadside on to the waves, and listing to port. The
strainers of both engine sea water cooling circuits had been checked but found clean. The port engine had been restarted and the temperatures were back to normal; the master decided to head to Skyros Island, 25 miles away, but the helm was out of order and a rudder angle of 30° to starboard was displayed.
Therefore, investigations were then undertook by the first officer and the engineers towards the three aft compartments (beach club 1, beach club 2 and steering room); all of them
were found partially flooded, with different heights of water. Pumping was started.
A PAN PAN alert had been transmitted and a request for assistance by a tug had been sent to the Greek authorities. Due to the tacking, the list shifted to starboard then suddenly
increased. The pumping means became unserviceable. Soon after, the lower deck and the main deck were flooded.
A MAYDAY with a ship evacuation call had been transmitted. A salvage tug had been made ready and the intervention of a Greek Coast Guard helicopter had been rapidly confirmed.
At 8.50 am, the winching operations were completed and the crew was safe and sound. At the end of the morning,  YOGI sank to the bottom at a depth of 500 meters.

Location: KITOVY BAY 2 MILES NORTH OF KURILSK, ITURUP ISLAND
SummaryOfEvents:
THE RUSSIAN-FLAGGED TANKER 'KARAKUMNEFT' STRANDED IN KITOVY BAY 2 MILES NORTH OF KURILSK, ITURUP ISLAND IN LAT. 45 15N., LONG. 147 53E., AT 1915 HOURS LT ON 15/02/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER. WRECK ABANDONED IN SITU.

ALL 20 CREW RESCUED AND TAKEN TO SHORE. NO INJURIES REPORTED. DIVERS INSPECTION REVEALED 11 HOLES IN HULL AND ENGINE ROOM FLOODED. APPROXIMATELY 550 CUBIC METRES OF OIL SPILLED INTO SEA. ADDITIONAL SALVAGE EQUIPMENT AIRLIFTED IN BY MIL 26T HELICOPTER. TUG 'ATLAS' AND MT 'ATIVA' ASSISTED WITH SALVAGE OPERATION. SALVORS PUMPED OUT REMAING 478 CUBIC METRES OF OIL TO LAND BASED TANKERS.

THE TONGAN-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'TAKUO' STRANDED ON BEACH AT NOMUKA'IKI ISLAND, TONGA IN LAT. 20 17S., LONG. 174 48W., ON 14/02/12 IN TROPICAL CYCLONE 'JASMINE'.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. WRECK BROKEN UP AND REMOVED IN FEBRUARY 2015.

THE FISHING VESSEL 'SHUN KING 8' BROKE MOORINGS, CAPSIZED AND PARTIALLY SANK WHILST ANCHORED OFF NUKU'ALOFA, TONGA ON 14/02/12 IN TROPICAL CYCLONE 'JASMINE'.

2 POLICE OFFICERS SWAM TO VESSEL AND RESCUED ALL 3 CREW ON A LIFE RAFT. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. PARTIALLY SUBMERGED HULL REFLOATED AND DRAGGED CLEAR OF THE SHIPPING CHANNEL ON 11/04/12. VESSEL HAD BEEN ANCHORED OFF PANGAIMOTU ISLAND UNDER POLICE INVESTIGATION FOR A MISSING CREW MEMBER AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.

Location: AEGEAN SEA 15 MILES NORTHEAST OF LEMNOS, GREECE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE RO-RO CARGO SHIP 'KONGE' CAUGHT FIRE IN HOLD IN THE AEGEAN SEA 15 MILES NORTHEAST OF LEMNOS, GREECE AT 0630 HOURS LT ON 13/02/12. TO BE SOLD FOR BREAKING UP.

ALL 5 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFT. SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY HAF SUPER PUMA HELICOPTER AND TAKEN TO LEMNOS. NO INJURIES REPORTED. VESSEL COMPLETELY BURNT OUT. COASTGUARD PATROL VESSEL ATTENDED THE SCENE. TOWED TO MYRINA, LEMNOS FOR INSPECTION. SUBSEQUENTLY LAID UP UNREPAIRED AT AGIOS NIKOLAOS, GREECE AWAITING THE OUTCOME OF LEGAL PROCEEDINGS PRIOR TO SALE FOR BREAKING UP.

Location: INDIAN OCEAN APPROXIMATELY 200 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PORT LOUIS, MAURITIUS
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PANAMANIAN-FLAGGED BULK CARRIER 'NINA P' CAUGHT FIRE IN THE ENGINE ROOM IN THE INDIAN OCEAN APPROXIMATELY 200 MILES SOUTHEAST OF PORT LOUIS, MAURITIUS ON 13/02/12. DAMAGED BEYOND ECONOMICAL REPAIR AND ARRIVED AT CHITTAGONG, BANGLDESH ON 08/06/12 FOR BREAKING UP.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. 5 VESSELS PROCEEDED TO ASSIST WITH FIRE FIGHTING OPERATIONS AND BLAZE BROUGHT UNDER CONTROL. NO INJURIES REPORTED. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN. LOF CONTRACT AWARDED TO FIVE OCEANS SALVAGE. TUG 'CORAL SEA FOS' EFFECTED TOW TO PORT LOUIS ARRIVING ON 22/02/12 FOR INSPECTION. CARGO TRANSHIPPED TO MV 'LUXURY SW'. ARRIVED IN TOW AT CHITTAGONG, BANGLADESH ON 08/06/12 AND DETAINED PENDING LEGAL PROCEEDINGS.

On the afternoon of Saturday 12 February 2012, Mr X received a telephone call to come to the assistance of his friend Mr Y.  Mr Y was in his boat and anchored on the North side of the estuary of Dundalk harbour.  Mr X made his way to his own boat, which was moored at a buoy on the south side of the estuary of Dundalk harbour.  To get to his boat Mr X had to use a small punt.  He walked out along the mudflat to the punt, untied it and proceeded to walk toward his boat pulling the punt behind him.  After some time Mr Y became anxious as Mr X had not arrived to assist him.  Mr Y contacted Mr X's home to discover that he had left home and should have arrived to assist him.  The alarm was raised and the emergency services were alterted.  Mr X's body and the submerged punt were recovered from the estuary later that evening.

inform you about the unfortunate death of an AB who fell from the up mast on to the deck and lost his life on board our vessel M/V NINOS on February 11, 2012, at the port of Bangkok, on about 09:45 local time.

Location: 65 nautical miles NNE of Cape Freels, Newfoundland
SummaryOfEvents: On 10 February 2012, at approximately 2000 Newfoundland Standard Time, a crew member on the large fishing vessel Katsheshuk II lost his life when a hydraulically operated shutter door closed on him as he was exiting the holding tank in the vessel’s processing factory.

SOLASStatus: AGNES: Unknown/unspecified, BIEN NAM 17: Unknown/unspecified, MARITIME 36: Unknown/unspecified
Location: NHA BE RIVER OFF NHA BE, VIETNAM
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VIETNAMESE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'BIEN NAM 17' SANK AFTER COLLISION WITH MVS 'AGNES' AND 'MARITIME 36' IN THE NHA BE RIVER OFF NHA BE, VIETNAM IN LAT. 10 42N., LONG. 106 45E., AT 1530 HOURS LT ON 10/02/12.

VESSEL HAD BEEN ANCHORED AWAITING BERTHING WHEN MOORINGS BROKE AND DRIFTED DOWN RIVER. SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO STARBOARD SIDE OF HULL AND TOOK WATER. 11 CREW RESCUED BY LOCAL VESSEL. BODY OF 1 MISSING CREW MEMBER RECOVERED THE NEXT DAY. NO POLLUTION REPORTED. SALVAGE CONTRACT AWARDED TO TNHH SONG THUONG. CARGO AND BUNKER FUEL REMOVED. TEMPORARY REPAIRS EFFECTED BY DIVERS. REFLOATED ON 23/02/12 AND TOWED TO SAFE ANCHORAGE FOR INSPECTION.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Port Approach area of Callao, Peru
SummaryOfEvents: On 8 February 2012 at 1534 hrs., the ship CAMISEA was en route to the Callao Bay. Orders were left with Deck Watch Officers to inform the Master when they were abeam the Palomino Islets, a few miles from Callao.  Incorrect information was given as to CAMISEA's exact location; instead of approaching the Palomino Islets, CAMISEA was actually in the vicinity of the San Lorenzo Island.  The Master immediately ordered for the manoeuvring speed to be reduced.  The Watch Officer was ordered by the Vessel Traffic Control Centre of the Maritime Coast Guard Captaincy of Callao to go to the anchorage No. 8 while waiting for the pilot to arrive and then to proceed to moor the ship on buoys at the 'La Pampilla' port facility.  Existing mist at the time resulted in low visibility and a vision scope of no more than 50 m.  The Master was again informed as to the ship's exact position; given the ship’s length and its superstructure.  The Master immediately made his way to the bridge, however on his way, the ‘CAMISEA’ collided with the Chinese F/V Yan Yu 664; resulting in a hole of about 1 m in diameter and a tear of part of the gunwale at the level of the port bow of the fishing ship.  The Master ordered for the engines to be stopped and all crew were alerted as to the collision. Assistance was offered, however not afforded as ‘YAN YU’ continued to navigate without any risks.  TRAMAR was informed of the casualty and ‘CAMISEA’ was instructed to proceed to the anchorage No.8.  No injuries were reported from all 31 persons on board (9 officers, 22 crewmembers).

Location: EAST OF THE BREAKWATER AT SAMSUN, TURKEY
SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'HAY K' STRANDED EAST OF THE BREAKWATER AT SAMSUN, TURKEY IN LAT. 41 17N., LONG. 36 22E., AT 1100 HOURS LT ON 08/02/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. SUSTAINED SEVERE DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER IN ENGINE ROOM. ALL 8 CREW RESCUED.

ShipsInvolved: GINGA TIGER (IMO 9278715), ZHE XIAO SHAN HUO 23651 (-)
SOLASStatus: GINGA TIGER: SOLAS, ZHE XIAO SHAN HUO 23651: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
M.T "Ginga Tiger" (IMO No. 9278715) was a 16,232 GRT, 7,683 NRT, 26, 197Mt of deadweight, chemical tanker, built by Shin Kurushima Dockyard, in June 2002, flying Panama flag, with 159.98m of LOA, 26.80m of breadth, NK c1ass. She was owned by Tiger Shipholding, S.A, and technical operated by Unix Une pte Ud and commercial operated by Tokyo Marine Co., Ud. The vessel was manned all with Korean and Chinese officers and crew. 
The vessel was partly loaded with various chemicals, departed from Zhangjiagang at 1610U on 07th Feb 2012 and proceeded to Jiangyin with two river pilots on board. At about 1722 hrs, in vicinity of buoy No. 62 a collision occurred with a small coaster barge which was crossing ahead of Ginga Tiger. 
The coaster "Zhe Xiao Shan Huo 23651" was reportedly to be loaded and as a result of the impact, the coaster barge capsized alongwith its two crew. 
Our vessel immediately anchored to render assistance and conducted notifications to MSA through the pilot. 3 MSA boats were at site almost immediately and one of the crew member was rescued and in good health condition. Ginga Tiger was later advised by MSA to proceed to her destined berth at Jiangyin for cargo operations. 
The second crew member is still missing as per information from MSA. There has been no pollution reported and our vessel has just minor paint scratches and dent .

SOLASStatus: KOTA DUTA: SOLAS, TANYA KARPINSKAYA: SOLAS
Location: In Higashi-ku of Niigata Port, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
Both ships came into collision in Higashi-ku of Niigata Port, Japan.
TANYA KARPINSKAYA consequently sank.
All crews of TANYA KARPINSKAYA were safe.

The chemical tanker KYOKUHO MARU No.2 left Komatsu Wharf, Izumi-otsu Port, Izumi-otsu City, Osaka Prefecture, with the master, the second officer and other three crewmembers onboard.  On her way northward to the Umemachi Terminal in the Section 1 of Hanshin Port, at about 12:29 on February 7, 2012, the chief engineer found the second officer collapsed in the port No.1 cargo tank.
      The second officer was rescued but, having been disabled to breathe by the inhaled gas, died in oxygen deficiency.

Location: SEA OF AZOV 50 MILES SOUTHWEST OF BERDYANSK, UKRAINE
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PANAMANIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'ALACA 1' SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER AFTER STRIKING ICE IN THE SEA OF AZOV 50 MILES SOUTHWEST OF BERDYANSK, UKRAINE IN LAT. 46 10N., LONG. 036 05E., AT 0600 HOURS LT ON 07/02/12.

ALL 12 CREW ABANDONED SHIP ONTO THE ICE AND SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY MIL-8 HELICOPTER AND TAKEN TO SIMFEROPOL, UKRAINE. ICEBREAKING TUG 'KAPITAN DEMIDOV' PROCEEDED TO THE SCENE. ABANDONED VESSEL DRIFTED AND RELOCATED ON 07/03/12 40 MILES SOUTH OF ORIGINAL INCIDENT LOCATION.

THE RUSSIAN-FLAGGED FISHING VESSEL 'TYULEN-4' BROOK MOORINGS, STRUCK PIER AND SANK AT GELENDZHIK, RUSSIAN FEDERATION PM ON 07/02/12 IN STRONG WINDS.

SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO STARBOARD SIDE OF HULL. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. PARTIALLY SUBMERGED BUT SUPERSTRUCTURE STILL VISIBLE. ANTI POLLUTION BOOM DEPLOYED AS A PRECAUTION AND 9.6 TONS OF BUNKER FUEL REMOVED. WRECK STILL IN SITU AS OF FEB 2013.

SOLASStatus: AP BAC 03: Unknown/unspecified, DAI DUONG 125: Unknown/unspecified
Location: GULF OF TONKIN 40 MILES SOUTHEAST OF THANH HOA, VIETNAM
SummaryOfEvents:
THE VIETNAMESE-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'DAI DUONG 125' SANK AFTER COLLISION WITH MV 'AP BAC 03' IN THE GULF OF TONKIN 40 MILES SOUTHEAST OF THANH HOA, VIETNAM IN LAT. 19 42N., LONG. 106 25E., AT 1830 HOURS LT ON 06/02/12.

ALL 8 CREW RESCUED BY 'AP BAC 03' AND TAKEN TO UNKNOWN PORT. NO INJURIES REPORTED.

MV Captain Ivan Vikulov had been stuck in the frozen Azov Sea for five days, in position 45°54’N 35°34’E and had been waiting for an ice breaker to continue on its passage to Rostov-on-Don, Russia. On 05 February 2012, at 0645(UTC + 2), the fire alarm panel on the bridge indicated the activation of a heat detector in the cook’s cabin. Several minutes later, the chief mate activated the vessel’s general alarm but the fire spread rapidly from the cook’s cabin, situated on the starboard side of the first deck. In about 30 minutes, all forward cabins on the starboard side were engulfed in flames. The fire continued to spread across the alleyway to the port side cabins and also on the bridge deck.


For three and a half hours, the crew members tried without success to contain and extinguish the fire with water hoses from the alleyway and the external superstructure. The cold weather conditions in addition to the prevailing strong winds, the intensity of the fire, and the dense smoke hindered the fire- fighting operation. Eventually, the master had to order the evacuation of the vessel.

By the next day, the fire had burnt itself out.

The safety investigation concluded that the fire spread as a result of several factors including the weather conditions, and the duration of the fire inside the cabins.

The Maltese registered motor tanker Haldoz arrived at Tarragona, Spain pilot station on 03 February 2012 at 0400 (LT).  She eventually was alongside Terquimsa Terminal Pier No. 4 at about 0455 (LT). 

Once the berthing operations were completed, the Terminal loading master and the cargo surveyor boarded the vessel for the routine safety checks together with the ship’s officers. 

Loading operations commenced at 0950 (LT), after the safety checks were formally completed. There were eight cargo parcels, which had to be loaded; four parcels of Styrene monomer and four parcels of Polyol. 

About one hour into the cargo operations, the port emergency centre received a report of cargo pollution within the Terminal.  Cargo operations were eventually suspended at 1105 (LT). 

Emergency level was raised by the Terminal’s emergency centre and several resources to mitigate the pollution.  The Spanish authorities estimated that cargo spill was in the order of 100 metric tonnes. 

Although MSIU has not established with utmost certainty the circumstances into the cargo spill, one recommendation was made both to the vessel’s managers and Terminals intended to improve the cargo operations procedures.

Location: SOUTH CHINA SEA OFF GUIKENG, SHANTOU, CHINA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE PANAMANIAN-FLAGGED BULK CARRIER 'UNISON EVER' STRANDED AFTER DRAGGING ANCHOR IN THE SOUTH CHINA SEA OFF GUIKENG, SHANTOU, CHINA IN LAT. 23 13N., LONG. 116 48E., AT 2025 HOURS LT ON 02/02/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER. REFLOATED AND SUBSEQUENTLY TOWED TO NINGDE, CHINA FOR BREAKING UP.

NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. COASTGUARD VESSELS ATTENDED THE SCENE. ALL 20 CREW RESCUED 0N 09/02/12 BY RESCUE TUG 'NAN HAI JIU 113'. SALVAGE CONTRACT SIGNED WITH GUANGZHOU SALVAGE BUREAU. TUG 'DE XIN' ARRIVED ON SCENE ON 10/04/12 TO COMMENCE SALVAGE OPERATION. REFLOATED AND ARRIVED IN TOW AT NINGDE, CHINA ON 03/09/12 FOR BREAKING UP.

On 2 February 2012, at 0500 hrs, the passenger ship RABAUL QUEEN capsized and sank off Papua New Guinea.  The ship was on its way from the Kimbe Wharf in West New Britain Province en route from Rabaul and into Lae under weather conditions of strong winds and rough seas.  A total of 372 people were on board from Bougainville, Manus, New Ireland East New Britain provinces, who arrived in Kimbe to catch a connecting vessel to Lae, along with passengers from West New Britain province.  Approximately, 246 lives were saved thanks to the joint Australia-Papua New Guinea resue operation.  A distress call from the ship was picked up by the Australian Navy Ship who immediately attended to the accident scene.  Three international bulk carriers, 2 international tankers, a Royal Australian Aire Force plane, two helicopters hired by Morobe Disaster and Rabaul Shipping also assisted in the rescue operation.  It is thought that the very severe weather conditions was a cause of the sinking.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
THE SIERRA LEONEAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'SEA HOPE' IN COLLISION WITH MV 'PARIS-Y' WHILST BERTHED AT BEIRUT, LEBANON AM ON 02/02/12. SUBSEQUENTLY ARRIVED AT ALIAGA, TURKEY ON 17/02/12 FOR BREAKING UP.

SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO STERN. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. INSPECTION EFFECTED.

THE ROMANIAN-FLAGGED HOPPER MOTOR 'MIDIA 24' DRAGGED ANCHOR AND STRANDED IN THE BLACK SEA OFF BICHVINTA, GEORGIA PM ON 02/02/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO HULL AND TOOK WATER IN CARGO HOLD. ALL 5 CREW RESCUED. NO INJURIES REPORTED, SOME OIL SPILLED INTO SEA.

Location: 1 mile off the cost of the Black Sea port of Zonguldak
SummaryOfEvents: On 31 January 2012, the Cambodian-registered dry cargo ship VERA, carrying 2850 tons of scrap metal capsized in a storm, 1 mile off the coast of the Black Sea port of Zonguldak.  The ship was sailing from Russia to the the Turkish Aegean port of Aliaga.  By the time the Coast Guard arrived in response to the distress call, the ship had already sunk.  Three crew members were rescued and taken to hospital.  Coastguards and police were still searching for the 8 other crew members.

On 29 January 2012 a fisherman was swept overboard from the twin rig trawler Zenith during a routine net hauling operation in the Irish Sea. The crew reacted swiftly to the situation and the skipper skilfully manoeuvred his vessel back alongside the casualty. However, the fisherman was not wearing a lifejacket and the crew had no suitable equipment available to hold him alongside whilst his recovery was effected. Subsequently, despite their efforts, the
casualty slipped from his rescuers’ reach and was lost.

While the pilot was operating the vessel, the vessel swung towards port even after a 'hard to starboard' order. The vessel eventually began listing towards starboard and ran aground. The vessel was refloated after more than two hours of tugging assistance from the local port authority. There were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

On 28 January 2012, the Liberian-flagged cargo ship LAURA 1, loaded with clay suffereed two casualties in port Antwerp in the Amerika Dock.  Two workers were lifting a bulldozer into the cargo hold when it crashed down, hitting the two and causing fatal injuries.  Emergency services were on site, but the workers were pronounced dead.

THE MOLDOVAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'RONA' STRANDED AFTER DRAGGING ANCHOR 10 MILES NORTHWEST OF KILYOS, TURKEY IN LAT. 41 18N., LONG. 28 50E., AT 0543 HOURS LT ON 27/01/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

TUG 'KURTARMA 10' AND RESCUE BOATS 'KEGM 1' AND '9' ATTENDED THE SCENE. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. ALL 9 CREW RESCUED PM ON 28/01/12.

CARISMA had been on a voyage from Slite to Roenne to take a cargo of sand. The ship arrived at Roenne on 25 January 2011 at 2200. As the loading operation was planned to commence the next morning, it was decided not to rig the gangway until visitors were expected.
Half an hour after arrival, a part of the crew left the ship to go ashore. Instead of rigging the gang-way they used a pilot ladder that they rigged on the ship side. Shortly after having arrived at the town centre, one of the crew members felt tired and returned to the ship.
At 0020 on 26 of January 2012, the seaman was observed struggling in the water between the ship and the quay. Within ten minutes the seaman was safe, but he died later that night at the hospital in Roenne.
After the accident the ship has been equipped with at new gangway that can be rigged parallel to the ships side.
This report does not contain any recommendation in relation to the fatal accident the seafarer on 26 January 2012.

Location: Norwegian Sea, 230 miles northwest of Stad, Norway
SummaryOfEvents:
On 25 January 2012, the Icelandic-flagged fishing vessel HALLGRIMUR took water and foundered in heavy weather conditions in the Norwegian sea, 230 miles northwest of Stad, Norway at 1418 hrs (local time).  

Search and rescue operation, including RNOAF helicopters, P-3 aircraft, fishing vessel HEROYHAV and coastguard ship BERGEN was deployed.  One crew member was rescued and airlifted to hospital and three members were reported missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: Master of "MSC CHELSEA" Panama Flagged that on 25/01/2012, 3rd Officer, Mr. Raneesh Ravi did not report for his duty at 0800 hrs. A thorough search was carried out on board but in vain. Urgency message was sent and requested MRCC Cape town and Walvis Bay for assistance. Ship reversed her course for Search and Rescue without any success.

Location: ALITAK BAY 4 MILES EAST OF CAPE ALITAK, AK, USA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FISHING VESSEL 'HERITAGE' DEVELOPED LIST TO PORT, TOOK WATER AND SANK IN ALITAK BAY 4 MILES EAST OF CAPE ALITAK, AK, USA IN LAT. 56 50N., LONG. 154 12W., AT 0600 HOURS LT ON 25/01/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

ALL 7 CREW ABANDONED SHIP. 2 CREW RESCUED FROM WATER BY USCG MH-60 HELICOPTER AND TAKEN TO HOSPITAL IN KODIAK. 5 CREW RESCUED FROM LIFERAFT BY FV 'TUXEDNI' AND TAKEN TO LAZY BAY, AK. NO SERIOUS INJURIES REPORTED. LIST DEVELOPED AFTER EXCESSIVE ICE FORMED ON THE DECK CAUSING LOSS OF STABILITY.

During an Emergency drill carried out while un Audit
for of SMC Certificate was in progress with Bureau
Veritas Representative, a seaman xxx was involved in an accident, remaining locked in 
a watertight door n. 8, deck n. 2.
Immediately, he has received the first aid 
and transferred to local Hospital of Bari, where is 
hospitalized in serious conditions.

MT JAG PRAKASH COLLIDED WITH MT DOJA WHILE NAVIGATING IN THE GULF OF KUTCH, INDIA, THE COLLISION OCCURED DUE TO LACK OF EFFECTIVE MONITORING AND POOR SITUATIONAL AWARENESS OF TRAFFIC BY BOTH THE VESSELS. THE CONTRIBUTORY CAUSE INCLUDED INADEQUATE MANNING OF THE BRIDGE WATCH, AND NAVIGATIONAL LIGHTS BEING NOT SWITCHED ON.

On 23 January 2012, the Maltese registered bulk carrier MV Bargara was discharging its Canola cargo at Berth 11 at Fangcheng port in China.  At about 1330, the AB on duty went down into cargo hold no. 3 to loosen up areas of the cargo to facilitate the unloading.  The mechanical grabber in use to unload the Canola cargo, and which was being operated by a shore crane operator, caught the AB from his legs. 

As a result of this accident, the 25 year old AB suffered severe injuries and consequently lost both his legs. 
 
The safety investigation identified safety issues related to risk awareness, risk acceptance and communication.

Location: PHILIPPINE SEA 32 MILES SOUTHEAST OF NANGUMBUAYA POINT, CATANDUANES, PHILIPPINES
SummaryOfEvents:
SANK AFTER DEVELOPING LIST IN THE PHILIPPINE SEA 32 MILES SOUTHEAST OF NANGUMBUAYA POINT, CATANDUANES, PHILIPPINES IN LAT. 13 25N., LONG. 124 48E., AT 2047 HOURS LT ON 21/01/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER.

2 COAST GUARD VESSELS, HELICOPTERS AND A NAVAL VESSEL ATTENDED THE SCENE. ALL 14 CREW ABANDONED SHIP ON TO LIFE RAFTS. MV 'ORIENTAL XANADU' RESCUED 11 CREW AND A NEARBY FISHING VESSEL RESCUED 3 CREW AT 0920 HOURS LT ON 22/01/12. NO INJURIES REPORTED.

Location: KOREA STRAIT 30 MILES NORTHWEST OF KITAKYUSHU, JAPAN
SummaryOfEvents:
THE CAMBODIAN-FLAGGED GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'DE CHENG' CAUGHT FIRE IN HOLD IN THE KOREA STRAIT 30 MILES NORTHWEST OF KITAKYUSHU, JAPAN IN LAT. 34 13N., LONG. 130 29E., AT 1815 HOURS LT ON 21/01/12. DAMAGED BEYOND REPAIR AND SUBSEQUENTLY BROKEN UP IN A UNDISCLOSED YARD IN JAPAN.

3 COASTGUARD VESSELS PROCEEDED TO THE SCENE AND RESCUED ALL 9 CREW. NO INJURIES REPORTED. DEVELOPED LIST TO PORT DURING FIREFIGHTING OPERATIONS. BLAZE SUBSEQUENTLY EXTINGUISHED AND TOWED TO SAFE ANCHORAGE FOR INSPECTION. TOWED TO MOJI, JAPAN ON 28/01/12 FOR FURTHER INSPECTIONS. EXTENT OF DAMAGE UNKNOWN.

Location: Off the Iranian coast near the port of Bandar Abbas
SummaryOfEvents: A passenger ship carrying 22 people capsized and sank during a storm off the Iranian coast near the port of Bandar Abbas on Saturday, 21st January 2012. The ship was sailing from the island of Hormuz to Bandar Abbas. Media reports say that the boat began its 11 mile journey despite a travel ban on small boats by shipping authorities, due to a storm with winds of about 50 mph. The report did not give the cause of the incident but said that in heavy winds and bad weather the boat (allegedly) ran out of fuel before capsizing and sinking.  Only seven people were rescued, and 15 are still missing. Rescue efforts were continuing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: SULU SEA OFF THE COAST OF SAN JOSE, ANTIQUE, PHILIPPINES
SummaryOfEvents:
THE FILIPINO-FLAGGED GENERAL CAROG SHIP 'SEAFORD 2' SUSTAINED TEAR IN HULL, TOOK WATER AND SANK IN THE SULU SEA OFF THE COAST OF SAN JOSE, ANTIQUE, PHILIPPINES EARLY AM ON 21/01/12 AND REQUESTED ASSISTANCE.

VESSEL DEVELOPED LIST TO STARBOARD. ALL 17 CREW ABANDONED SHIP AND TOOK TO LIFERAFTS AT 0230 HOURS LT ON 22/01/12 SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY LOCAL COASTGUARD. ANTI POLLUTION BOOMS DEPLOYED TO CONTAIN OIL SPILL. NO INJURIES REPORTED. TEAR IN HULL POSSIBLY CAUSED BY STRIKING A ROCK.

SOLASStatus: CASTA DIVA: SOLAS, STARLIGHT VENTURE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: While transiting the Singapore Strait, the Hong Kong, China flagged oil tanker, STARLIGHT VENTURE, attempted to overtake the Liberian flagged vessel, CASTA DIVA, leaving the Deep Water Route. STARLIGHT VENTURE altered her course 'hard to port' towards CASTA DIVA. The Master attempted to radio STARLIGHT VENTURE and ordered 'full astern', both in attempt to avoid the collision. However, STARLIGHT VENTURE collided into CASTA DIVA. There were no injuries or incidents of pollution reported.

SOLASStatus: ADRIA BLU: Unknown/unspecified, AMIR H: SOLAS, SLOCHTERDIEP: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 2 A.M. today due to bad weather the vessel attempted to be shifted in a safer location. During maneuvering of the vessel ship collided with two other ships (the Dutch-flagged Slochterdiep and Tanzania-flagged Adria Blu). As a result of collision vessel suffer a crack at the port side in way of cargo hold number four (4) (approximate length of crack 1 meter) and water ingress within the cargo hold. The vessel is currently listed 19 – 20 degrees starboard side.

m/v CSAV TOTORAL had departed from Cristobal on 11 January 2012 and was on her way to Rotterdam. On 18 January while passing the Azores Island MOB alarm was triggered after the 2nd engineer was found to be absent. 
After inquiries early on 18 January revealed that the 2nd engineer had been seen around 22:30 hours the last night before lastly and a following thorough search around the vessel was in vain the MOB alarm was triggered. 
The MRCCs La Palmas, Lisboa, Ponta Delgada, the US and Netherland's Coast Guard responded on the distress alert immediately and Ponta Delgada was assigned to act as Search and Rescue Unit (SRU) for this SAR operation. Further engaged in the mission was the Portuguese aircraft "Rescue 22" and the Navy vessel "N.R.P.J. Candido".
While CSAV TOTORAL returned and searched back on her recorded ECDIS track the aircraft and the naval vessel searched the dimensions ot the defined area. 
CSAV TOTORAL returned all the way towards the position where the 2nd engineer had been allegedly seen the last time and reported the result of the search to the SRU. After almost 38 hours of unsuccessful search the SAR was officially terminated and the vessel was suspended from any further activities. MRCC Punta Delgado informed all other participants to terminate the SAR and CSAV TOTORAL resumed her voyage to Rotterdam. 
The corpse of the lost seafarer was not found.
A police investigation initiated upon arrival of CSAV TOTORAL at Rotterdam revealed a non-criminal background of the loss of the seafarer. A police report is on file. 
Considering the overall aspect of the occurrence it appears to be a matter of conjecture that the 2nd engineer fell over board accedentally while removing waste as traces found 
The flag State safety investigation Authority is in process of analysing the occurrence in close cooperation with the company to identify if the accident is possibly connnected to such human elements like fatigue, stress, alcohol or purely to negligence.
At the request of the flag State, the occurrence was declassified.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed
Cargo1: general cargo in containers, includes DG

SOLASStatus: Dette G: Unknown/unspecified, DETTE G.: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: At 23:09 hrs on 16 January 2012, an able seaman (AB) on board Antigua & Barbuda registered container ship Dette G died as a result of falling overboard during cargo operations while the ship was moored alongside Queen Elizabeth Dock in Hull, UK. The AB fell into a narrow gap between the ship and the quay when disembarking from the ship through a pilot gate. He quickly disappeared from view and his  body was not recovered from the water until the following morning.

Location: BIGHT OF BENIN 90 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PORT HARCOURT, NIGERIA
SummaryOfEvents:
THE OFFSHORE CONSTRUCTION VESSEL 'MAKO' CAUGHT FIRE AFTER A BLOW OUT ON ADJACENT OIL RIG 'KS ENDEAVOR' IN THE BIGHT OF BENIN 90 MILES SOUTHWEST OF PORT HARCOURT, NIGERIA IN LAT. 04 21N., LONG. 005 47E., AT 0503 HOURS LT ON 16/01/12.

VESSEL WAS ALONGSIDE THE OIL RIG AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT AND CAUGHT FIRE AFTER LEAKING GAS FROM THE BLOW OUT IGNITED. ALL 27 CREW ABANDONED SHIP TO LIFERAFTS AND WERE SUBSEQUENTLY RESCUED BY THE SECURITY VESSEL 'JANIS 1'. NO INJURIES REPORTED. THE FIRE FROM THE BLOW OUT BURNED FOR THE NEXT MONTH AND A HALF AND THE 'MAKO' WAS COMPLETELY DESTROYED AND EVENTUALLY SANK.

Light touch on ground stb. side under pilotage guidance 

The passenger ship DEUTSCHLAND was on a cruise through the group of islands off southern Chile and reached the Italia Glacier in the northern arm of the Beagle Channel on Sunday 15 January 2012 at about 2300. The master, an officer on watch, a helmsman and a pilot were on the bridge. A few minutes before reaching the glacier, the ship's command asked the pilot if it would be acceptable to sail closer to the glacier than planned so as to provide passengers with the best possible view of this area. The pilot responded with a decision to reduce the speed and sail much closer to the glacier.
