The DEUTSCHLAND grounded on her starboard side as she was turning back towards the middle of the fjord two cables away from the coastline. The engine was stopped immediately and instructions to establish the damage to the ship were given.
It was possible to move the ship back in the direction of the middle of the fjord by means of various engine and helm manoeuvres a short time later and continue the voyage to the next port.
Damage to the ship or environment was not found.

The vessel on January 15, 2012 at approximately 13:40 had one explosion followed by another explosion. The vessel broke in half and sank within 25 minutes.  Three Person have died in result of the explosion.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Total loss of the ship

Location: 6-km northwest of Jawol Island, off Incheon
SummaryOfEvents: On 15 January 2012, the Korean small product tanker DOOLA NO. 3 exploded in waters 6-km northwest of Jawol Island, off Incheon.  Eleven crew members are reported missing and feared dead.  The tanker was on its way back to the port of Daesan after unloading a cargo of gasoline at Incheon.

On 15th January 2012 the trawler Tit Bonhomme had taken a battering in rough waters and went down off the west Cork coast after striking rocks in the early hours of Sunday morning. The Irish-registered fishing vessel was heading for shore at Union Hall harbour when she got into difficulties beside the Adam and Eve islands. The crew made a distress call to the coastguard about 6 a.m., but it was cut off and all radio contact was lost.  A lifeboat was launched shortly after 6 a.m. and half an hour later spotted debris in the water, believed to be wreckage from the trawler. Coastguard helicopters from Shannon and Waterford were scrambled to the scene, and one survivor was found in the water at about 08 a.m. Five other crew members are still missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Off the island of Giglio, Tuscany, Italy
SummaryOfEvents:
On 13th January 2012 the Italian passenger ship Costa Concordia departed Civitavecchia en route to Savona, Italy, where it was scheduled to arrive the following morning. A few hours and 40 miles later, the ship struck a rock formation about 450 feet from the coast of Giglio in Tuscany. It began taking on water at about 9:45 p.m local time. The rocks left a 165-foot gash on the port side of Concordia's hull; after the impact, the ship listed at 20 degrees before partially sinking on Saturday morning. Some passengers jumped into the water and swam to safety, but there were delays in getting others into life boats, especially as the vessel had by then rolled over onto her side and many of the lifeboats were inaccessible. Thirty two lives were lost. Some reports indicated that the ship had also suffered a major electrical fault.
There are 2500 tonnes of oil on board, and booms have been placed around the vessel to contain any leaks, but worsening weather conditions and the shifting of the vessel will render these measures les effective. Offloading the fuel cannot be initiated until all rescue operations have been completed.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
THE GENERAL CARGO SHIP 'KATRINE KROG' STRANDED AFTER DRAGGING ANCHOR WHILST MOORED OFF JEREMIE, HAITI ON 13/01/12 IN HEAVY WEATHER. SUBSEQUENTLY TOOK WATER AND SANK ON 02/02/12.

ATTEMPTS TO START MAIN ENGINE WERE UNSUCCESSFUL. VESSEL TOOK WATER FOLLOWING STRANDING. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED. REFLOATING ATTEMPTS BY MV 'NAVAL EXPLORER' ON 10/02/12 AND 13/02/12 UNSUCCESSFUL. FURTHER SALAVGE OPERATIONS ABANDONED AFTER MV 'NAVAL EXPLORER' ALSO STRANDED.

Location: Wharf on the south side of Keiyo Foods Complex,Chiba Port, Tokyo Bay, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
When the ship was entering a port in order to load steel scraps, a stand roller on forecastle deck came off and flew away.
One deck crew (OS) was found collapsed around there and then confirmed dead by a doctor.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
FATALITY (CHIEF MATE) INSIDE CARGO TANK OF SINGAPORE REGISTERED CHEMICAL / GAS TANKER SIGLOO CRYSTAL (IMO NO. 8810188), DRIFTING OFF SHANGHAI, PRC, 9 JANUARY 2012
	On 9 January 2012 at about 1830h, the Indian Chief Mate (Indian CoC) and 2 crew entered the no. 4(S) cargo tank to remove some water near the sump area. At that time, Sigloo Crystal (LoA 131m) was on ballast and drifting off Shanghai, awaiting instructions to enter port.
	After about 10 minutes, the 2 crew reported having headaches and the Chief Mate told them to leave the tank for some fresh air. At about 1845h, the duo re-entered the tank. But after afew minutes, again both reported feeling unwell and the Chief Mate told them to go for a breather. The 2 crew left the tank and met the deck Cadet at the main deck.
According to the agreed tank-entry procedures, the Cadet (standing near the tank opening on the main deck), would every 5 minutes initiate a walkie-talkie call to the Chief Mate to confirm that all is well. At a time recorded as about 1858h, the Chief Mate stopped responding to these calls and the emergency alarm was raised.
Rescue efforts commenced immediately with 2 rescue teams (wearing breathing apparatus) taking turns to enter the tank. At about 1929h, the unconscious Chief Mate was lifted out of the tank on a stretcher. The crew administered CPR but there was no response from the Chief Mate. Some 4 hours later, shore medical officers inspected the Chief Mate but could not detect any life-signs i.e. already dead.
The autopsy report indicated the cause of death as ‘coronary atherosclerosis  heart disease, complicated by Butadiene and CO (carbon monoxide) inhalation. The manner of death is nature (sic)’ i.e. no foul play was suspected.
Investigations revealed that in September 2011, the deceased was certified fit for sea during a pre-employment medical examination. Inspection of the deceased cabin did not revealed anything suspicious or indicate any signs of taking of drugs/medication. It appeared that the deceased was unaware of his heart condition and thus his lowered toxicity threshold and the adverse consequences thereof.
There is also no evidence to suggest any compromise of the procedures with regards to the entry into the no. 4(S) tank and all the gas detection equipment used were found to be working satisfactorily.
Following the incident, the owners enhanced the pre-employment medical examination by including new tests to detect any latent medical condition such as atherosclerosis.

On 9 January 2012, MAERSK CHAMPION was engaged in tanker lifting/heading control off the
Brazilian coast when a fire broke out in the ship’s hospital.
The cause of the fire was most likely self ignition by a chemical reaction between chlorinecontaining
granules and other chemical substances in a plastic box with medicine and chemical
residues located in the ship's hospital.
Initially, an attempt was made to fight the fire with a portable fire extinguisher with dry powder.
However, this was in vain because the fire was already too extensive. Thereafter the fire was
fought and extinguished effectively with water by fire fighting teams using air breathing apparatuses.
A supernumerary master acted as the first man on the fire hose and thus he was the leader
in each fire fighting team with an AB as the 2nd man.
2½ hours after the fire broke out the ship headed for Rio de Janeiro and arrived the next day.
The ship’s hospital burned out and the adjoining corridor, TV/recreation room, mess room and duty
mess was also damaged as a result of the fire. The fire and smoke damages to the ship’s interior
were severe.
During the fire, it appeared that the two accesses to the air compressor for refilling air bottles to the
firemen’s outfits that was situated in the bosun’s store in the forecastle was hindered through the
deck hatch by a locked padlock, and through the accommodation by the dense smoke in the accommodation,
and refilling of air bottles was not possible. Even though this did not create any
problem, it was considered a lesson to be learned.
This report does not contain any recommendation. After this incident, the shipping company has
initiated a number of preventive measures.

Vessel suffered an engine room explosion resulting from the improper installation of a piston and subsequent defects in engine cooling. The explosion badly injured the vessel's oiler and the Fourth Engineer. The Oiler, shortly after being airlifted died from his injuries. The other one survived, however he was repatriated back to the Phillippines.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
Le Jean-Claude Coulon II, Chalutier pêche arrière de 45 mètres, quitte le 29 décembre 2011 le port de Lochinver en Ecosse pour se rendre sur ses  lieux de pêche. La marée est prévue durer 11 jours.
Le 7 janvier 2012, le navire se trouve dans le nord-ouest de l’Ecosse, dans le secteur des îles Hébrides. Il fait mauvais temps. 
En fin de matinée, la fune tribord casse. L’autre fune est virée et le panneau bâbord saisi. Puis, une maille sur le bras bâbord cède. L’ensemble du train de pêche, excepté le panneau déjà embarqué, est perdu.
Un peu avant minuit ; le vent ayant molli, l’opération de  « grappinage » débute afin de récupérer le chalut. Après quelques heures de recherches et plusieurs tentatives infructueuses, le train de pêche perdu est remonté  à la surface, le cul du chalut ayant été croché par le grappin.
Une équipe, composée du bosco, du treuilliste et de deux matelots, est sur le pont pour ma manœuvre de récupération. Le câble est viré au maximum et le grappin se trouve en hauteur, au niveau de la chape de la poulie tribord.
Le bosco se penche par-dessus la lisse et cherche, derrière les fils du vahiné l’endroit le plus approprié pour fixer le croc de la caliorne afin de remonter l’ensemble à bord. A ce moment, vers 03 :10 hrs, le treuil dévire automatiquement d’ environ 2 mètres, du fait du tangage et du poids du train de pêche. Le bosco est entrainé à l’ eau et mortellement blessé par le grappin.
Des bouées couronnes lui sont lancées. Un canot est mis à la mer pour le secourir. Le corps sans vie est récupéré par l’équipe du canot, puis embarqué à bord.
L’hélicoptère  des secours tentera d’hélitreuiller une équipe médicale, sans succès du fait de la force du vent et de l’état de la mer. 
Le navire rentre ensuite à Stornoway.

On 8th January 2012 the MV TYCOON broke its moorings in bad weather and was pushed up against a concrete wall, which was part of the port infrastructure. The crew of 15 were all rescued, but the ship slowly sank in shallow water adjacent to the wharf, and eventually broke in two. The ship was carrying 102 tonnes of lubricating oil, as well as approximately 260 tonnes of bagged phosphate as cargo. As part of the Australian National Contingency Plan a pollution response expert was sent to the scene to manage the situation, together with a marine surveyor to provide expert advice. However, severe weather conditions have so far hampered their task, although the rough seas will assist in the dispersion of any released oil.
To date, the extent of the pollution is unknown, with only 100m of beach affected.

On 4 January 2012, at 1800, the VLCC Seeb entered the Singapore Strait, following the east- bound traffic lane of deep water route.  During her transit in the Strait, Seeb was on manoeuvring speed and hand steering.  The vessel was constrained by her draft and displayed the required signals in the deep water route. 

Kota Tenaga, which was bound for India, had earlier dropped the Singapore PSAM pilot (Jong Fairway).  Her master was taking actions to avoid the west-bound LPG carrier Yosu Gas on her port side.  However, inadvertently, Kota Tenaga manoeuvred in such a way that she entered the Deep Water Route into the path of the east-bound Seeb.  Subsequently, both vessels collided. 

Seeb suffered s ome damages to her forecastle deck fittings, dents and paint scratches on her starboard side shell all the way from stem to the forecastle deck.  Her structural integrity, however, was not breached.  Kota Tenaga sustained damages to fuel tank no. 3 port, resulting in a spill of about 54 metric tonnes of fuel oil, and the loss of two loaded containers of which one was later recovered.  The vessel was rendered unfit to proceed with her voyage.  There were no reports of any injuries from both ships. 

The relevant authorities were informed about this accident.  In line with instructions from VTIS, Singapore, Seeb then proceeded towards Eastern Boarding Ground for anchoring.  Containment and clean-up efforts continued until 07 January 2012.  During this period, there was no disruption to traffic movements in the TSS. 

The safety investigation, which was carried out with the assistance and cooperation of the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, concluded that Kota Tenaga had entered the Deep Water Route and was unaware of Seeb until moments before the collision. 

As a result of the safety investigation, two recommendations have been made to Kota Tenaga’s and Seeb’s managers, which are intended to improve the standard of look-out and bridge watch keeping.

At approximately 20:00 (LT) during rough seas and heavy rain, NOBLE LEONARD JONES, while under tow from Mexico, broke from towage when the towing lines broke and the vessel began drifting during heavy weather conditions. The weather condictions made reconnecting the vessel very difficult and caused further damage to the forward sponsons.

Location: South China Sea, about 150nm west of Manila
InitialEvent: Hoisting of heavy equipment with a rolling sea
SummaryOfEvents:
2	SHIPBOARD ACCIDENT RESULTING IN A FATALITY ONBOARD SRS MT THERESA DUA (IMO NO. 9124055), OPEN SEA ABOUT 150 NM OFF MANILA, PHILIPPINES, 2 JANUARY 2012 AT ABOUT 1600HRS
On the afternoon of 2 January 2012, Theresa Dua (LoA 138m), on ballast, was in open waters and experiencing moderate rolling. The Myanmese deck cadet and one seaman were using a tripod winch to hoist a portable cargo pump from a cargo tank. The seaman was on deck operating the winch while the cadet was inside the tank, climbing a fixed step-ladder while manually (hand) guiding the pump.
When the pump was about 2 metres from the deck opening, the vessel experienced a heavy roll. The pump hurled violently against the cadet and caused him to fall to the tank top – a height of about 9m. The Myanmese Master (Myanmar CoC) and Chief Officer arrived at the scene soon after to render first aid. The cadet was coherent and although complaining about pain of his right arm and stomach, declined being strapped to a stretcher. He managed to climb the stairs by himself with assistance of the crew.
The Master requested for medi-evacuation but the nearest MRCC (Philippines Coast Guard) could not provide such services. The Master then diverted to the nearest port of Manila, some 150 nm away. Meanwhile the crew was in regular contact with the Manila medical team to monitor the cadet’s condition. However, on 3 January at about 0030hrs, the cadet succumbs to his injuries and died onboard. The port-mortem report indicates the cause of death as internal injuries and no foul play was suspected.
Investigations revealed that no instructions were given to the crew to hoist the pump but only to clean the cargo tank. Apparently, the seaman and cadet, on their own accord, carried out the task without any risk assessment, authorisation or supervision.

Location: Along side loading berth at Cockatoo Island, Western
SummaryOfEvents: the vessel reported that the Second Officer was injured when releasing the break on the "spring" drum, being caught on the upper left arm and under the armpit area by the break arm. The incident occurred berthed at Cockatoo Island Iron Ore facility while the vessel commenced to shiffting on 2th january 2012 at 0450.  At 0500 the after deck reported that the Second Officer had been injured.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: On 01st JAN. 2012 AT AROUND 1740 HRS/LT. O/S X WHILE PREPARING TO READ THE FODDER INSIDE TANK, A/B  Y AS LOOKOUT, SUDDENLY SAW THE PELLETS SLIDING DOWN AND HE SAW O/S  X FELL DOWN COVERED THE REST OF HIS BODY. A/B  Y IMMEDIATELY REPORT TO C/O VIA VHF RADIO WORKING CHANNEL 71 ABOUT THE INCIDENT AND HE SHOUT FOR HELP TO O/S XXX AND MESSMAN XXXX  AROUND THE VICINITY. ABOUT FEW MINUTES THE C/O AND SECOND OFFICER TOGETHER WITH THE CREW ARRIVED AND RESCUE OPERATION COMMENCE TO RECOVERED THE CASUALTY. AT AROUND 1810HRS/LT O/S X RESCUED AND FOUND OUT DEAD ON THE SPOT DUE TO HIS HEAD AND BODY WAS BUMPED TOWARD THE STRAIGHT LADDER PLATFORM LYING DOWN WITH BROKEN HELMET COVERED WITH PELLETS SLIDE DOWN. HE HAS SUFFERED A LEFT UPPER EYEBROW AND LEFT EAR OPEN WOUND DUE TO THE STRONG BROKEN HELMET IMPACT THAT CAN CAUSED OF OPEN WOUND.

The passenger ship, RABAUL QUEEN departed Kimbe for Lae (280 nautical miles) with 360 passengers and a crew of 15 persons on board at 1100 on 1 January 2012.  Sea conditions were north-westerly winds of less than 10 knots and smooth seas.  Conditions worsened as the ship reached Cape Campbell on the eastern side of Willaumez Peninsula, where rough seas, rain and strong north-westerly winds prevailed; causing spray from the sea to come over the starboard side of the ship.  Passengers moved to the port side of the ship or inside to keep dry.  The movement of passengers combined with the wind exerting a force on the starboard side of the ship, resulted in the ship developing a port list.  At 0220 on 2 February, the Chief Mate altered the course to make for the Nessup Channel.  At 0330, the Master was called to navigate the ship through the Siassi Islands and into the Vitiaz Strait.  On leaving the lee of Umboi Island, steering became uneasy, as winds had increased to between 20 and 30 knots and the seas to 3.0 m.  The Master took the ship out of auto-pilot, into hand steering and took the helm.  The prevailing winds and the imbalance of the ship caused her to maintain port list, exposing more of its starboard side to the weather and sea.  At 0615, a large wave hit the ship on its starboard quarter.  The stern was pushed to port and the ship heeled heavily over to port, causing her to come beam onto the north-westerly.  The Master lost steerage of the ship and was not able to bring its head back around the port.  A second wave hit the starboard side of the ship as it was returning to the upright, causing it again to heel over to port.  The heel angle was far greater and resulted in the ship’s port side becoming submerged causing water to flood into the accommodation.  The ship was heeled over for a shot time when a third wave hit the exposed hull and the ship capsized.   Due to the speed at which the ship capsized, the Master did not have time to give a mayday signal.  The Master and 3 employees were in the wheelhouse as it filled up with water.  Three of the four men were able to swim to safety before the ship sank.  Liferafts, lifejackets and buoyant flotation devices floated to the surface.  Survivors managed to swim to liferafts, while others were assisted on board.  The first rescue ship arrived at 0940; 3 hours after the ship sank.  246 passengers were rescued, 4 were pronounced dead and as many as 161 persons were considered to be missing and presumed dead.
As the ship sank, fuel and bilge oil from the engine room began to float on the surface of the sea.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Pollution,Total loss of the ship

Location: ANCHORAGE AREA AND BREAKWATER OF HAMRIYEH PORT. SHARJAN UAE
SummaryOfEvents:
LADY MOON (Panama)
Dubai, Jan 16 -- Bunkering tanker Lady Moon (137 gt, built 2006) carrying diesel fuel sunk about 500 metres off the coast of Hamriyah, today, but all five crewmen were rescued, according to Sharjah Hamriyah port officials. The vessel started having technical problems when it was 10 nautical miles offshore, officials said. When attempts to fix the issues failed, the Master of the vessel contacted Al Hamriyah Port officials for help. The Master told the port's sea monitors at the control unit that the vessel's engines were struggling. Later, he told them he had lost control of the vessel's steering, and by then the vessel, loaded with diesel fuel cargo, had started sinking. The control unit notified the coast guard, which rushed to the vessel and rescued the five Indian crewmen, officials said. jung-woo 2 set sail from the port of Montevideo, Uruguay to go longline
fishing for mero. It had arrived in the Antarctic and was sailing toward its
place of operation when, at about 01:00 on January 1, 2012, on the water
about 1,620 miles south of New Zealand, it sank after a fire broke out under
the poop deck.
